column3: and step-by-step techniques.  My greatest concern is once again finding the trademarked material TYVEK utilized in craft work.  The makers of TYVEK specifically have stated it is never to be heated or used other than for what it is specifically designed for.  Deathly toxic
column4: once more it is appalling to find it used with a 'heat outdoors' statement attached.  Does the company know this material is being used this way???  As an art educator I must not only be aware of this safety info for myself but for my students.  Poor editing let this one slip by

column1: I read Lucky or Smart after receiving a recommendation from a very creditable source.  However
column2: it was a great disappointment
column3: and in my opinion
column4: a waste of money.  $13.95 (as per the inside cover of the book) for 58 pages that delivered little value.    Bo Peabody may himself be both lucky and smart for founding and selling a low revenue-no profit generating internet company during the internet bubble; I hope you are lucky enough to read this review and then smart enough to avoid purchasing his book.  My brief summary of the lessons from the book follows:  Chapter 1:  Start a company that is innovative
column5: morally compelling and philosophically positive;  this will attract smart
column6: motivated people that will do great things because they are smart and motivated (Enron aside) Chapter 2:  you are born an entrepreneur or a manager - accept who you are because you cannot change Chapter 3:  entrepreneurs are B students
column7: managers are A students - unfortunately I was a B student in high school and an A student in college
column8: something the author does not address Chapter 4:  strive to be good enough to survive; if you do you will be bought by a company that can make you great; but don't be great on your own or you will not survive Chapter 5:  have faith Chapter 6:  don't take no for an answer Chapter 7:  entrepreneurs don't have power - "get used to it" Chapter 8:  stay calm and be gracious in difficult situations Chapter 9:  read the WSJ daily
column9: the NY times on Sunday and pick one other reputable weekly or monthly business magazine - and don't read any other form of press Chapter 10:  always sell Chapter 11:  know what you don't know  after reading the above there is no reason for you to purchase the book unless you want to know more about Bo Peabody or the companies he founded.  That is all there is
column10: except for a number of tangentially related stories that involve Bo and his limited experiences in the business world (I say this because he was in his early thirties when this book was written).  Instead of reading Lucky or Smart I would highly recommend the Richest Man in Babylon or Rich Dad Poor Dad.

column1: This is a delicate subject which has interested and concerned me for some time now. I've always found it difficult to know how to respond when I find out that someone is gay
column2: and it's even more confusing and potentially devastating if it's someone close to you
column3: like a family member or someone you love. Acceptance would be one straightforward option
column4: if it weren't such a challenging concept in the context of "family"
column5: or someone you "love". This book's emphasis seems to be in trying to make the gay person realise that they can change
column6: and then applying whatever pressure is necessary to make them do so. This is all very well
column7: but in my experience gay people are usually very reluctant to change
column8: and even claim that their gaiety is something they're born with. We more melancholy members of society can find such attachment to gayness disconcerting
column9: and it's therefore understandable that members of a morose family would want to undermine any gayness in their midst at whatever cost. Some would say that people of all temperaments across the whole range of emotions
column10: from ecstatic elation to suicidal depression
column11: just have to accept each other and get on with things the best they can. However
column12: this doesn't take into account the fact that
column13: as highlighted by this book
column14: love often necessitates cruelty
column15: especially where excessive gaiety is concerned

column1: Keynes was no doubt an influential economist.  His theories and 'expertise' on economics influenced the post-New Deal economic policies of the United States and the internationalist wealth redistribution schemes like IMF.  However
column2: his ideas on economics failed miserably and it was application of Keynesian ideas that wrecked so much havoc on the U.S. particularly in the 1970s with the stagflation (an inflationary recession with unemployment which was theoretically impossible accordingly to Keynesism.)  We have Keynes to thank for budget deficits and the nebulous idea that we can spend ourselves into prosperity through the largesse of the federal government.  Read Planning for Freedom or Socialism by Ludwig von Mises instead

column1: If you have had little or no exposure to North American culture or media

column3: Lisa Johnson's advice seems largely based upon common sense or on how to not be lower class.  Very little useful specific information is given.  I also disliked the author's approach to meeting people.  In the unlikely event that one does see a millionaire in the 7-11
column4: it's just not the sort of place that one socializes and properly meets people.  Yet that's just the sort of thing that is suggested by the author.  The general lack of propriety in her methods is what makes this book poor instruction unless you really need the basics.  Try Ginie Polo Sayles's book for something a bit more useful

column1: Ok
column2: I don't mean to be rude
column3: but if you think this is great writing you are woefully uneducated. It is almost a sad confirmation of the common stereotype of fundamentalist Christians being uneducated yokels that so many of them think this is great writing. Here's my take: I'd enjoy a good "end of times" story - this just isn't it. The Left Behind series is amateurish and poorly written and just plain astonishing to me that it has had such huge success. P.T. Barnum once said that no one ever went broke understimating the intelligence of the American public and this series proves it. Christians should demand better writing from their revered authors. Go read some C.S. Lewis or something - please.

Each chapter represents a step in the instructional design process. This is the best feature of the book. But then the model/book goes into minutia and makes for heavy & confusing reading. In fact

column1: I was highly anticipating this book but when I received it I became disappointed. Based on reviews and recommendations
column2: I was hoping to find an exposition of Christ's teachings
column3: i.e. the Sermon on the Mount
column4: with the Older Testament scriptures as a back drop and context for His words. Unfortunately
column5: what I found was an antithesis rather than continuity between Christ and the New Testament Scriptures over against the Older Testament Scriptures. One example of this is where the authors are [basically] saying that Christ and the New Testament abolished the penalty for capital crimes
column6: i.e.
column7: the death penalty for murder. The book states that Genesis 9:6 is more than likely a proverb. They state that the New Testament only refers to the death penalty in a negative way
column8: i.e.
column9: its abuse and misuse and therefore has been abolished.  Since when did man's abuse of any portion of God's law make that portion of the law null and void? It is my understanding that only God has the authority to make void any portion of His law. I don't understand how the authors reasoned from scripture to come up with such a conclusion and I would disagree strongly with it. I admit I did not read the entire book but after sampling just a small portion and finding what I consider a poor hermeneutic and exegesis on such an important ethical issue that is clearly taught in the scripture to be continual and binding on all people and nations
column10: I lost confidence and interest and sent it back for a refund from the seller. It is too bad so many writers
column11: readers
column12: etc. pit the first 39 books of the Bible against the last 27 resulting in neo-nomianism (at best) to anti-nomianism (at worst).  I would recommend Kenneth L. Gentry
column13: Jr.'s book: God's Law in the Modern World. It honors God's law and teaches God's law is for modern man and continually binding unless otherwise clearly nullfied by God himself through additional revelation. After all
column14: it is His Law and Word and is not to be added to or taken away

column1: I thought I was going to get a thriller when I first heard of this.  Instead I got a pseudo-sequel to COLD MOUNTAIN set in 1980 Texas
column2: and I have rather low opinions of COLD MOUNTAIN.  It was difficult to follow the story due to McCarthy's decision to not only avoid using quotation marks to identify dialogue (a move I've always considered to be a pretentious affectation)
column3: but also commas
column4: apostrophes
column5: and proper spelling
column6: such as not capitalizing "English" or using "livingroom" instead of "living room" and "mam" instead of "ma'am."  I don't know if this is something McCarthy does in all his books or this was a one-time deal
column7: but it was a major turnoff and made the experience grueling rather than enjoyable.  I also didn't see the relevance of the italicized monologues of Sheriff Bell at the beginning of each chapter/section
column8: as he tended to ramble on about life after  World War Two and how it wasn't uncommon to see 22-year-olds as ordained ministers or 25-year-olds as sheriffs of counties the size of Delaware.  Hopefully its movie adaptation (which I legitimately pity the Coen Brothers for having to wade through) is more accessible

column1: I admit I didn't finish reading this book
column2: as I was so confused after a few chapters that I gave up. 1. It is unclear what exactly Ladoux means by emotion. Sometimes it seems that he is only talking about emotions that result in an action. (Reasonable as that's what you can test) But there are passages when he talks about "liking" somebody as an emotion. column1: I bought this as my first book on homeopathic medicine in order to learn more about it.  My conclusion is that there is woefully inadequate evidence to support the theory.  If I were to claim to have a Toyota in my garage
column2: you shouldn't be too surprised or demand extremely strong evidence in order to believe me.  This is because there are clearly many people who do in fact have a Toyota in the garage.  This is a very orinary claim.  On page 12 of Everybody's Guide
column3: the author points out that "Most scientists believe that no medicine diluted more than 12c potency could have any biochemical effect
column4: since it is improbable that any molecules of the original substance remain."  This belief is based on basic prinicples of the very well developed fields of Biology and Chemistry.  If Homeopathic medicine did work in dilutions more than 12c
column5: it would shatter some basic principles of Chemistry and Biology.  Unlike religious leaders
column6: scientists fantasize about making or proving a discovery that shatters currently accepted models.  This type of discovery can clearly lead to a Nobel prize and world-wide fame in the scientific community.  In order to believe a claim that shatters currently accepted models of Biology and Chemistry
column7: we need evidence of extraordinary quality.  On page xiv in the preface
column8: the author reports on a 1991 study by three Dutch professors.  Of 107 trials
column9: they found 22 studies that met their criteria for scientific quality.  Of these
column10: 15 showed that homeopathic medicines worked.    It is of course possible that these studies were somehow flawed or fraudulent
column11: or that they lacked the statistical certainty to overthrow currently accepted science.  As I said
column12: we need evidence of extraordinary quality.  I don't know what happened to the Dutch  professors after 1991
column13: but I haven't seen any Nobel prizes awarded!  Things that really exist develop and improve over time.  Look how much science has advanced in the past 100 years.  How much has Homeopathy advanced in the past 180 years?  Not much as far as I can tell.  Save your money on Homeopatyic books and medicines.  Eat well
column14: get plenty of excercise and sleep
column15: and go to a real doctor when you have a medical problem

column1: This book is about a Jewish girl named Hannah Green who flees from Spain in fear of the Spanish Inquisition after witnessing her mother being captured and burned alive at the stakes for being a Jew.  She comes to England with her father and lives as a Christian while following the Jewish religion in secrecy.  Through a chain of events she becomes a royal fool and a spy - for both Queen Mary and Elizabeth.   Throughout the book Hannah talks about how she misses her mother and can still smell her mother's burning flesh from the stakes and then also professes her love for Queen Mary and what a wonderful woman she is.  It is well documented in history as well as this book about Queen Mary's burning of hundreds of non-Catholics at the stakes.  A practice that earned her the name - Bloody Mary.  The book is very sympathetic towards Queen Mary and portrays her as a virtuous woman who believed that she was burning people for their own sake - "only doing what she believed to be right in her heart".    The fact that Hannah was living her life in fear of being discovered as a Jew and continued to deeply love Queen Mary was extremely unbelievable and ridiculous. I could not help but roll my eyes every time I read how much Hannah loved and admired Queen Mary.
Beside the fact that time has long passed this book by
column2: it is utterly unreadable given the tedious writing. The term "Cultural Creative" is so self-congratulatory and pretentious as to be nauseating. This is strictly for San Franciscans lost in a time warp

column13: perhaps

I picked up a bargain copy of this at a bookstore and was glad I hadn't paid full price for it. The topic is interesting to me as I love eating at fine-dining restaurants
column2: but this book was not a worthwhile exploration of that topic. I was hoping for the kind of insider scoop on restaurant operations you get from
column3: say
column4: Anthony Bourdain's books. Instead
column5: this is all about how you
column6: the lowly restaurant-going peasant
column7: should suck up to hosts
column8: waiters and chefs because what they do is soooo cool and you are soooo not worthy of their time and effort. I kept thinking of the term "scenester" when I read this - someone who is so interested in getting into the "hot" place du jour that they'll do anything short of humiliating themselves to get inside. The whole tone of the book is fawning towards chefs and restaurant owners/personnel and there's not really a lot of "insider" information here that you couldn't figure out for yourself. And the book is overcomplimentary towards restaurant people in the extreme. Shaw's book makes it seem like if a restaurant treats a customer poorly
column9: it's obviously the customer's fault because fine restaurants run by celebrated chefs are pinnacles of perfection and couldn't possibly do anything wrong. It seemed to me like Shaw mainly wrote this book to give props to his chef friends and get accolades from people in the business for writing a book that made them look so good
column10: and therefore get nsider access to even more chefs/restaurateurs (and free gourmet meals
column11: of course). I don't think there was an honest intention here to give any kind of real "inside" story.  I agree with the reviewer who said this book is a lot like the discourse you'll find on eGullet
column12: pretentious and self-righteously obsessed with details the average person could care less about. I couldn't even finish reading this. Another book for the charity pile
column13: although frankly I feel bad about inflicting this on anyone else

column1: This book will certainly appeal to people who want to bash Saudi Arabia. The author
column2: a Lebanese
column3: shows a particularly Levantine distain for the Saudis. He considers them creatures from the sand and thus colors his entire commentary with more venom than really necessary.  Are there corrupt members of the Saudi ruling family? Certainly. Is the family
column4: as a whole
column5: corrupt? No. Many are pious
column6: charitable
column7: open-minded and liberal.  Aburish takes up too much time discussing what amounts to no more than street gossip and not enough on what's really going on.   He also factually misrepresents the early 20th C. in Saudi Arabia. It was a harsh place with a harsh justice. Feuding tribes slaughtered others; they did not "count coup" as did American Plains Indians. They fought viciously and were fought against viciously. It wasn't only Abdel Aziz who put his enemies to the sword--members of his own family were similarly treated by both other tribes and the Ottoman Turks.  It's really a pity that many will buy this book expecting to "get the goods" on the Saudis. What they are getting
column8: instead
column9: is spite expressed by a "civilized" Arab for his "dirty
column10: sandy cousins". It's a frequent lament: "Oh
column11: how could this uncultured Saudis have the luck to be sitting on all that oil
column12: while we
column13: the cultured elite
column14: have nothing!

column1: Having read "The Millionaire Next Door
column2:
as well as most if not all of the classics in this category, I expected life-altering experiences with this book.  There were too many statistics, and statistics that contradicted one another, not to mention generalizations about various subgroups that, try as I did, I had to put my copy down and use it at first for a door stop, then because the cover art is great, I decided leaving it on the coffee table makes a great conversation piece.  
 What we have here is Moore retelling the stories of Peter Pan"
column3: "Alice in Wonderland" and "The Wizard of Oz".  He strips the tales of their fantasy elements
column4: placing the characters of Wendy
column5: Alice and Dorothy in real life situations of sexual awakening.  Of course the idea of fairy tales and folklore carrying at their heart
column6: themes of sexuality
column7: is nothing new
column8: but here Moore puts aside any pretense of masking those themes behind the fantastic.  We are delivered these tales from the mouths of the protaganists themselves
column9: Wendy now middle aged
column10: Dorothy several years into adulthood
column11: and Alice apparently over 50.  The three meet as tenants in a French hotel on the eve of WWI.  Together they bond through their bizarre tales and form a three way affair
column12: which is Moore's first mistake.  Far too much of the writing takes place in the present
column13: and we are forced to bear witness to the laughable sexploits of the three.  I'm not adverse to sexual tension shown between the women
column14: but page after page we are given graphic depictions of their encounters
column15: complete with ridiculous banter.  The meat of "Lost Girls" should have been the tales themselves
column16: but about half the writing is devoted to the asinine sexual escapades occuring at the hotel.  As for the tales themselves
column17: they were inspired
column18: particularly Wendy's tale
column19: but the revelations contained within them not grand enough to warrant much more than a passing reflection.  I kept wondering when the series would redeem itself for such vulgarity
column20: but it never fully did.  As for the art...  Apparently Melinda Gebbie was seeking to capture the feel of turn of the century children's literature
column21: illustrations fitting for the original works from which this series pulled
column22: but at that she fails miserabley.  Her work came off as completely uneducated and reminded me of Henry Darger ("Realms of the Unreal") minus the naive beauty.  Her splash pages succeed
column23: but almost every cell in the books should have been rejected.  That brings me to an additional point- was anyone properly editing this!?  Time and again we are given errors in text
column24: problems with the context of the writing itself
column25: not to mention my previous complaints about moronic dialogue and far too much time spent with the women cavorting at the hotel
column26: as well as a half baked tie in with the coming Great War.  Has Moore's past works made him immune from editorial criticism and censure?  It would appear so

column1: I've found the BEFSX41 (v2.0) to be very problematic.  With firmware version 1.50.18
column2: some distributed network software such as bittorrent will cause the router to reboot itself every 5 minutes
column3: bringing down the entire net.  With the newer firmware version 1.52.10 it fixes this problem
column4: but within a day starts to block or deny connections to our web server (passthru tcp port 80)
column5: making the router totally unusable.  Tech support was friendly and helpful
column6: and the only solution they could come up with was to rollback the firmware to 1.50.18 for our websites
column7: and upgrade each time to 1.52.10 whenever we had the need for distributed networking.  So now we upgrade/downgrade the firmware sometimes several times in a single week
column8: and each time we do it brings down our net.  I've also found that some of the setup options are restrictive compared to other brands.  You cannot assign a static ip to a local computer by specifying its MAC address.  Instead you need to set the ip of the computer manually and this makes things very difficult for our laptops that need static ips.  Also
column9: it appears that you cannot map two different external ports to the same internal port number
column10: even though they map to two different computers.  This makes it impossible
column11: for example
column12: to allow remote desktop access to two different local computers at the same time

column4: 000 deaths would have been impossible to keep a secret. Anderson claims around 30
column5: 000 Mau Mau died during the course of the rebellion which is closer to the truth

column5: did you see that?  Ugh!   The writing is amateurish at best. Similes and metaphors are conspicuously absent
column6: but there are plenty of adverbs and adverbial phrases to fill the gap.   The author switches back and forth between referring to his characters by their first and their last names; sometimes he uses one and then - in the very next sentence! - the other. "Michael grabbed her by the shoulders and turned her around. O'Rourke saw the tears in her eyes and tried to put his arms around her..."  He makes many grammatical errors

column2: people have been giving this book good reviews.  My personal opinion is that the book is terrible.  Part of the problem with books of this nature is that historians don't understand biology
column3: and biologists don't understand history.  Kelly's major fault lies in his understanding of plague's biology.  He suggests that the Black Death may have been the reason for the increased frequency of the CCR5-delta32 allele deletion.  He cites an article from 1998.  I doubt he read the article nor anything about the topic further.  In the original journal article (Stephens
column4: et al.
column6: Am. J. Hum. Gen.
column8: the Swedes
column9: at 14%
column10: have the highest frequency of the deletion with the Chinese as the lowest.  The Black Death struck China too
column11: so why do so few people have the deletion there?  This same problem plagues (pun very much intended) Scott & Duncan's work (Biology of Plagues
column12: 2001; Return of the World's Greatest Serial Killer
column13: 2005).  What Kelly fails to miss is the abundance of research that shows that Y. pestis doesn't interact with the chemokine receptors
column14: which would have caused the elevation of frequency (the CCR5-delta32 allele deletion confers protection against AIDS).  This is just one of many faults in his presentation of Y. pestis as the causative agent of the Black Death.  He also plagarizes; see p. 25 of his work and p. 24 of Herlihy's The Black Death and the Transformation of the West

column10: exchanging it for Peter Kump's book. Absolutely no regrets. Comprehension and recall/retention of material are very important to me. Having these while reading at tremendous speeds is a true sign of speed reader. Power Reading barely covered these topics

column1: Some people collect Tarot decks for their art
column2: and this deck is indeed attractive.  Some use the Tarot as a personal mediation tool
column3: and for those who wish to meditate on specific feminine aspects
column4: this deck may prove useful.  As a divination tool
column5: I found it didn't suit my needs.  The artwork
column6: while lovely
column7: has a misty quality to it
column8: which can make it rather hard to focus on details.  Some of the images are just too blurred.  (As an aside
column9: a color-blind person really ought to avoid this deck
column10: more than one person with color-vision problems has mentioned the cards all look 'muddy'.)  The cards are large
column11: making them difficult to shuffle for multiple-card layouts.  Since this is a "Goddess' tarot
column12: traditionally 'male' cards in the Major Arcana are replaced with Goddess figures (though there are still 'King" cards
column13: and so forth)
column14: and that's where it gets bumpy for me.  It felt like the deck's creator really had to dig to find Goddess to match the archetypes associated with the Major Arcana
column15: resulting in the presentation of Goddess-figures that may be unfamiliar to those either more accustomed to a particular tradition
column16: or haven't a working background of world mythology.  Also
column17: since the Major Arcana draws from *so many* different cultures
column18: the Goddess aspects are truncated
column19: and shifting from Norse
column20: to Egyptian
column21: to Celtic
column22: to Indian
column23: to Russian
column24: and even to archetypes that really aren't 'Goddesses' but women prominent in myth and legend...  disturbs the flow of the Major Arcana.    The Major Arcana is supposed to reflect the spiritual journey
column25: from the beginning (to use the deck's name) to the last
column26: the World/Universe.  Jumping around from culture to culture
column27: giving only the most basic introduction to these Goddesses is distracting to say the least.  Some of the attributions are inaccurate
column28: as well.  Each suit of the Minor Arcana is
column29: with this deck
column30: the 'Path' of a particular Goddess.  To Frejya is given the Suit of Cups
column31: the 'water' suit
column32: and the suit of emotions.  Frejya is not 'just' the Norse goddess of love and beauty
column33: She is also a Warrior Goddess
column34: chief of the Valkyries
column35: a teacher of shamanic magic
column36: a strong fertility goddess
column37: and She receives half of the chosen slain the Valkyries escort to Asgard.  (Since there actually *is* a 'Path of Freyja' in a certain tradition
column38: it's doubly off.)  This deck reduces Her to the 'Love Goddes' and diminishes Her in the processs.  If so much is overlooked with this one Goddess I know well
column39: I question the accuracy of other attributions made to the other Goddesses.  It seems more like the Goddesses were made to fit into a prescribed role--which hardly seems respectful.  The decks is *called* the Goddess Tarot
column40: but really only shows one aspect of the Goddess--the gentle
column41: nurturing face.  Traditionally 'tough' cards like The Tower
column42: Death
column43: the Nine and Ten of Swords
column44: the Fives (in all suits) have their edges smoothed down.  While some might find this makes the deck easier to 'handle' ( can't help but feel that it diminishes the accuracy
column45: and reduces the impact of the cards that *are* reflections of gentleness and healing--the Four of Swords
column46: the Two of Cups
column47: the Queens
column48: etc.  This is really the only 'Goddess-focused' deck I've worked with
column49: and so I cannot compare with similar decks.  This was a very good attempt at creating a deck that emphasized the Goddess--I simply believe it's a shame that the decision was made to narrow that focus further
column50: and thus limiting the range of the deck

column1: I purchased this Vantec product and used it for a short time.  Most USB enclosures offer "heat dissipation thru the metal case"
column2: as does this one. However
column3: I grew very concerned about how hot the Vantec became
column4: especially after active operation.   Heat is a major enemy of electrical motors. The HDD obviously just cooks inside the Vantec. There is also a definitive  difference between its temperature in stand-by mode
column5: and during/immediately after active use.   I found another USB enclosure offering active ventilation: the Apricorn EZ Bus DT
column6: which not only has a built-in fan
column7: but IMHO
column8: for several critical reasons
column9: is a better design and a smarter choice.  Here is why:   The Apricorn's 3-inch diameter fan is mounted transversely
column10: so it pulls heat directly off the entire underside of the HDD and expels thru vents on either end of the case.   In comparison
column11: the Vantec's internal chassis has a solid metal plate which covers the entire HDD circuit board (see the image I loaded above).  The Vantec has no venting
column12: so the heat inside builds up fast. I installed a 500GB HDD in the Apricorn and ran a 220+GB backup from the Vantec. Upon completion hours later
column13: the Apricorn's exterior was completely cool to the touch; the Vantec's exterior was REALLY HOT.  A couple of other things I found superior about the Apricorn:   It's heavier with a wider base
column14: compared to the Vantec's (3" vs. 1.5"). When mounted vertically
column15: you can nudge the Vantec (or the desk it's sitting on) and it will fall over; it happened twice in the few days I used it. There would be major motion required to tip the Apricorn
column16: and I've never toppled it in months of use.   The Apricorn's easy-action pushbutton power switch is conveniently (and sensibly) located on the front of the unit. The Vantec's is on the bottom of the rear panel (see photo above)
column17: but it's a stiff toggle-type switch and awkward to operate. You have to hold the Vantec down with one hand firmly in order to get enough leverage to operate the balky switch... and you leave a nice handprint on the case
column18: which then has to be cleaned. Do that a few times and the sexy "mirror finish" isn't going to look new for very long.   Also
column19: the Vantec's internal PC board HDD cable is mounted off-center on from the socket on any HDD. You have to kink the Vantec's flat cable in order to complete the connection (see photo above). The Apricorn's is located exactly in line with the HDD's connector
column20: and requires no stressing of the cable.   The Apricorn is available here on Amazon
column21: but I found it for less at Page Computers. It is slightly higher in cost than the Vantec
column22: but I'm convinced it is a much better product. Also
column23: with Apricorn's active ventilation and greater physical stability
column24: I have peace of mind about the longevity & safety of the expensive drive mounted inside it

column1: Do dogs understand language?  Do they have their own syntax and grammar?  Stanley Coren thinks so.  Or maybe
column2: as with many of his other books
column3: he's only pretending to believe what he says in order to pique people's interest and sell more copies...  The words we use in dog training are actually irrelevant.  Since I train dogs in Manhattan
column4: I often find myself on an elevator with one or more dogs.  When the door closes I'll say
column5: "What do we do on an elevator?" and they'll all sit.  This often charms and surprises the other elevator occupants who may say something like
column6: "Look!  They understand every word you say!"    Not really.  I trained the dogs to do this by first saying "What do we do on an elevator?-we sit."  Once that pattern was established
column7: the dogs were able to make the leap from "What do we do on an elevator?" to "Sit" quite easily.  In fact
column8: I could have as easily trained them to do this by using nonsense words
column9: gobbledygook
column10: ridiculous sounds that have no meaning at all.  So it isn't my words or syntax the dogs are responding to
column11: it's my intent
column12: my body language
column13: my tone of voice (all carrying emotional information)
column14: and a previously established pattern of behavior.    Stanley Coren should know this better than anyone since one of his dogs is deaf
column15: yet still obeys him.  Why?  Because of his body language and a previously established pattern of behavior
column16: not because the dog "understands" his words.  Coren would say that the dog understands his hand signals the same way the hearing-impaired understand sign language.  But looked at objectively it's far more likely that the dog's response to hand signals is still just part of a previously established pattern of behavior
column17: not a linguistic or cognitive process.   Coren would still disagree.  He claims that certain vocalizations made by dogs can be grouped together
column18: which he takes to mean that there's a kind of syntax or grammar at work.  I'm sorry
column19: Stan
column20: but real language doesn't operate on such a simplistic level.  And while it may seem brave and controversial of Coren (who has a degree in psychology
column21: not linguisics or animal behavior) to disagree with Noam Chomsky about the nature of language
column22: at this stage in the development of linguistic science that's a bit like a high school sophmore disagreeing with Sir Isaac Newton about gravity.    Look
column23: it's fairly obvious to anyone who really understands dogs that the reason certain yips
column24: barks
column25: growls
column26: etc. are sometimes used together and others aren't (which isn't always true
column27: by the way -- it depends on the dog)
column28: is that each vocalization comes from an emotional
column29: not a cognitive state.  In other words
column30: certain emotions -- like fear and aggression -- may be felt by the animal simultaneously
column31: while others -- calmness and fear -- can't be.  It's not grammar or syntax
column32: it's emotion
column33: pure and simple.    Even if Coren hadn't thought this through from an emotional point of view
column34: if he'd spent any time at all studying comparative neuroanatomy he'd know that a dog's brain has no Broca's area
column35: which makes linguistic ability totally impossible.  But as with other books he's written (his LEFT-HANDER SYNDROME was notorious for being based on false data)
column36: Coren doesn't seem to care much about the truth.    Still
column37: I have to admit that it's hard not to buy into this myth because as human beings we're constantly explaining our feelings and experiences to ourselves through our thoughts and inner monologues
column38: or to others through conversations
column39: letters
column40: etc.  As a result we're almost forced
column41: by the way our brains work
column42: to supply a similar linguistic medium for a dog's feelings and behaviors when no such medium or ability exists.    I trained my dog to respond in a certain way whenever I ask him a certain question.  And I have to admit
column43: I like the way it feels when I say to him
column44: "Do you love me?" and he wags his tail
column45: comes over
column46: puts his paws on my chest
column47: and licks my nose.  Does he understand the meaning of that sentence when I say it to him?  Of course not.  But I know he understands the emotion.  It's a shame that Coren doesn't get this fundamental difference between real linguistic understanding and pure emotion
column48: particularly when the misinformation he disseminates in this book can be detrimental to the relationship between you and your dog
column49: a relationship that SHOULD be based on real and
column50: quite often
column51: wonderful emotions
column52: not on any imaginary ability to use and understand language.    If I could I'd give this book no stars at all

column1: Admission to America's elite colleges is an increasingly trying affair. An academically strong
column2: middle class high school senior with no particular claim on a space
column3: "un-hooked" as it is known
column4: is faced with increasingly long odds of acceptance. The "un-hooked" applicant is squeezed by a dynamic made from increasing applications as more high school seniors go on to college and the colleges' own efforts to expand the applicant pool through increasing financial aid as well as recruiting international students even as they hold the number of places in freshman classes unchanged.  In this environment it is hardly a challenge to find a really sharp kid who was not accepted and also to find some "hooked" applicant who seemed rather less than qualified who was accepted. Venting on this situation provides a good release.   Golden vents well
column5: but is unfortunately short on substance. Lacking quantitative data
column6: the scope and scale of the matter escape Golden.   More importantly
column7: Golden does not attempt to address what seems to be the most pressing question: What do we expect of these elite institutions? Do we require that they be social engineers? If yes
column8: to what degree? Failing  an attempt to answer this question "The Price of Admission" is reduced to a voice only of frustration and angst.  For a more thought provoking read
column9: see Harry Lewis's "Excellence Without a Soul". Lewis is not specifically concerened with admissions
column10: as GOlden is
column11: but Lewis is very much interested in the question of what an education at one of these elite institutions should be.

column1: British actor Anthony Hopkins was playing a African-American man who pretends he's Jewish. Hopkins did the role well and he managed to make me forget that he's playing a Black man from New Jersey. I can understand learning to speak properly but you don't pick up a slightly British accent. That would be pretentious. I just think there are actors that could have been more believable as Coleman Silk. Coleman is accused of racism after using the word "spook" when he mean "specter" or "ghost" because two students never appeared in his class. He never met them so he didn't know they were Black.  Nicole Kidman was playing a woman who came from a rich family who ran away from home at 14 after being sexually molested by her stepfather. She got on my nerves because she came across as she was on smack in every single scene. Coleman Silk falls in love with her despite the fact she seems psycho. I found it impossible to feel sorry Nicole's character. I thought she was capable of doing what her Vietnam Vet husband accused her of.   The best part of the movie were the flashbacks that Coleman (Anthony Hopkins) had of his youth. A younger Coleman was played by Wentworth Miller who was much more believable.  I don't want to say too much about the movie. I bet the book by Philip Roth is better and if anyone is interested maybe should read that instead.

column1: The first book of Auster's New York trilogy was originally published in 1985
column2: and in 1994 was adapted into this graphic novel. I've never read the original (or any of the other parts of the trilogy)
column3: so I can't comment on Karasik and Mazzicchelli's adaptation. However
column4: I can say that since I'm not particularly fond of existentialist or postmodernist literature (those two terms being the most common critical shorthand for Auster's story)
column5: this really didn't do anything for me at all. The story is basically an exercise in metafiction
column6: and if you like that stuff
column7: great -- I do not. It is dressed up (at least initially) in the mystery genre
column8: but that's just window dressing. (There's a long legacy
column9: especially in France
column10: of cloaking novels and films of ideas in genre trappings (for example Alain Robbe-Grillet's two books The Erasers and The Voyeur
column11: or the films of Jean-Pierre Melville.)  The story begins fairly straightforwardly: a reclusive writer of potboiler mysteries named Daniel Quinn lives in New York on his own since the death of his wife and son. A complete stranger calls him and thinks Quinn is a private detective named Paul Auster and begs him to to take his case. (The writer Paul Auster
column12: and his family
column13: shows up for one scene -- it's that kind of book.) Quinn meets with the strange man
column14: who was raised in rather harrowing circumstances by his professor father
column15: who was seeking to discover the true language of God. The father has been released from jail and Quinn is supposed to keep an eye on him and report. Everything starts to derail when he loses track of both the old man he's been following
column16: and his clients. He spends several months watching the building and going crazy. Once he realizes they've disappeared
column17: he finds his own life has disappeared as well. Obviously this is all somewhat about identity
column18: but it's more about fun stuff like language
column19: representation
column20: and other tiresome postmodern subjects (as are the other two parts of the trilogy
column21: which involve a man spying on someone
column22: and yet another disappearance).   It has to be said that the artwork does an admirable job of treating the bizarro world Auster has thrust his characters into. The simple
column23: heavy black and white inking is a perfect match to the material
column24: especially when the representations become less literal and more symbolic. However
column25: if your taste runs more toward things like plots and characters
column26: this is probably not for you. Fans of Auster may enjoy this

column1: I thought this book would be great and was really looking forward to making some of the recipes
column2: but I have to admit I'm disappointed with the recipes and with what I've baked from it so far.  I was surprised that so many of the recipes called for vegetable shortening instead of or in addition to butter.  I know the book itself explains that shortening is used to achieve a certain texture
column3: but I have read in other baking books that shortening is a crutch and doesn't deliver the flavor punch of pure butter.  So I was a little skeptical
column4: and then reading through the recipes
column5: although they are very clearly written
column6: there aren't a lot of extra tips on technique or anything for individual recipes.  The book already assumes a level of competence.  I made three recipes from the book: the essential chewy sugar cookie
column7: the essential chewy chocolate chip cookie
column8: and the Fudgy Brownies.  All three recipes tasted delicious
column9: so I can't complain there
column10: but the brownies came out a little tough for my tastes
column11: and both the cookies spread too much -- way too much
column12: and I even refrigerated the dough for the sugar cookies. I consider myself to be an intermediate baker and have made these cookies from other recipes in the past with better results
column13: so right now I'm wondering if I should even try any more of the recipes in this book or just give up.  I think it's okay for a "base" cookie recipe book
column14: but you would need to look elsewhere for better techniques or to tweak the ingredients

column1: Seth's UK publisher apparently paid £1.4m for this book WITHOUT EVEN READING A WORD!  Any publisher prepared to cough up that amount of cash so recklessly deserves an entire omelette on their face and that is pretty much what they got.  Seth is a fine writer and this is a well-crafted book.  It tells the story of his uncle (a one-armed dentist) and his aunt (a German refugee) with whom he spent some time when he first came to England.  Their tale is interesting without being remarkable and this is where the problem really lies.  Two Lives would make a wonderful 100 page short memoir.  I say this with confidence as 100 of these 500+ pages are very good indeed.  The correspondence between the couple and the stories that the letters unearth are moving and compelling reading.  The rest of the book is a bit dull really.  Something his publisher would have noticed had they bothered to read it (if indeed those stories are true).  Ho hum
column2: publishers have their own reasons for throwing good money away.  Shame that they could have supported a whole host of exciting new authors with just a small portion of the cash they wasted on this.  If you are interested in this book (and you will wonder why you were when you read it) for goodness sake wait for the paperback.  This edition is too heavy in every sense of the word

 It is true that the basics of good interviewing haven't change much over the years, but they have changed some.  And this book, while it was surely  a must-read in the 70s, is so outdated that I found myself skipping the  first chapter, then the second, then the third ... then much of the rest of  the book.  For example:  there is a full chapter, and several pages  scattered through the book, that talk about research techniques.  This is  pre-internet, pre-much-of-what's-out-there-today, and as a result, those 75  or so pages are useless.  The same is true for the roughly 25 or 30 pages  that talk about how to get an interview, and how to make a good first  appearance.  This is pre-email, and clearly pre-women's-lib.  Many of the  tips for women on how to get interviews and make sure they come out  successful are down right offensive to women today.  Fortunately, most  female interviewers no longer have to rely solely on looking nice, batting  eyelashes, and agreeing with everything their interviewee has to say.     Yes, there are a few good pointers, but to buy and read an entire book for  mearly a few pointers isn't necessary.  There was nothing here that I  hadn't seen elsewhere.  For a good, up-to-date book on interviewing, try  Creative Interviewing
column3:
by Ken Metzler, it's over priced, but  filled with great and useful information 
 This was not good news to me and does not represent who I am as a PCA Presbyterian woman, happily married and the mother of two sons. I resent how the author demeans women in her writing as if they are less intellegent than she is for choosing to submit to their husbands and staying home with their kids. There can only be one leader of a corporation, and one leader of a home; in a dance, one leads and one follows--two cannot lead in a dance, or there is no dance. The author has never studied Greek or Hebrew as far as the credentials state, and she is in no place to profess to be qualified in the exegesis of Scripture to prove her feminist agenda. I would not recommend this book to anyone. It is a waste of time

Meanwhile I am a trainer myself and I support a more constructive approach to dog training based on positive reinforcement.  If you know nothing about dogs' psychology
column6: and want to learn more from "The Voice" in dog behavior I suggest "The Other End of the Leash" by Patricia McConnell or "Culture Clash"  by Jean Donaldson or "The Power of Positive Dog Training" by Pat Miller. If you would like to become a benevolent leader of the pack without imposing yourself to your dog with violence or fear
column7: I suggest "How to be the Leader of the Pack...And have Your Dog Love You for It" ("How to" booklets from Dog's Best Friend) by Patricia B. McConnell. All these books are written by professionals that have been working with dogs and studying dogs' behaviors
column8: but they are very entertaining and easy to read and comprehend. Patricia McConnell also wrote a number of other books addressing specific behavioral issues.

column1: I am sorry to say that I thoroughly disliked "Of Human Bondage."  I know it is on every must read list for fiction (which is why I decided to read it) however
column2: I just wonder how such a boring story can continually be relegated to such a hallowed position in literature?  Not only did I find it dull but I was becoming increasingly uncomfortable with the main character's perception of women!  I'm not a feminist in the least but most of the female characters were described in such pathetic ways.  "Yellow teethed"  "Sallow skin"  "Dirty Hands"  "Tear stained over powdered face"
column3: it goes on and on.  I wondered if the author was uncomfortable women?  I looked online for some information about Maugham.  To my surprise I found out that Maugham was bisexual.  He did marry and have a child but for most of his life it sounded like he was involved with men. In no way can I say this substantiates or confirms the tone of the book -- but in some way it answered my question or concern.    Instead of this book I'd recommend the following classics:  Beautiful and Damned by F. Scott Fitzgerald
column4: Madame Bovary by Flaubert.  At least in these books
column5: maybe the female characters are not the most virtuous but the characters are written with such sensuality that even though they might not be described as gorgeous they are brought to life in the pages by the author with a kaleidoscope of words that makes them multidimensional -- good or bad.

column1: Bart Ehrman's attack on Dan Brown's DaVinci Code raises as many questions as it answers
column2: prompting a diligent student to write an attack on Ehrman's attack on Brown. Needless to say this might engender an infinite series of attacks on attacks
column3: so caution is the best approach. Nonetheless
column4: let's look at some of the errors that Ehrman commits while trying to give us the "truth and fiction" in the DaVinci Code. I'm focused on a single chapter (Jesus
column5: Mary Magdalene
column6: and Marriage) to keep this review to a minimum.  Ehrman asserts that "most of Jesus' followers
column7: and certainly his closest followers
column8: were men (p. 145)."  We'd all agree with that
column9: but before we take it for granted
column10: you must consider that the gospels were written by men with an obvious bias against women
column11: typical of the times. So it should be said in fairness that our impression that Jesus' most active followers were men comes from the stories told by men. In the rare case of a gospel by a women (the Gospel of Mary)
column12: for example
column13: his closest adviser is a woman
column14: not a man. Hence Ehrman's "history" may not reflect the "truth" but merely the opinion of the men.  Ehrman urges us to "recall the saying of Jesus preserved for us from Q...(p. 146)." Someone call the Press! Apparently Ehrman has discovered the Q document. That warrants a major press conference. I was under the impression that Q was a hypothetical document
column15: but now Ehrman apparently is able to find sayings that have been preserved in it. This type of thinking is sloppy and doesn't belong in a serious book.  Ehrman uses a passage from Matthew (19:28) that says the disciples will be seated on 12 thrones to judge the 12 tribes and he concludes that "The future rulers of God's people would all be men (p. 146)." That would assume that all the disciples were men
column16: which is by no means the clear case. It's rare for any of the gospels to give the names of all 12 disciples
column17: and some gospels give the names of as few as 7. So who knows who the other 12 were. And certainly there are gospels which talk about Mary being a disciple
column18: and she's not a man. So Ehrman's conclusion is faulty.  Ehrman claims "Of course there were not many Epicureans or Cynics in Jesus' immediate environment of Palestine... (p. 150)." Needless to say there is no citation for this assertion. That's because you probably couldn't find one. Cynics were known for their wandering
column19: and it's hard to believe that there were not cynics visiting Sepphoris or Caesarea which were major cities
column20: and Sepphoris was well within Jesus' "immediate environment." By the way
column21: the word Palestine was adopted nearly 100 years after Jesus' death
column22: so it's more than curious to find Ehrman talking about Jesus and Palestine.  Ehrman spends a lot of time questioning whether or not Jesus was married and he continually asks the question - "Why would his wife never be mentioned? (p. 153)" Apparently Ehrman has forgotten that the gospels were written by Christians who belonged to sects that were in competition with the sect that was represented by Jesus' family. It's for this reason that the writers slanted the gospels to paint the family in a negative light
column23: as Jeffrey Butz has so brilliantly pointed out in his book The Brother of Jesus. If these same authors went to so much trouble to denigrate the brothers and sisters of Jesus
column24: to what lengths would they have gone to remove any traces of his wife and children (Some scholars believe that the wedding at Cana is such a trace)? For if he had been married and had children
column25: Christianity would have developed in a dramatically different way. While I am not arguing here that this is the case
column26: any adequate discussion of the  situation surely must raise this possibility. Ehrman
column27: however
column28: for whatever reason
column29: neglects to mention it.  Ehrman claims that "Magdalene indicates her place of origin - the town of Magdala... (p. 154)." Yes
column30: that's one theory. But only one. And not a particularly good theory since it wasn't called Magdala anyway
column31: but Magadan (Matthew 15:39)
column32: and it's hard to see how you go from Magadan to Magdalena. A better theory has been put forward by Margaret Starbird who believes that Migdal (the ancient name for the city
column33: which means tower
column34: becauser there was a fish tower there) refers to the fact that Mary "towered over" the other disciples. In other words
column35: a nickname for "Mary the Great". Whether you subscribe to Starbird's theory or not
column36: it deserves to be mentioned. But
column37: in fact
column38: it is in keeping with Jesus' tendency to give his disciples funky names (Rocky
column39: the Brothers of Thunder
column40: the Daggerman) rather than place names.  Ehrman claims "We do know of Jewish men from the time and place of Jesus who were single... (p. 155)" yet he fails to list a single one. Why? Because they are so few. It was inconceivable for a Jewish rabbi aged 30 in the 1st Century to be unmarried. William Phipp's excellent book Was Jesus Married provides good scholarship on this topic. Ehrman claims to have read it
column41: but apparently he skipped that chapter.  Ehrman makes a school boy's error when he claims that the Essenes were celibate (p. 156). While it is true of one sect within the Essenes
column42: there was another sect
column43: noted by Josephus
column44: who were married and allowed to reproduce.  These problems are not minor points. Yet even if they were
column45: their sheer number is disturbing in a work that professes to separate "truth" from "fiction" in the works of another author. When Ehrman is working from such a self-exalted platform

column1: I'm not a big fan of existentialism to start out with

column1: I know he's a famous "name-it-and-claim-it" preacher
column2: so I wanted to see his thoughts exactly
column3: rather than sit through some rambling sermons of his and get pieces here and there.  That's the great thing about books- preachers have to be concise and to the point.    I discovered he is teaching something I never heard before.  First
column4: let me say that he acknowledges some truthful teachings.  He acknowledges that we are not to be greedy.  He acknowledges that Jesus said to store our treasure in heaven
column5: not earth.  He acknowledges that there is nothing evil about money
column6: but the "love of money" is what is evil (although
column7: I think prosperity teachers like himself are deceived; they are in love with money
column8: which is evident by seeing their lifestyles).  And
column9: by the way
column10: there is much in his book that is very good.  I only want to point out some of the dangerous errors.  And here it is:    He says that we are not to store treasure on earth
column11: but in heaven.  That is true.  The Scripture says it.  But look at what he says that means.  He says that the storehouse for our treasure is in heaven
column12: not the earth (not in banks).  When you need money
column13: you can get it when you want
column14: from God
column15: from our heavenly storehouse.  There's no need to store it here (on earth)
column16: where robbers and thieves can get to it.      According to Copeland
column17: how do you make deposits and withdrawals from this treasure bank in heaven?     From pages 63-75
column18: he says how to make deposits.  These include (his words for the subheadings in this section):  -- Tithing (I this this is
column19: by far
column20: the most important) -- Giving to the Poor -- Investing in the Gospel -- Giving as a Praise to God    From pages 75-86 he explains how to make a withdrawal.  In the summary for making a withdrawal
column21: he lists 6 points
column22: culminating in a prayer that summarizes these points.  Here's his prayer from page 85-86:  "Father
column23: in the Name of Jesus
column24: we ask you for $____.  We have this money in our heavenly account and we are withdrawing this amount now.  We believe we receive $____.  As in Mark 11:23-24
column25: we believe it in our hearts and confess now that it is ours in the Name of Jesus.  We agree that we have $____ according to Matthew 18:19.  From this day forward
column26: we roll the care of this over on You and thank You for it.  Satan
column27: in the name of Jesus
column28: we take authority over you; we bind your operation now and render you helpless.  Ministering spirits
column29: we charge you to go forth and cause this amount to come to us according to Hebrews 1;14.  Father
column30: we praise Your Name for meeting our needs according to Your riches in glory by Christ Jesus and for multiplying our seed for sowing in the Name of Jesus."     I have just two questions for Pastor Kenneth Copeland:  1. Do you really live by these principles? Do you have a significant savings account and/or retirement bank account? According to your book
column31: you shouldn't
column32: if you really believed what you wrote.  2. Why didn't the first disciples and Apostles living in Jerusalem know this "secret" about heavenly "deposits" and "withdrawals?"  They were so poor and in hardship that the Apostle Paul went around making a special collection for them from the other Roman churches
column33: as mentioned in 2 Cor. 8 and other passages.  In fact
column34: why didn't any other theologians ever teach this heavenly deposit and withdrawal system?  Shouldn't that be a hint to you that you are going off into the deep end???!!!

Cold Mountain is an unfortunate novel.  It is unfortunate it won the National Book award (why did it win?).  The novel has an unfortunate structure; Fraser simply strings along one incident after another
column2: with little connecting thread.  The weight of flashbacks alone drags the novel to the ground (and it hardly gets off the ground in the first place!)  There are glaring anachronisms.  It is difficult to believe that some of the sentiments he puts in his characters mouths could have been uttered in 1864.  This is a forgivable sin
column3: if the novel is well written
column4: if it rises about the banal
column5: if it offers something more than surface.  But this novel is all surfaces and all banality.  Its publication is indicative of some of the pathology of today's publishing world (this will be a BIG novel
column6: this will become a BIGGER film
column7: which will sell more of this BIG novel).  Too bad for us the novel does not justify the claims of its promoters.  Fraser's eight million dollar advance for his next work is probably a clarion signal of another BIG novel to come

column1: This book is certainly heavy on the eye-candy - it has lots of great pictures (though perhaps dated... very late-80's hair styles) and nice listings describing the colleges and whatnot. column2: this is a lovely place to look.  Unfortunately
column3: glaring factual errors and odd 'stereotypes' really detracted from the quality of this guide. Included is a brief summary of the Oxford colleges. Unfortunately
column4: many are left out (seemingly at random - the maps also leave out several important sites while including other entirely mundane ones) and the descriptions of others are factually quite incorrect (and sometimes contradictory - All Souls is described as being the only graduate college [it is not a graduate college]
column5: then Nuffield is also described as being a graduate college [it is]). There are also odd little tidbits of information that seem to represent a story of the colleges frozen sometime in the past (and not a nifty 1920's past - presumably the late 1980's or early '90's when the first edition was published) - 'excellent darts team?' ok
column6: so they may have once
column7: but that's rather useless information today. My own college's description
column8: though quite pleasant
column9: is not a very good representation of the place today. Some of the college descriptions are also really just mean
column10: representing some undefined antipathy on the part of the author (did someone from that college steal his girlfriend or something?).  Overall
column11: it's a very pretty publication that certainly had a very good team of photographers and graphic designers
column12: but as it's not so strong on the facts and could do with some updates - Oxford isn't as unchanging as it may seem

column3: in fact
column4: on Lake Champlain. Mr. Lengel also incorrectly writes that Henry Knox
column5: after retrieving the cannons from Ft. Ticonderoga takes them down the Hudson. This too is incorrect. Knox and his men took the cannons across land to Lake George (which was frozen in winter)
column6: down to Lake George village and south to Albany before turning east to Boston. I'm totally shocked that no review of this book mentions these inaccurate statements. Anyway
column7: after about 100 pages I took the book back to the library. I couldn't depend on the rest of his facts-so what's the point of reading it?

column1: A Critical Response to Strangers in the Land: Blacks
column2: Jews
column3: Post-Holocaust America       Since I began intensively studying the Israel-Palestine conflict nine years ago
column4: I have (as a Jew) also been concerned with its historical and current effect on relations among blacks and Jews in this country. These relations have reflected the influence that neoconservatism
column5: originating primarily among Jewish intellectuals
column6: has had on mainstream (liberal) Jewish institutional life and political culture in America
column7: and the manner in which Jewish-identified aspects of neoconservatism (opposition to affirmative action
column8: support for Israel
column9: an obsession with alleged anti-Semitism and now "Islamo-fascism") have been adopted by a broader culture of white racism and class privilege
column10: with obvious dire effects both domestically and globally. What began as one aspect of the white ethnic intellectual backlash in the 1960s has evolved
column11: been appropriated
column12: and become central to the domestically ruthless and globally violent ideology of the current administration
column13: with a concurrent black-Jewish subplot that has been much discussed but not adequately understood.  	It is in this context that I was intrigued to discover a massive 527-page work of scholarship called Strangers in the Land: Blacks
column14: Jews
column15: Post-Holocaust America by UCLA English professor Eric Sundquist (Belknap-Harvard
column16: 2005). Upon obtaining this book
column17: however
column18: I was quickly disappointed to find-in spite of many insightful analyses of literary works-a clear unwillingness to seriously engage the central issues noted above. While I will leave it to others to judge whether Strangers in the Land succeeds as a work of cultural/literary criticism
column19: I would suggest that it is an utter and insidious failure of political criticism. Moreover
column20: I think that it is as a work of political criticism that it will be (and should be) primarily received. As such
column21: this book stands as an apology for neoconservatism and its support for white privilege in America
column22: as well as its support for the Zionist project in all its aggressive criminality
column23: now coming to a head as any possibility of viable Palestinian state is being destroyed. In this context
column24: Sundquist shows a marked lack of compassion for the dire plight of the Palestinian people
column25: and-given his obviously considerable scholarly skills-demonstrates a seemingly willful innocence of the implications of historical scholarship
column26: human rights reports
column27: and diplomatic records now freely available
column28: most recently summarized by Norman Finkelstein.  	In summary
column29: Sundquist views neoconservatism as rather benignly emanating in the 1960s from liberal Jewish intellectuals understandably caught amongst a dedication to the meritocracy
column30: Jewish group interests
column31: and the threatening demands of what he sees as anti-Zionist and incipiently anti-Semitic advocates of Black Power. Sundquist reduces Black Nationalist
column32: Black Power
column33: Pan-African
column34: and Third World Liberation movements
column35: and specifically the leadership of Malcolm X and Stokely Carmichael
column36: to demagogic
column37: venal
column38: anti-Semitic opportunism and bigotry. Sundquist adopts a boilerplate Zionist narrative of the history of Palestine and Israel that would not pass muster in any college classroom worth its name
column39: which romanticizes Israelis and denigrates Palestinians. While maintaining a scholarly tone and engaging in prodigious amounts of research
column40: Sundquist ultimately refuses to seriously engage the critical scholarship which he references
column41: from the work on Jewish whiteness of his UCLA colleague Karen Brodkin
column42: to Manning Marable's careful scholarship on African-American political movements
column43: to the new Israeli historians
column44: and to Edward Said and Rashid Khalidi.  	All this is done in the framework of a purportedly unbiased treatment of Black-Jewish relations.  But two examples will be quoted of Sundquist's peculiarly jaundiced notion of "balance" in his treatment of black-Jewish and Israeli-Palestinian issues:  "(Meir) Kahane's views were all the more remarkable for being borrowed from the same black nationalism the JDL (Jewish Defense League) meant to oppose. The paperback jacket of Kahane's "Never Again!
column45: an exposition of JDL militancy, rightly compared the book to Cleaver's Soul on Ice" and "The Autobiography of Malcolm X." The JDL's symbol
column46: a clenched fist issuing from a Star of David
column47: mirrored the clenched fist of Black Power. Consciously styling themselves "Jewish Panthers
column48: members undertook armed community patrols...Underscoring the parallel, Kahane declared that the JDL did not differ from the Panthers in wanting to instill self-assurance and pride in young people...  In the face of Black Power's demand that Jews acquiesce to policies inimical to their own interests

column1: The first books by John Ringo were gripping tales of interstellar war and invasion
column2: liberally laced with what he himself calls carnography. By the time his third book was published though
column3: he seems to have learned the all too common skill of filling pages without providing any content.  "The Hero" tries to tell the story of a military special operations team a thousand years in the future. All the characters are totally forgettable
column4: and indeed the authors proceeds to kill most of them off quickly enough. The story consists of the teams travails slogging around a hostile countryside playing Blind Man's Bluff
column5: while some of the members try to kill each other. The situations are arbitrary and meaningless. The authors introduce strange fauna
column6: and then mostly ignore them except when convenient. The equipment carried by the soldiers is shockingly primitive for a culture with a millennium of uninterrupted technical civilization.  The only minor points of interest are that Ringo finally includes the English pronunciation of his Bane Sidhe (for those who hadn't figured it out)

column8: and there is confirmation that the Posleen were bioengineered

column4: try

column6: having recently composed a wonderful memoir of life before, during and (mostly) after her husband suffered a traumatic brain injury, entitled A Three Dog Life. Unfortunately, this earlier work, a 179-page collection of about 100 stories, ranging in length from one sentence to a few pages, was disappointing. In Safekeeping, snippets of her life from an eighteen-year-old pregnant wife, to grandmotherhood, her writing feels stiff and forced and even though I disliked it from the start, I trudged on hopefully. Unfortunately, my disappointment never disappeared and only wavered during two of the stories, I Ate There Once, about a conversation which takes place as she rides in a car with her second and third husbands and, What the Moment Can Hold, which tells of her feelings and actions during an encounter with her newborn granddaughter. Both felt authentic and true. As far as the rest of the stories, they seemed like what you'd get from an above-average college student if you assigned them to create a journal of life, specifying, Write down any random thought you have." Additionally

column1: Pasquale Scaturro and Gordon Brown make the first "source to sea" expedition down the Nile. It is a splendid adventure that would make a great story. Unfortunately
column2: the author spends nearly a third of the pages interjecting musings from himself (he wasn't there) and boring the reader with sideline stories that that have little if any connection with the current expedition. Just as the reader gets swept up in the adventure
column3: the author interupts the scene with some left field factoid and destroys any sense of cadence. It's almost as bad as being in the grip of a televised Olympic event and having it interrupted by an inane story about the father of one of the athletes.  The author
column4: Richard Bangs
column5: wasn't on the trip but writes an almost first person narrative based on interviews with Scaturro and assorted other people. Inexplicably
column6: he doesn't interview Gordon Brown who comprised a full 50% of the expedition. Instead he castigates Brown at every turn for being moody
column7: violent
column8: "silent for days"
column9: self-absorbed
column10: etc.
column11: etc. At no point does the author offer any explanation why Brown might be behaving the way he does. The reader is left wondering why and a simple over-the-phone interview of Brown would have answered these questions.   In the final chapters Bangs decides (again
column12: without talking to Brown) that Brown's anti-social behavior is linked to a brain cancer that has long-since been cured. Not only is it a convenient way for Bangs to avoid doing his homework and writing a definitive documentary; it's a blatantly cheap shot at Brown and any other person who has been challenged with a handicap - temporary or not.   This is a wonderful adventure that deserves an honest
column13: accurate
column14: and well rounded accounting by a first rate author who isn't afraid to dig for details and doesn't have some personal axe to grind

column1: I wonder how long it will be before Frost's literary stock is devalued as much as it deserves to be. These are trite and banal poems that do not ring true or sincere. Frost seems distant from both his poems and the reader. What he has to say is obvious and unoriginal. How he says it is on the level of a hallmark greeting card at its best; at its worst
column2: it is no better than a limerick. Posthumous revelations about his horrific cruelty to others and his shrewd creation/manipulation of his celebrity image as the New England farmer-poet only confirm that there was something seriously wrong with this man and his poems that an earlier generation missed. How earlier generations could find genius in such obvious observations is astounding. Bad poetry from a twisted man

column1: THIS REVIEW IS ABOUT THIS PUBLISHERS EDITION NOT ABOUT THE BOOKS CONTENT ITSELF.  If you want to know about the content--- be aware that this book is copyright free and in the public domain and you can actually read the entire text free
column2: online
column3: if you are curious about the content of the book and what it is about. I am a person who prefers a real
column4: bound book in the hand to reading on the computer screen or printing off a book onto computer paper.  I learned about this book as it is popular with homeschoolers using the Charlotte Mason method.  This book weaves science content into a story format (narrative format).  About this edition of the book--buyer beware!  I am very annoyed. I saw that Amazon sells three different publishers' versions of reprints of this very old book
column5: before I purchased the book from Amazon.  Of course I am mad at myself for making a mistake
column6: but I am also not happy with the way Amazon markets this Kessinger Publishing's version of this book.  I have had issues in the past with facsimile reprints of antique books sometimes being very hard to read. I took time to research this. I wanted whichever publisher's version has a readable font that is clearly printed.  The way Amazon presently has this item (book reprinted by Kessinger Publishing) set up on their webpage
column7: I thought I was looking inside this book. Imagine my surprise when the book arrived and the printing itself is horrible! I can't stand to read this! Upon double checking this now
column8: I see I made a simple mistake--if you don't want to make the same mistake that I made please read on...  It appears that this Kessinger Publishing version is a facsimile reproduction of the original. The old font type is hard to read. But the more problematic thing is that the ink is blobby and uneven. Specifically
column9: I mean that some parts of the letters are missing (there is white space) while others are blobbed so that the letters don't look as they should
column10: they are black blobs in some parts. I would prefer a book whose text is clearly visible. A modern font is also usually easier on the eyes.  I am very annoyed as this is not even the cheapest price edition of this book which is currently in print! Come to find out there are cheaper versions with nicer and easier to read font!  I am upset with Amazon additionally as the way they have this set up to "look inside this book" brings you to the edition published by the publisher "Yesterday's Classics" which has what looks to be a great font
column11: a nice
column12: clear
column13: modern font and a good printing job. (Also today I received a different book purchased from Amazon by the publisher "Yesterday's Classics" and it is a wonderful printing job and a a nice binding to boot.  I will be returning this book to Amazon. Too bad I have to pay the shipping to return it to them!
