column1: For good or for ill I recently was asked to help pick out graphic novels for children of my library system.  I suspect I was asked this partly because I am under the age of 30 and partly because my brother-in-law is a comic book inker.  The upside is that I get to see lots and lots of new titles for kids.  The down side is that more often than not they're truly terrible.  I mean just awful stuff.  Now recently Scholastic has been trying to corner the market on quality graphic novels for children. Somehow they missed the "Babymouse" boat
column2: but they've already given us "Bone" and "The Baby-Sitters Club" series.  It's not all good all the time though.  Recently a co-worker threw a series title
column3: "The Black Belt Club" onto my desk and asked me to read it through.  I had no idea when I read this book just how heavily Scholastic was riding on it.  Already the first book in the series (this is the second) has been optioned for a film.  Go to the book's website and you'll learn about their hopes for an animated series
column4: video games
column5: the whole nine yards.  There's just one catch.  Unless the books become mighty popular
column6: there won't be much point to all the hyping.  And reading it through I have no idea if kids are gonna go in for its "prose and comic hybrid" style or not.   	 Max has never felt completely at ease as a member of the exclusive Black Belt Club.  The club consists of four students who are sent by their sensei into the world to fight evil.  Pretty standard stuff.  After a disappointing demo team performance he returns to the dojo for a special assignment with his fellows.  There they are told by a mysterious magical Native American woman named Grandmother Dancing Feather that there's been an imbalance between the four elements in the world.  It's up to the kids to defeat The Hate Master (honestly
column7: that's his name) and get the elements back in alignment.  Along the way
column8: Max has to face up to his fears as well as his own sorrows.  But it's only through friendship that the four can join together and defeat their enemy once and for all.  The book is a combination of written prose and graphic novel elements.  In a way
column9: Scholastic is banking on this series to be a kind of link between straight out comic books and straight out literature.  Like "Captain Underpants"
column10: this is supposed to bridge the gap.  The funny thing is
column11: Scholastic keeps referring to this series as the "first ever prose and comic hybrid".  It says this on the book's webpage.  Now this is where it gets funny.  "Captain Underpants" came up with this style way way before Barnes ever did.  And "Captain Underpants" is produced by Blue Sky Press which is an imprint of... Scholastic
column12: Inc!  So if Scholastic already has the real "hybrid" credited to their name
column13: what the heck are they doing foisting credit to "The Black Belt Club" books?  Just weird.  Anyway
column14: what was I saying?  Ah yes.  This new technique.  Well
column15: insofar as it goes
column16: it works.  The problem is not in the style but in the writing.  THAT
column17: unfortunately
column18: is where it begins to fall apart. 	 Since the first book
column19: Barnes has kicked up the emotional conflict.  Her hero Max still has self-esteem issues and he sometimes doubts whether or not the three other members of the club are really his friends (a legitimate concern).  There's also an odd backstory where Max is taken care of by his gruff karate-hating uncle because his father is so often away on business.  None of that is really resolved in this book
column20: however.  Apparently by the end Max has discovered that
column21: "There was nothing better in the whole wide world than having friends!".  Also that
column22: "love is stronger than hate".  No real innovation or new ideas here.  Barnes is perfectly content to rely on old overused phrases like these
column23: when even a simple rewording could have conveyed the same thoughts without seeming overly trite.  And that
column24: unfortunately
column25: is the problem with this series itself.  It's just too simplistic.  There's lots of fancy action sequences
column26: and the parts with Max on his own are fine
column27: but the moralistic tone is more than a little preachy and self-serving.   	 Then there are the weird elements.  In this particular book
column28: the kids are visited by a magical old Native American woman named Grandmother Dancing Feather.  What tribe is she with?  It apparently doesn't matter.  What does matter is that she represents a kind of condensed be-one-with-the-world combination of every pseudo-Native American teaching out there.  In the back of the book we're told that Dawn Barnes did some "personal studies" with a Seneca Shaman and a Ute Shaman.  She then takes the very very vague notion of "interconnectedness between themselves [i.e. children] and other living beings" and smooshes it into one big mess.  It's not that such ideas aren't legitimate.  It's that she's watered and dumbed them down in what she obviously thought was a kid-friendly fashion.  Then she takes the rather offensive route of having a magical person of another ethnicity guide the kids.  Even EVEN if Barnes had said that the villain was a coyote (which apparently he is) and then explained who coyote was to some Native American tribes THEN she might have tied together a legitimate myth with her video-gamelike storyline.  Instead she doesn't seem to want to spoil her tale with anything with that much depth.  Pah.   	 The plot of the book is taken directly from Barnes's belief in a teaching style she has dubbed
column29: "positive dialogue response".  A November 1
column30: 2005 issue of Entrepreneur said that this meant
column31: "motivating children with praise rather than fear".  Therefore fear is bad in her books.  Anger's bad too.  Part of the problem with the book is that Barnes equates anger with hate
column32: making both out to be bad.  I'm all for the "hate is bad" part
column33: but anger has a real use in this world.  It can be used to fight injustice
column34: for example.  Blas people
column35: for all their charms
column36: won't go fighting for what is right if they don't feel angry with the situation at hand.  Barnes doesn't quite acknowledge this and the book suffers. 	 Now Dawn Barnes (who bears a truly frightening resemblance to the Sensei featured in the books) has the credentials to pen this kind of "novel with action graphics".  She's called the "Martha Stewart of Karate" in her own press releases.  Already the Director of Children's Education for the National Association of Professional Martial Artists (does that make her a DOCENAPMA?) she's apparently a third-degree black belt.  A Beverly Hills former ballerina black-belt
column37: but a black belt all the same. A quick gander at her website at this moment in time shows that not much has happened with the book series since it sold its film rights back in July of 2005.  In spite of its novel appearance
column38: I wouldn't expect much more to happen either. 	 When it comes down to it
column39: you can have a good idea for a kind of book
column40: a good set of nonviolent attitudes
column41: factual information on a karate technique
column42: and still end up with a not-so-hotso book simply because the writing is sub-par.  For those kids into the idea of karate
column43: the book will be much loved and read.  For others
column44: however
column45: the overly hokey writing will turn them away and they'll be far more interested in better books like "Bone".  A fine title but nothing to get worked up about

column1: [This review refers to the CD-ROM "version"]  I ordered this CD because Amazon has it listed as an alternate version of PLATO: COMPLETE WORKS
column2: edited by John M. Cooper.  Well
column3: this is definitely false advertising.  This CD merely contains the Benjamin Jowett translations.  For those of you who don't know who Benjamin Jowett is
column4: he was a very prominent British scholar who is largely said to be responsible for rendering Plato's works into an English classic.  While his translations are certainly important historical documents
column5: they suffer from the fact that they were produced in the middle of the 19th century.  Yes
column6: that's right: the 19th century.  The translations in the Cooper edition
column7: on the other hand
column8: are all very accurate and up-to-date.  I highly recommend the print edition of PLATO: COMPLETE WORKS (Ed. Cooper)
column9: but this CD bears no resemblance to it.  If you have ever casually surfed the internet looking for the works of Plato
column10: you have probably had the "pleasure" of reading a Jowett translation.  All of his translations can be found for free on the internet.  In assembling this CD
column11: someone merely copied these translations into a word file
column12: converted it into a PDF
column13: and shoved it on a CD.  Trust me: you can do the work yourself and save yourself twenty bucks.

column1: `I'm Just Here For the Food Version 2.0' by Food Network culinary supernerd
column2: Alton Brown is a revision of his James Beard award winning first book. For those who always go to the back of the book to see whodunit
column3: this book is not worth buying if you already own the first edition.  What is surprising is that the thinness of the `improvements' to the book are apparent on the front cover
column4: where we see that this version `includes these special upgrades
column5: - 4 removable refrigerator magnets
column6: -15 brand new recipes'. This does not even merit calling this a significant new edition. It falls far short of the improvements found in Brown's hero
column7: Harold McGee's second edition of `On Food and Cooking'. It is an even bigger disappointment when you compare it to new releases of popular software. My best cases are to compare it to the excellent PC strategy games
column8: `Sid Meier's Civilization' and `Sim City'
column9: both of which are now at `Version 4.0'. And
column10: each new release involved a virtually complete redesign with major overhauls of mechanics and features. Merely adding new features to the existing system comes out as a new product
column11: not unlike Volume 2 of `Mastering the Art of French Cooking'.  The original ended its text on page 287 and Version 2.0 ends on page 321. This gives us 34 new pages or a 12% increase in material. What is surprising is that a large number of these pages are added to the Appendices.  In Version 1.0
column12: the appendices start on page 240. In Version 2.0
column13: the appendices start on page 256
column14: showing that the additions to the main text are nothing more than the 15 new recipes. We will come to these later. The best news about these additions is that a sizable chunk of these 18 pages comes in the Index. I am a big fan of good indices and tables of contents
column15: as I think that they can double or even triple the value of a cookbook. Most of the rest of the additions to the appendix are marginal. Much goes to the touted refrigerator magnets showing the major cuts of meat from cattle
column16: hogs
column17: lamb
column18: and chickens. The diagrams surrounding these doo-dads are a bit better than in Version 1.0
column19: but not nearly as good as you will find in
column20: for example
column21: the Larousse Gastronomique.  As I stated in my review of the original volume
column22: I am a seriously doting fan of Mr. Brown's work
column23: and his recent `Feasting on Asphalt' Food Network miniseries and his contribution as commentator on `Iron Chef America' continue to win my admiration. I firmly believe that AB's voice-over to the cooking are what makes the show as entertaining as it is. If that were gone
column24: the show would sink into mediocrity and disappear. On the other hand
column25: AB has been lured into turning his printed output into something of a brand
column26: very similar to Mark Bittman's `How to Cook Everything' rubric and Rachael Ray's '30 Minute Meal' mantra. Oddly
column27: of these three
column28: I thing Rachael has given her audience the greatest value per title.  I thought Alton's second volume was almost pure rip-off
column29: and this volume is very close to being the same kind of exploitation of his audience. AB redeemed himself with his fourth and fifth titles
column30: which I believe are superb services to amateur cooks and bakers.  My biggest single surprise in this Version 2.0 is the fact that there seemed to be no effort whatsoever to fix the `bugs' in the original text. The most obvious type of `bug' was misspellings. I may be able to forgive misspelling the famous plastic model making brand
column31: Revel
column32: but I have a harder time forgiving the use of an archaic and unfamiliar name
column33: `cimeter' for a type of knife much more commonly know as a `scimitar' (OK
column34: so `cimeter' IS in my Webster's Unabridged 3rd Edition
column35: but AB's use is really annoying
column36: when the more common spelling is so much more familiar).  Before I get into the additional recipes
column37: I must say that in spite of how much I like AB's explanations of food science and technique
column38: I virtually never use any of his recipes. If Alton and Mario Batali or Bobby Flay or Jacques Pepin or Nick Malgieri or James Peterson gave me conflicting information
column39: I would use the advice from the professional chef or professional teacher over AB's suggestion or recipe. That's because
column40: as Daniel Boulud has so clearly stated
column41: the thing which separates the amateur from the professional is the fact that the professional has made the same dish a thousand times over
column42: so that all the inefficiencies in his method have been worn off
column43: leaving the essence of good method. And
column44: in the case of professional teachers Malgieri and Peterson
column45: they have studied the professionals
column46: so their advice is as good or better than the practitioner.  Regarding the recipes
column47: I think it is poor form that Alton did not highlight the new ones in his table of contents; however
column48: if you happen to own both Version 1.0 and Version 2.0
column49: you can easily find the new recipes by laying out the tables of contents side by side and locate the additions. And
column50: I find that some of the new recipes are a waste of time. While I don't actually make AB's recipes
column51: I generally find them
column52: especially on his `Good Eats' show
column53: to be excellent illustrations of his points. In this book
column54: some of the new recipes do nothing to advance our understanding of his cooking principles. The `Roasted Tomato Soup' is a perfect example
column55: as the recipe involves no roasting! It uses roasted tomatoes from the previous recipe
column56: giving us no illumination on roasting technique (and
column57: I think Ina Garten's roasted tomato soup is better).  If you own Version 1.0
column58: stay away from this new edition. It is clearly not worth an additional $32.50! If it were not for AB's autograph in my Version 1.0
column59: I would give it away.

column1: I was very disappointed by this book. I was very eager to read this book and learn about Wolfram's thoughts about a new approach to science
column2: but there is nothing in this book that justifies such a lofty title. The first six chapters of the book describe various types of cellular automata
column3: which are computational models whose evolutionary behavior is governed by simple rules. Wolfram devoted much of his scientific career studying such systems.   One particular system that has caught Wolfram's interest is a cellular automata model that he calls "Rule 30". What is so remarkable about "Rule 30"? Rule 30 starts off with a single element and
column4: through repeated application of a simple rule
column5: rapidly evolves into a system involving apparently complex behavior.   There were two big problems with the first six chapters of this book. First
column6: Wolfram never bothers to try to explain what is so special about "Rule 30". Why doesn't Rule 29 or Rule 31 show complex behavior? What are the essential elements of Rule 30 that give complexity? Wolfram gives no information on this. A second big problem is that Wolfram is much too repetitive. The point that complexity can be generated by simple rules is hammered in over and over again. This book could clearly have used a lot of editing.  The rest of the book describes ways in which cellular automota can by applied to various scientific problems
column7: but no concrete
column8: specific pathways are given for how to tackle these various problems. Rather
column9: the chapters consist of various suggestions and musings by Wolfram on how cellular automata may relate to a wide range of scientific problems. The breadth of his discussions is more impressive than their depth
column10: which often never gets much deeper than noting visual similarities between some of his diagrams and the physical appearances of shells
column11: tiger stripes
column12: snowflakes
column13: etc.  A key problem with this book is that it never attempts to analyze why some rules give "complex" behavior and why others  don't. I'm reminded of a story that Wolfram himself related about the time he showed Richard Feynman a printout of "Rule 30":  "Well
column14: we'd just been crawling around the floor--with help with some other people--trying to use meter rules to measure some feature of a giant printout of it. And Feynman takes me aside
column15: rather conspiratorially
column16: and says: "Look
column17: I just want to ask you one thing: how did you know rule 30 would do all this crazy stuff?" "You know me
column18: I said. I didn't. I just had a computer try all the possible rules. And I found it." "Ah
column19: he said, now I feel much better. I was worried you had some way to figure it out." "  Both Wolfram and Feynman are geniuses
column20: but Feynman had something that Wolfram doesn't: A gift for seeing past the unessentials and getting to the gist of a problem. Wolfram fills his books with countless pages of diagrams showing "complex" behavior
column21: but never tries to explain the essential nature of Rule 30.  After reading this book
column22: I'm also reminded of a statement by Freeman Dyson
column23: another brilliant scientist
column24: after he looked at Wolfram's book: "There's a tradition of scientists approaching senility tocome up with grand
column25: improbable theories. Wolfram is unusual in that he's doing this in his 40's"

column1: I was disappointed there was not more substance to this novel.  Fitzgerald was less than halfway finished when he died
column2: and the seventeen "completed" episodes were in obvious need of re-editing.  Judging from the author's notes
column3: they would have been revised extensively anyway to fit his shifting vision of how the plot would evolve.  There are moments of clever satire on the Hollywood Industry (and especially its writers) that would probably have made the finished product well worth reading
column4: but Fitzgerald was still struggling to balance the satirical tone of his novel with the love story of its protagonists.  The editor's notes were very helpful
column5: though
column6: inasmuch as they showed what direction Fitzgerald wanted to take and the alternate endings he had in mind

Even the avid "trekie" reader of the Star Trek science fiction novels
column2: movies and television series must suspend disbelief
column3: when he finds Captain Kirk saying "Beam me up
column4: Scotty."  But the biblical literalist reading this book need make no such effort
column5: when he reads in this book that Jesus will effectively beam millions of true Christians up to heaven in the world-wide "Rapture."  Though the characters and their roles are fictitious
column6: the book specifically references the relevant biblical passages for the believer.   The story line opens with the chaotic moment of discovery after the historic mass Rapture event
column7: and the remainder is a moral melodrama concluding with emotional born-again conversions.   In the September/October 2006 issue of Foreign Affairs Walt Mead writes that fundamentalists are not hospitable to the idea of gradual progress toward a secular utopia driven by technological advances and the cooperation of intelligent people of all religious traditions.    Instead fundamentalists separate themselves from the world and have a premillennial pessimism about prospects for social reform.  Billy Graham's biography by Strober notes that they criticized Graham's "new evangelism" for its inclusiveness and for its involvement in addressing social problems. Yet their separatism does not preclude proselytizing as portrayed in these novels by the "Tribulation Force" or as exemplified by Jerry Falwell's Moral Majority.  They are also committed to an apocalyptic vision of the end of the world and are hostile to international institutions such as the United Nations. Mead notes that it is no coincidence that the Left Behind novels show the Antichrist rising to power as the secretary-general of the United Nations.  The U.S. Statistical Abstract reports that the per capita numbers of fundamentalists are growing exponentially
column8: while evangelicals and liberals - e.g. Southern Baptists
column9: Lutherans
column10: Presbyterians
column11: Methodists - and Catholics are continuing their per capita declines.  Such data and the reported popularity of these Left Behind novels indicate fundamentalism's growing appeal in reaction to contemporary American society.  I see the readers who seriously respond to this book as the "left behind" in the backwash of the tidal flows of cultural change in modern American society
column12: and as conservative Christians who believe it is better to stay behind.  And in not just a few respects
column13: they may be wise to do so.  Thomas J. Hickey

column1: Like so many others
column2: the Fed chairman is a mediocrity who rose to prominence by serving as a flunkey to David Rockefeller through exclusive membership in the J.P. Morgan-Chase billionaire's semi-secret Trilateral Commission.  Greenspan has long deserved to be exposed not for his own evil but for the greater evil that he is covering up.  Unfortunately

He tells you right off that this is going to be a hatchet job and immediately gets down to looking for facts to support his allegations.  Instead of talking about Greenspan's relationship to Rockefeller
column6: Batra diverts attention to any problem that exists in the economy and blames it on Greenspan.  This is like a medical book discussing cancer in terms of its symptoms rather than its causes

column1: A foreign girl moves to North America
column2: a place she was never suspected to have fit in
column3: and manages to become the top student in her class. Ewa or Eva Hoffman was a thirteen year old
column4: Polish immigrant when she arrived in Vancouver. She adapted quite well after a year of uncomfortable living. She became the Valedictorian of her high school
column5: went to Rice University
column6: and then Harvard. Lost in Translation by Eva Hoffman is a book not worthy of the reader's time. 	 	The main character in this book complained about her situation too much. Maybe Eva didn't want to move
column7: but it turned out for the better. She was safer
column8: she got a better job then what she was hoping for
column9: and she got to experience a whole new lifestyle. Instead
column10: Eva complained that she didn't fit in because she didn't wear make-up or because nobody understood her Russian jokes. The majority of the book was filled up with complaints. Another example would be how she was mad that her friend at college was just too stupid to understand her
column11: but actually Eva was just over analyzing the situation. Everything that happened to Eva in America had a negative side to it
column12: which the author always wrote about.  	This book was also very difficult to understand. The author jumped from time period to time period in an unsystematic way. At one point she was talking about high school
column13: the next paragraph was college
column14: then her childhood
column15: then the boat voyage
column16: and finally back to high school. The author could be talking about piano lessons in America and then she will write about her best friend in Poland and how much she misses her. If the book was in a regular pattern
column17: readers may be able to understand her life story and maybe even enjoy it slightly.  	This book is completely uninteresting and it has no plot. The author basically wrote down a bunch of random events that don't form a story. Even if the book was in a sensible order it
column18: the story would have no plot and it would still be perfectly boring. The author just tells a bunch or random events that happened. An example would be when she overheard her parents talking about books
column19: then it was about her friend at a school for the arts
column20: then the author moved on to a summer vacation. The author can move on to different events because this is a biography
column21: but there is no sense in jumping from event to event without actually having a reason.  	Lost in Translation by Eva Hoffman is simply a book that should not be read unless absolutely necessary. Eva complaints were far too many
column22: the book was difficult to comprehend
column23: the book has no storyline
column24: and it just isn't interesting.  A. Coffin

column1: Many years ago I enjoyed reading Ivins' columns but unforunately her brand of independent liberalism has turned into just another mainstream media voice parroting the Democrats. Her personal hatred of George Bush has become distracting and embarrasing. Strangely enough she reminds me of Rush Limbaugh. When he began doing political commentary on the radio Limbaugh was an independent with a conservative streak and was comfortable attacking Republicans. Similarly Ivins was originally an independent with a liberal streak who was comfortable attacking Democrats. Now Limbaugh is as firmly ensconced in the Republican camp as Ivins is in the Democratic camp.  What a shame
This epic is often talked up as some kind of ancient thriller
column2: a there-and-back-again from the 1st Century B.C.  However
column3: even a casual read will reveal the problematic nature of an assessment of this nature.  The poem is in reality a subtle and complex study of the nature of Greek epic.  Apollonius is not simply writing an adventure story
column4: the story was common knowledge then and there were multiple versions people could turn to.  Apollonius
column5: the scholar is meditating upon epic and its place in a modern world.  The text is incredibly ambiguous and can reveal millions of alternate readings.  Apollonius needs to be read again and again
column6: often in the context of earlier epic works.  You cannot fully understand Apollonius without Homer.  On the surface it is an adventure story
column7: but with no real hero
column8: no real ending and with often no real motives. A good translation by someone who understands the text is a must.  Unfortunately I don't think that Rieu is up to the task.  Only recently has Apollonius become a viable subject for study
column9: and I think that Rieu's translation is out of date.  By trying to turn Apollonius' text into an exciting adventure like his Odyssey
column10: Rieu skips over textual ambiguities that imbue the text with more meaning.  He even mistranslates the opening sentence and ruins its effect.  Anyone looking for Apollonius is best advised to turn to Hunter's superb translation in Oxford Worlds Classics
column11: it's modern
column12: up to date and accurate

column2: who will lead him to the Dark Tower  On this journey
column3: Roland travels through gritty rundown lands
column4: often times lost in thought
column5: reflecting on his past and all that he has lost. And thus becomes the pattern of the story. Roland travels and thinks and travels some more.  I did enjoy one childhood story in particular. column1: If you are interested in this book
column2: you are probably a baby boomer concerned about the aging of your mind due to occasional forgetfulness.  Schacter will give you much comfort that your brain is most probably perfectly fine.  Daniel Schacter explains that our brains are programmed to forget and delete trivial clutter to allow our cognitive resources to deal with the contemporary complexities of daily life.  I thought the brain worked like a bad hard disk PC drive.  After reading this book
column3: I understand it works like an excellent Internet browser that automatically empty its cache memory
column4: so it can function on new searches.   Schacter mentions patients endowed with near perfect memory.  They were overwhelmed  by information overload.  Not able to differentiate trivia from important information
column5: they lead dependent miserable lives.  Schacter made me understand that there is nothing perfect about a perfect memory.          Schacter also made me aware how unreliable our memories are.  This has serious judicial implications affecting the credibility of eyewitnesses and plaintiffs relying on recalled memories from their childhood.  Next time you concede an argument because the other party stated they clearly remembered a specific situation
column6: attempt to get to the objective data to check the evidence.   Memories are highly fallible.        So why am I giving this book a 2?  It is because the writing is dry and lengthy.  Another author
column7: Aaron Nelson in his book "Achieving Optimal Memory" elegantly summarizes "The Seven Sins..." in just 11 pages.  You actually don't learn much more after reading the entire 200 pages of "The Seven Sins..." Schacter shares so many clinical examples in such exhaustive details about each of the Sins
column8: that he exhausts most readers in the process.  Instead
column9: I do recommend "Achieving Optimal Memory" that covers not only the "Seven Sins" but a lot more and much more efficiently in a much easier to read 200 page book.

column1: Time was when the words Betty Crocker actually stood for something good in cookbooks
column2: although the books' recipes
column3: for better or for worse
column4: were always a product of their times.  The very first "Betty Crocker Picture Cook Book" was published in 1950 (still available)
column5: revolutionized how cookbooks were produced
column6: and was an enormous best-seller.  The recipes were the result of much thorough testing in the company's kitchens and in homes across America.  This was cooking from scratch with very little reliance on convenience foods in its pages.  This gradually changed as Betty and her books became more and more of a shill for General Mills' products and her name got plastered on one mix after another to the benefit of the company's bottom line
column7: but to the detriment of good cooking.    The two all-purpose cookbooks that came out in 1961 and 1969 were both loaded with recipes and wonderful tips/helps
column8: although you could see the beginnings of sacrificing quality for convenience--especially in the 1969 edition--but this was still relatively minor in proportion to the majority of the recipes.  If you have one of these books
column9: treasure and keep it; you'll never see their likes again.  The current 10th edition looks good but
column10: like the past several editions
column11: the number of recipes has been drastically reduced.  Gone are the many variations
column12: which are especially missed in baked goods.  It was wonderful having recipes of many cakes that were sized for two people or small families and having different mixing methods to choose from.  Now way too many recipes are of the "dump and stir" method instead of choosing methods that would insure the best results.  Also gone is the very friendly
column13: assuring
column14: conversationial voice of yesteryear.  Yes
column15: there are recipes covering a wider range of ingredients and styles
column16: but they are mostly stripped-down versions.    It's obvious that the folks at Betty Crocker now seem to think that no one really cooks anymore and can't be bothered with proper preparation of dishes
column17: which begs the question of why General Mills even bothers to publish these cookbooks anymore.  The "Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook" is a better bet for those looking for an all-purpose
column18: everyday guide.  It has a better layout
column19: the recipes and ingredients are generally of a higher quality
column20: and there are more recipes and variations than Betty Crocker's had in some time.  Even better
column21: if you care at all about the quality of the food you eat and serve your family
column22: I highly recommend the cookbooks of Cooks' Illustrated/America's Test Kitchen.  Their comparable
column23: general-purpose cookbook is called "The America's Test Kitchen Family Cookbook."  The recipes are tested and reworked--dozens of times
column24: if necessary--to be the best their staff can make them and you get precise directions in preparing them.  It's a shame that Betty Crocker has abdicated her throne and good name
column25: but there's even better stuff out there now.  Go for it!

column1: I am dumbfounded by all the 5-star reviews. This book is absolutely dreadful.   I was skeptical of this sort of manifestion/metaphysical approach to wealth and success at first
column2: but after using it I am becoming increasingly less skeptical.  I have a hard time buying everything prosperous-universe crown promotes
column3: but at the very least
column4: keeping an attitude of hope and optimism helps you persevere through hard times. On the other hand
column5: I think that approaching this sort of thing with an open mind includes--importantly--remaining open enough to admit when something doesn't work
column6: and not to rationalize the failure ("I must be indulging negative thoughts
column7: or The Universe must not think I'm ready for what I desire"). I'm guessing that people are raving about these books and awarding them so many stars because of what the books promise (and they CAN be inspirational)
column8: not what the techniques actually deliver with consistency
column9: and I think that is especially true of Wilde's book.  This book is a unique train wreck. I found it so unreadable that I got through 54 pages and gave up
column10: then as an heroic effort of perseverance picked it up again and struggled on.  When Abraham Lincoln said
column11: "He can compress the most words into the smallest idea of any man I know
column12: he could well have been talking about Stuart Wilde.   Wilde goes on interminably about the most modest of ideas, as though he has discovered the Philosopher's Stone. I'd almost rather listen to a Hollywood celebrity blather on about politics than read another page of this godawful book. The first 4 chapters of the book could have been expressed in a concise 6 or 7 pages, but instead Wilde babbles on with his dimestore philosophizing--stuff that is really embarrassingly simplistic--and with stories that seem to have little purpose beyond demonstrating how unutterably clever and superior he is. He *is* occasionally funny, during those rare instances (I count two) when through sheer dint of will he is able to deploy a little strategic understatement, but most of the time he writes with a grandness totally unbefitting his modest thoughts, and it all ends up sounding very stupid.   Wilde evinces a smug and outrageous self-love in this book that is quite unbearable and that makes it practically impossible to digest the infrequent good advice that he presents (an example of which is one mentioned by another reviewer, viz., to practice accepting by really accepting everything offered, including picking up pennies on the street). Reading this book, you get a sense of the author's sense of self-grandiosity (even while he's condemning people's egos), and as a result it does not surprise you when you find your way to his website and see him present himself as a visionary and a prophet (one prone to conspiracy-mongering).  Wilde display contemp for anyone whose priority is not amassing wealth. For instance, at one point he condemns a researcher he knows for going to Argentina to conduct entymological research on some dumb beetle
column13: and dismisses this pursuit of knowledge for its own sake as the fellow's unwillingness to enter the marketplace. This comes immediately after his dismissal of college education as time spent learning useless stuff." The book is fecund with idiotic assertions of this sort.  There are MANY better books on success
column14: and probably the worst of them is still better than this one. A much better book of this type is "Shortcut to a Miracle
column15: or even Joe Vitale's The Attractor Factor
column16:
which although flawed is vastly more readable that this piece of garbage. Don't be fooled by these glowing reviews. This book is awful

column1: Fortunately the book was not that expensive so I simply wasted time and did not match it with wasted money. The book is portrayed as a survey from Ancient Sumeria through the Roman Empire. This is patently false. I have looked all through for any reference to either the Sumerians or the Assyrians and find none. This could of course be because I read about half and decided I had wasted enough valuable time. Any information prior to the Hellenists is almost unheard of.  The author makes grand assumptions that are fine for a writer of historical fiction but not for an academic study of a subject. For example his claim that it is now "a proven fact" that the Hebrew slavery
column2: delivery and migration to Palesine are simply myths is patently over-reaching. I know there is little archeological evidence to support the complete Biblical narrative but that is far from proof of falsehood. The author should take a clue from all those who at one time claimed that Nineveh
column3: the Hittites and many other ancient cultures and events were myths. It is fine to speculate
column4: but to claim as fact something that is still unknown is poor scholarship at best

column1: As an academic

column5: monitoring progress
column6: planning meetings
column7: keeping minutes
column8: etc. So I bought the book from the guy who "invented" mind mapping to learn more about it. What did I learn? In a nutshell
column9: DONT WASTE YOUR TIME AND MONEY
column10: the book might even put you off for good from a quite useful tool.  Of course
column11: if you have a special kind of humour
column12: you can read it as a perfect parody of a "scientific" how-to book. This book is a wonderful mixture of unbearable hype
column13: awful jargon and artful use of pseudo science. Not that the author wouldn't be clear about it: Tony Buzan (I guess Barry had his reasons for emphasising in the starting chapter that it was written by Tony ...) states right at the beginning that this book will basically solve all the problems you've ever had (in fact
column14: not just you
column15: !mankind!) by introducing you to "a new concept in the development of thought" and "a revolutionary new tool". It gets even better later on when you learn about mind mapping as "the next step in the evolution of the human mind". To a certain extent
column16: the whole thing works; it does stimulate your creativity - I'm writing my first ever book review on Amazon - and it helps you practice speed reading - there is so little information amidst all this breathless writing that you can easily finish it in an hour. But let's be serious. The first couple of chapters teach you how your brain works
column17: empty blah based on "scientific research" mostly dating back to the 1970s (of course
column18: only material from sources of various quality exactly supporting a preconceived argument). That's a bit like James Watt explaining a fuel cell powered car to you - not completely off the mark
column19: but
column20: you know
column21: a few things have happened in the meantime ... Then you get to learn the principles
column22: "the laws" (I would have liked commandments; it would fit the style). Common sense dressed up as wisdom and nothing turned into something through fancy relabelling. I really like the distinction between the Mini Mind Map (TM) and the full Mind Map (TM). "Power words" and "basic ordering ideas" for comprehensive categories is also pretty cool. From there
column23: you move on to applications. Same story. I skipped the end; at last I heeded other reviews of the book. But the thing that makes the book a real turn-off is the way it is written and typeset: - We know that repeating important bits aid your memory
column24: so you get LOTS of repetitions (especially mind mapping is SUPER
column25: mind mapping is REALLY super
column26: you get the idea ...). - We know that metaphors help you memorise stuff
column27: so you get LOTS of them (really hilarious stuff
column28: I failed to note it down while reading). - We know that using the odd adjective and slightly colourful language enhances readability
column29: so you get LOTS of it. This is where the book scores 12 out of 10 points. It's littered with superlatives like infinite
column30: enormous
column31: gigantic
column32: etc. and very large numbers (trillions
column33: quadrillions
column34: 1's and lots of 0's behind them). An example "... means that we are all magically and eerily different from each other. ... You who are now reading this sentence contain
column35: in your brain
column36: trillions of associations shared by no one else
column37: past
column38: present or future" (p. 72). Spooky would have been nice there! - We know that highlighting text adds emphasis
column39: so we get LOTS of HigHLIghTEd text. - We know that using different fonts add visual clarity
column40: so we get LOTS of different fonts. - We know that boxes are useful for setting apart important points or illustrative material
column41: so we get LOTS of them. - We know that a good image says more than a thousand words
column42: so we get LOTS of psychedelic mind maps
column43: most of them unreadable
column44: but very LOUD. - We know that selling nothing as something can work if you dress it up well
column45: so you get LOTS of it
column46: e.g. "Intuition is a much-maligned mental skill which I and neuropsychologist Michael Gelb prefer to define as 'superlogic'" (p. 111) which then allows you to engage in "superthinking" (you know
column47: my friend and expert-of-the-human-psyche Joe Abrahamovitch Miller and I like to call it the thing only our wives have ... Joe
column48: by the way
column49: is a the bartender in the local pub around the corner). You also get the "parabrain"
column50: the "paraconscious"
column51: you get the regular urban myth that we only use a fraction of our brain
column52: and so on and so forth.  I could go on

column1: We live in a 1.5 story home where the master is the only thing upstairs & my husband runs an ISP from home - LOTS of computers in the house
column2: so we had to find a good monitor that would drown out the static of the electronics & outside world
column3: but allow us to hear our little pip-squeek clearly. At first I was thrilled the Sony when I used it downstairs during her daytime napping & loved that I could set it to voice-activated & only hear it when she's reallllly awake! But that night when we used it upstairs it kept picking up interferrence in the form of a loud static chirp after several hours of silence even though it was on voice-activated mode. I tried moving it several times
column4: but finally ended up going back to the old FP sounds & lights one we had which really wasn't any better! (AND having to run up & down the stairs to try all the combinations of 9 channels on the receiver & transmitter of the Sony was a royal pain!)  The next day I went to Target & found The First Years Digital 2.4ghz Monitor & what a difference! It was about the same price as the Sony
column5: but it searches for a clear channel like your phone does. I was afraid it would interfere with out 2.4ghz phones
column6: but after a week
column7: no problems & we have NO static/interferrence! It's crystal clear no matter where in the house (hubby even took it into the computer room & was able to hear her wake up just fine!) I know everyone's environment is different
column8: but the Sony definately didn't work for us

I found this book to be flawed in its very nature.   Scarf attempts to explain the problems of the couples in her book using categories and classifications of psychoanalytic theory that are utterly unfounded.  She  attributes the problems of mairrage to self-imposed psychoanalytic  conventions that do not have a true basis in real life.  Her explanations  of things such as "projective identification" are almost comical  to the reader with a critical eye.  For example
column2: she attributes the jealosy  of one partner to the other partners
column3: unexpressed
column4: repressed feelings.   This analysis seems to try to stretch a simply jealosy issue of one partner  onto the other.  The takes a simple problem and makes it complicated with  carefully selected detail and over-zealous classification

column1: The Grays is the latest discourse on alien visitation by Whitley Strieber. While fully clothed as a novel it is abundantly clear that although the narrative events and characters are fictional
column2: the over-arching message - that we are contact with entities from another world - is the center-piece of the work.  Communion
column3: published in 1998
column4: was Mr. Strieber's first foray into non-fiction. In it
column5: he claimed to have been regularly approached by extra-world creatures that seem to need contact - both physical and spiritual - with us. Since then
column6: there have been several more alleged non-fiction works that amplified on Mr. Strieber's experiences as well as those of family
column7: friends and members of what I will call the abductee community. There is also the rather brilliant "Majestic
column8: an out-and-out novel that described the events around and leading from the Roswell Incident of 1948.  It is Majestic" that is a connective tissue to "The Grays" in that both are driven by the fact that living aliens were captured after a vehicle crashed in the New Mexico desert. However
column9: in the former work
column10: it is the nature of the cover-up and the allegorical rapture of the main character that is the core of the story.  "The Grays
column11: on the other hand, is about the why of the visitation/abduction cycle. We learn why the human race is important to the Grays and how the US government has gone along with their wants and needs to propel its agenda.  The early part of the book introducing the various characters is bumpy and a bit incoherent, as if Strieber perhaps grafted it on late in the writing/editing process or - more likely in my opinion - used some older work notes. I say this because there are some time sequence problems and muddiness about characters.   This all goes away once the story takes hold. Strieber launches his characters - who are, as another reviewer noted, somewhat single-dimensional; almost caricatures - on an adventure story that could have been written by Clive Cussler or Steven Coonts or Arthur C. Clarke.   And therein lays the rub for me. The Communion" series addressed some major metaphysical issues in that Strieber often stated his inability to determine if the "aliens
column12: be they Gray, Blues, Nordics or whatever, were from another world or simply another dimensional manifestation of our own. There were times that Strieber seemed to imply that religion may have sprung from these entities. Here, we are dealing with a more-or-less straight forward space opera with heavy overtones of government mis- and mal-feasance that include allusions to the war in Iraq and the military-industrial complex. There is narrative flow, but there is no meaningful attempt to explain alien visitation on the sort of higher plane found int he toher works. In a way, I felt cheated at the end of the story because  Mr. Strieber manages to denigrate his preceding works by producing a workman-like and somewhat tedious page turner that raises but one question: Will the good guys beat out the bad guys?"  But
column13: we are not even granted that answer! Instead
column14: in the manner of the Sci-Fi serials of the 30s and 40s
column15: we see a crisis averted but with no true resolution. Instead
column16: one feels that the real message is "wait for the sequel!"

column1: ﻿well written and mildly interesting. however the author appears to think that we the people will be safer if we (the people) would simply give ourselves over to Big Brother.  Frankly terrorism and terrorists come and go
column2: but the constitution is with us always. Unlike the author
column3: I'll keep the constitution and bill of rights and take my chances with terrorists.  As an example of the authors flawed thinking
column4: he mentions that after 1973
column5: when new airport screening was introduced
column6: 5000 guns were collected from passengers as if this were a good thing (or that armed passengers were a bad thing) but what he fails to grasp that
column7: although 5000 guns were collected there were NOT 5000 or even 500  or even 5 incidents involving firearms then or in the previous years before screening. Nor does he seem to make the connection that the 9/11 hijackers managed to take over their aircraft with box cutters and planning and willingness to die. Could armed passengers or pilots have made a difference? Would things have been any worse?  Lets look at the UK. Many surveillance cameras and draconian police powers. The result? Pretty pictures of men alleged to be bombers (yet the bombs still went off and a second attempt almost succeeded) and one innocent man shot dead by police.   Terrorists are always going to be with us. In an industrial society technology acts as a force multiplier. One or two or a dozen men can kill thousands if they are determined. Auto accidents kill 50K/year.  A Tsunami  will kill tens of thousands. Civil war kills hundreds of thousands. And a pandemic may kill millions.  And no one is even bothering to count dead and dying of starvation.   Terror is a problem
column8: but it's more a problem of the mind and the author is stoking fears to sell books. Shame on him.

column1: Having suffered 2 major depressive episodes in the last 6 years
column2: I can assure those who swallow Breggin's nonsense hook
column3: line and sinker that nobody could have "talked" me back to anything resembling "health."  The mental anguish I suffered during those episodes was unbearable and waiting for a quack like Breggin to use psychoanalysis or some other form of talk therapy to provide any relief would have taken far too long.  Financial and insurance considerations aside
column4: talk therapies alone are simply too slow to achieve positive results.  No doubt pharmaceutical companies often drive treatment trends in a highly questionable manner both via perks to MD-psychiatrists and (the increasingly obnoxious) practice of direct advertising of prescription drugs to the public.  Nevertheless
column5: anti-depressants
column6: anti-psychotics
column7: anti-anxiety meds and sleep aids HELP relieve the suffering quickly
column8: which is what medicine should be all about
column9: not ideology.  Only one of Breggin's points is valid
column10: and that is the disturbing trend for nearly all MD-psychiatrists to focus on psycho-pharmacology to the exclusion of psychotherapy.  The current treatment model has the patient seeing a psychiatrist for meds management typically quarterly while also seeing a psychologist for psychotherapy anywhere from weekly to monthly.  It would seem that "one stop shopping" would not only make things more convenient for patients
column11: but competence in multiple therapies would also make for a more effective and insightful professional.  Use meds to stablize the patient and minimize the suffering
column12: then pursue cognitive and other talk therapies to provide coping skills and attack the environmental and experiential contributors to the disease.

column1: This book provides a broad overview of some of the issues behind the Simplicity movement.  The author
column2: Cecile Andrews set up a number of Simplicity study circles near her home in the Northwest.  This book reveals some of the factors that led her to become interested in Simplicity as well as her ideas of how Simplicity study circles might work.  Much of the beginning of the book provides justification for adopting Simplicity.  Andrews enumerates problems such as hyper-consumption
column3: environmental degradation
column4: and personal isolation.  She also explores possible actions we could take to solve these problems
column5: such as consciously building community with other people and the earth
column6: finding ways to express our spirituality
column7: and restructuring our economic system to make it more environmentally and socially friendly. In the last part of the book
column8: she describes the idea of Simplicity study circles
column9: the benefits that might be gained from participating in one
column10: and how a study circle should operate.  She also provides a 10-week study plan based on the earlier material in the book.  Although I agree with the ideas in this book
column11: I found the book rather disappointing in content.  Much of the discussion is either so personal as to be hard to generalize
column12: or else a superficial summary of other more substantial texts.  For example
column13: Andrews frequently refers to findings of Juliet Schor; readers would have more material for discussion by reading Schor's works directly.  Some of Andrews' suggestions for addressing problems are rather inappropriate.  To draw attention to hyper-consumerism
column14: she suggests surreptitiously clothes-pinning tags with messages like "You don't really need this
column15: do you?" inside articles of clothing in shops.  While I'm all for trying to get people to become more aware of their needless purchases
column16: I don't think messing with the property of individual store owners is an acceptable way to go about the mission.  Her suggestions for reforming our economic system would be great in an ideal state
column17: but until we are run by a benevolent socialist dictator
column18: I don't think they can realistically be put into action.  It would be better to focus our efforts on goals that are conceivably achievable.  Overall
column19: while I found the topic of this book interesting
column20: I think there are numerous other books on the topic of Simplicity that are better implemented
column21: starting with Joe Dominguez and Vicki Robin's "Your Money or Your Life".  It's hard to tell from this book if Andrews can take credit for originating Simplicity study groups such as those run by the Northwest Earth Institute.  If so
column22: she certainly deserves credit for her efforts in that area
column23: but I don't think there's enough substantial material in this volume to use as background reading for an effective study group by itself.

The purpose for his illegal acts was personal profit
column6: to skin the animals

column8: several hundred in a period of a few days

column17: like one of his skinned alligator carcasses
column18: on the ash pile of despicable acts by the self-indulgent

column1: After book 4 the series begins to meander around.  Characters are constantly side-tracked into meaningless
column2: boring tasks.  The first 200-300 pages of this book are basically a re-hash of the previous books only excitement (Rand's capture and escape from the "bad witches") seen from different characters perspectives.  This is an example of what writing becomes when the author obviously has no idea of where the story is going
column3: and there obviously is little or no editing.  The author must being paid by the word count and not the content.  The story seems to get written into little boxes
column4: and has to be written back on track again and again.  I no longer have the patience to actually read each page.  I find myself skimming through to find some useful information or a single point of action.  The characters have also stalled out with Rand spending most of his time talking to him-self while the world goes to hell.  His big secret plan to quickly deal with one of the forsaken (started in the previous book) continues to drag on and on and on.....  This series had a good basic story.  Unfortunately you have to wade through crap to try and find it.  I'm beginning to wonder if the series will ever end

column1: My blood was boiling as I read other customers' rave reviews of "The Prince of Tides."  Whoever considers this thesaurus-scrubbing
column2: self-indulgent mess of cliches a literary masterpiece has no sense of language and literature.  Someone was even audacious enough to compare Pat Conroy to Virginia Woolf.  What a joke!  Woolf's writing is brilliant
column3: original
column4: and real.  She cuts to the quick
column5: whereas Conroy slathers his story in cloying metaphors and trite descriptions.  One can almost see Conroy congratulating himself on each simile and metaphor as he writes
column6: not caring how superfluous or artificial his language is -- nor how unrealistic it makes the story.  I laughed out loud at some of the words he puts in the characters' mouths.  In the real world
column7: nobody is as self-concious and self-reflexive as the characters in this book.  They do not speak in reams of figurative language.  I cannot even get into how inconsistent and impossible the characters are
column8: especially the children.  Also
column9: Conroy caricatures both places and exaggerates the cultural gulf between them.  (I make that claim as a Southerner who lived in NYC for four years.)  It's one of many
column10: many flaws in this ridiculous book.  Read it if you like sensational stories with mass appeal (John Irving
column11: etc.)
column12: but avoid it if you have any respect for the English language and for real American literature (Cheever
column13: Plath
column14: Hemingway
column15: Cather
column16: etc.).  Don't be fooled by all the fools out there.

column8: or Hidetoro
column9: or whatever his name is

column12: and Hidetoro Lear gets treated shabbily.  He's wanted dead or dead.  In this treatment of the annoying plot

column14: and a cruel one?  You may as well cry over Saddam Hussein.  Look at this movie with fresh eyes.  Look at Shakespeare's King Lear with fresh eyes.  This stuff simply is not very entertaining

column1: Alan Moore pretty much took the world of superheroes
column2: shook them upside down and inside out with his WATCHMEN book(s). WATCHMEN is something that I find myself re-reading every year or two.  When I first heard about this project
column3: I had hopes that Moore would once again shake
column4: rattle and roll this otherwise usually pedestrian form of comic-book.  The premise was a good one....what would happen if a court of law had to be administered to a superhero (those who so often seem to live outside or above the law).  Okay
column5: it's ground that Stan Lee & Wally Wood covered in DAREDEVIL #7 (when Namor/Submariner wanted to file suit against the entire Human Race...and
column6: in turn
column7: has legal charges pressed against him).  But that was forty-some years ago....and Alan Moore is a master at the craft of comic-book writing....and this really sounded as though it had a great deal of potential.  Unfortunately one doesn't see a lot of new road paved between the DAREDEVIL #7 issue and this work.  Granted
column8: there are some interesting twists and turns....but the work as a whole does not live up to the finer sum of its parts.  While I can appreciate Moore wanting to explore and dissect the superhero mythos that seems to have captivated generation after generation
column9: I fear that he doesn't manage to do so with JUDGMENT DAY.    For those who truly wish to read Moore at his best
column10: I'd give a blazing five stars to WATCHMEN or V FOR VENDETTA. This is not a book I'd use to introduce those unfamiliar with Moore's work in comic-books.

column1: I have specialized in providing professional education and therapy to divorced
column2: courting
column3: and re/wedded couples since 1981. I am (a) 66
column4: (b) a stepgrandson
column5: stepson
column6: and ex-stepfather and stepbrother
column7: (c) an invited Board member of the Stepfamily Association of America
column8: (d) a contributing editor to 'Your Stepfamily Online
column9: ' and (e) the author of six personal-growth and family-relations books.  I recommend this book to readers who want a well-organized overiew of the complex premarital and re/marital counseling process. I caution readers that the authors omit several essential points which cripples the utility of their book:    1) why and how to assess and reduce co-parents' psychological wounds from childhood (vs. divorce). The authors lay the groundwork for this
column10: but don't guide readers on how to follow through;   2) the origin and impacts of blocked grief in adults and kids
column11: and how to spot and reduce it. There is no entry for "grief" in the book's index;   3) co-parent unawareness of five key topics: (a) normal personality formation
column12: composition
column13: and function; (b) keys to high-nurturance families and relationships
column14: (c) effective communication skills
column15: (d) healthy 3-level grief
column16: and (e) stepfamily realities
column17: norms
column18: implications
column19: and hazards. And...    4) little effective re/marital and co-parenting help (i.e. courtship coaching
column20: classes
column21: informed counseling
column22: co-parent support groups) available in most communities and the media.    In my clinical experience since 1981
column23: these factors will often block the best-intentioned adults from following relevant  re/marital and co-parenting advice. Counseling couples who are courting and re/married - specially any with existing kids - without including these factors in assessment and interventions can only be partially effective.    For more perspective on this review
column24: see:  http://sfhelp.org/11/choose_bks.ht

column1: Graphics aren't the most important part of a game to me.  I already owned Oblivion when I bought Gothic 2 because I was hoping it would be a darker and more mature "Oblivion" style RPG.    While it does have much more mature content than Oblivion
column2: .. I never got to see it because of the bad controls
column3: .. bad collision and lack of fun.  (By bad collision I'm talking about your character walking through or getting stuck on objects.)    The only weapons you can find at first are a tree branch and a tiny dagger.  There are no easy enemies to fight for a Level 1 character.  Even the little gremlin looking guys in the first cave by that pond at the beginning totally beat the crap out of you with ease.  The controls make combat an unfun chore.    I'm a patient and forgiving gamer but Gothic 2 barely has half the quality of Elder Scrolls 4 : Oblivion.  If you've never played Oblivion and don't have an XBox 360 or a PC that can run it
column4: .. then maybe you'll get into Gothic 2.  It has much lower system requirements

column1: Richard Roeper is the worst thing to happen to movies since the corporate take-over of the studios in the 1980's. He cares far more about celebrities
column2: his own image
column3: and behind the scenes gossip than he does for any film. Whereas a good critic would find ways to help people love movies (or any artform) more
column4: Roeper almost never does this
column5: choosing instead to focus on the most negative elements of many of the films he writes about. Even the descriptions above
column6: by the publisher
column7: highlight this fact: he writes about "Reviews of Hollywood finance." (Rather than encouraging people to care more about the story than the budget.) "Actors who appear in television commercials." Does Roeper want us to focus on who does commercials
column8: or focus on each movie
column9: and decide whether its story is told well or not? Citing two unsuccessful films
column10: Roeper proposes a "moratorium on pet projects." But Roeper wants to oversimplify films so he can snarkily make his point
column11: when he ignores the reality that many
column12: many successful (i.e.
column13: well-told) films are "pet projects." Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ
column14: or Martin Scorsese's The Last Temptation of Christ are two strong (and very different) examples. But Roeper just wants to dumb everything down (including the movies and movie audience) for his jokey complaints. I do believe that this very shallow man loves movies
column15: but he uses a tremendous amount of power and energy encouraging and teaching people to utterly dismiss entire movies because of one or two irrelevant elements. A quick example: When the film "Chicago" was in theatres
column16: Roeper nearly bent himself double complaining fiercely about the fact that the movie wasn't filmed in Chicago - EVEN THOUGH THIS HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH WHAT IS ON THE SCREEN. I heard him being interviewed on a radio show
column17: and the host was scoffing at "Chicago
column18: saying that he wouldn't go see a musical. Rather than stepping into the role of film critic and defending the film as sexy and fun (Roeper gave a thumbs up to it), Roeper merely complained about the location of the shoot again, and never said another word about it. Disgraceful. This book is NOT, a love letter to film." It is a course in learning how to diminish and dismiss film
column19: our greatest artform

column1: The 2002 version of the Star Wars core rulebook is an improvement over the original.  It upgrades some underpowered character classes
column2: adds some breadth
column3: and makes much-needed improvements to the very abstract and annoying vehicle operation system used in the 1999 rulebook.  Unfortunately
column4: the central
column5: crippling problem with the 1999 version remains:  the d20 system just isn't well-suited to Star Wars storytelling.  Playing this game is nothing like playing out a Star Wars story
column6: and a lot like playing Dungeons and Dragons in space.  Star Wars is fast-moving
column7: fluid
column8: and dynamic
column9: and not much concerned with power balance.  A kid fresh off the moisture farm can fight his way past elite enemy troops to save the princess
column10: and one Sith Lord can arrange the downfall of the entire Jedi order.  Audacity and heroic (or villainous) attitudes matter more than experience and number-crunching.  Major characters rarely die
column11: and then only if there's a strong dramatic reason for it.  Plotlines are loose and free-form.  A game based on Star Wars should reflect that.  By contrast
column12: d20 is very cut-and-dried
column13: and very regulated
column14: and much too lethal.  Concepts like "level"
column15: "class"
column16: and "hit points" are fundamental to the d20 system
column17: but are not very applicable to the Star Wars universe.  The system has a lot going for it
column18: and it's great for Dungeons and Dragons
column19: but here it's a case of trying to stuff a square peg into a round hole.  I prefer the West End Games "d6" version released in the late 1980s.  It has its flaws - it doesn't deal with very powerful characters as well as it might
column20: and character creation could use some tuning (particularly for Force-sensitive PCs) - but it captures the feel of Star Wars.  A revision of that rule system
column21: or a completely new system incorporating the best features of both d6 and d20
column22: would have been a much better choice than using the d20 system as a "one-size-fits-all" set of mechanics.  However
column23: it seems unlikely that Wizards of the Coast will forsake their flagship d20 system for something as high-profile as Star Wars.  So I suggest that if you really want to get into gaming in the Star Wars universe
column24: look for a used copy of the West End Games version

column1: I bought this book a few years ago on the recommendation of a professor of labor history.  History is often told from the point of view of the "winners"
column2: so I thought it would be good to absorb a perspective that is not usually taught.  I admit that all history is a form of narrative
column3: and there are no "pure" facts in history since all narratives make value judgments at least implicitly.  But some narratives "work" better than others; some narratives enshrine values that would be better for us to hold than others.  Some ways of understanding the past are more helpful
column4: and thus more correct
column5: than others.  The narrative presented in this book is not very helpful for the same reason that ruling-class narratives are unhelpful: both are heroic narratives.  The only difference is that those who play the role of hero and those who play the marginalized have switched places.  History is far too complex of a process - of a story - to say that "so-and-so was responsible for such-and-such".  In this case
column6: we learn that poor laborers
column7: minorities
column8: women
column9: and immigrants are "really" responsible for America's accomplishments.  Of course
column10: this is partially correct
column11: for it is surely the case that we would not be where we are were it not for these groups.  But to imply that educated white men - people like two of the authors of the book themselves - made little "real" contribution to America's accomplishments but instead were responsible for all of our social failings is preposterous.  This is simply a swing of the pendulum to the opposite extreme.  In fact
column12: I think that the whole project of parcelling out persons into groups
column13: and then telling a group-based historical narrative is problematic.  Which group defines your identity?   The failing of this book is that it mistakes the the part for the whole
column14: the necessary for the sufficient.  A much better narrative that includes the marginalized and the working class can be found in Howard Zinn's *A People's History of the United States*.    I gave the book two stars instead of one because the writing is quite good - just like an absorbing historical fiction

column1: Once in a while a person accidentally stumbles on an especially annoying book. One written particularly because a desperate publisher made a phone call
column2: or mailed a letter with a check to an author with the words: "It's time to write another one
column3: Shirley..." and the author hurled herself to write
column4: without a plan
column5: without ideas and the only thing that came out was a dull diary filled with self pity
column6: anti-Americanism
column7: sexism and generally criticism... Well
column8: this is one of those books and I truly feel sorry for the trees that have to die annually to satisfy the erroneous marketing projections of underpaid book editors in the current cost-cutting environment (especially after the advent of Print-on-Demand) in order to deliver such hideous and mind numbing gems. Yet I am also grateful. I'm grateful for these sacrifices because they serve to carry a message to the reader
column9: which he or she can carry to you the broader audience. That message is - DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME WITH THIS BOOK AND THIS AUTHOR.  In terms of content - well
column10: there is no story here. This is simply a tedious account of a lonely woman who spent someone else's money to visit Antarctica and record her daily experiences. What kind of experiences
column11: you wonder?  The kind that go like this"  "...we took off over the frozen sound toward the Transantarctics..." "...we could see individual birds waddling about with stones in their beaks..." "...Later that day we landed at the snout of the Mawson Glacier for a picnic..." "...so we all had our own few feet of privacy. It was hot and dark inside..." "...and later we saw all their small yellow tents pitched in the distance..."  and go on and on and on...  Occasionally the author makes references to Scott's
column12: Shackleton's and other expeditions
column13: but in no way enough to stir imagination or interest. I doubt you'd learn anything new from this book.  If you are truly interested about Antarctica
column14: the history behind the conquests and a first person account of the harshness of the pole and its frozen lands
column15: check out "Race to the Pole: Tragedy
column16: Heroism
column17: and Scott's Antarctic Quest" by Ranulph Fiennes.  Yield to reason - ignore this one.  - by Simon Cleveland

column1: The author chose a very important topic
column2: but he's attacking straw men throughout the entire thing. He complains about religious people who supposedly use isolated Bible quotes to endorse poverty's existence
column3: and then he spends a half-chapter piling on the Bible quotes to say why we should act. I agree we should act and the Bible says we should act
column4: but I could do with a little less condescension. No religious person uses the Bible to argue in favor of poverty. Who on earth does the author think he's arguing against?    He says there's a problem
column5: and we all agree with that
column6: but then he assumes that the existence of poverty somehow predetermines the particular solutions he recommends.  He fails to conclusively link the causes of poverty with those solutions.  Knowing how someone fell into a hole does not provide sufficient information about how to get them out of the hole.  Repeating the same assertions a dozen times is not the same as a reasoned argument.  The author needs to realize that people don't differ much about whether poverty is bad. They disagree on how to reduce it
column7: and the author does not address these other opinions much.  Instead we get a lot of caricature of religious people and conservatives

column1: There are just two rules when you create a thriller with a pretty lead: 1) The lead (the delectable Ashley Judd) had better show some skin. 2) Thou shalt not be boring.  Twisted utterly fails on both counts.  Basically
column2: Judd is Jessica Shepard
column3: a messed up cop who specializes in hunting serial killers.  She's fond of bedding men she meets at late night bars
column4: because she's self-destructive.  Only Jessica looks fabulous all the time
column5: even when she's been on a bender (which is apparently every night).  How she maintains her good looks without stinking up the place is just another part of cinema magic.  Jessica is mentored by John Mills (Samuel L. Jackson).  For a second there I thought Jackson was going to play an understated version of his usual maniacal self.  I was wrong.  Things take a turn for the strange after Jessica discovers that every man she sleeps with is murdered.  And she keeps having these weird blackouts every night.  The victims wash up on the shore the next day with a single cigarette burn on their hand.  Poor Jessica is haunted by her parents' murder/suicide and wonders...since her father went on a mass-murdering spree before he killed himself
column6: could she too have the "serial killer gene"?  Jessica is paired with Mike Delmarco (Andy Garcia)
column7: an Italian goomba who is alternately creepy
column8: lecherous
column9: and like everyone else in this ridiculous movie
column10: wants to get into her pants.  Mike follows her around an awful lot...could HE be the killer?  Or maybe it's the ex-boyfriend cop
column11: Jimmy Schmidt (Mark Pellegrino).  Or maybe it's...actually
column12: I figured it out in the first ten minutes.  Being something of a true crime fan
column13: and having read a bit on the subject
column14: this entire premise is absurd. You don't wake up one day and become a serial killer; if anyone actually got a good look at the life of a serial killer
column15: it screams DANGER from day one.  Pretty Jessica has none of those problems in her past
column16: except for a vague "suppressed rage" that manifests itself in kinky sex and kicking people in the face.  Her cherubic face shows no signs of hardship
column17: and neither does the rest of her. Although the script wants us to believe she's a haggard cop
column18: the camera is only too happy to zoom in on her rear end.  Not once
column19: but twice.  And it's not a naked rear end either.  So we have a gorgeous female cop who sleeps around
column20: yet there are very few bedroom scenes.  We have a serial killer plot that is connected by red herrings (Who is that lady across the street?  Why does Jessica fiddle with a cigarette but never light it?).  On one hand
column21: the cops are strictly by the book; they make a big deal out of the fact that Jessica kicks a serial killer in the face.  On the other hand
column22: nobody pulls Jessica off the case when she's a prime suspect
column23: nor watch her home when the serial killer is obviously following her around.   Neither sleazy or highbrow
column24: gritty or moralistic

column1: I received the book and CD with hopes to put it to good use for some of my sculpture work. I looked through the book and sent this back without trying the CD because the poses were horrible. The images provide little information that is of any use anatomically or expressively speaking. These poses are so stiff and contrived looking. They are not poses anyone would take in the performance of daily living or activities. Allot of the models are posed so unaturally that they almost look like they are in pain. What kind of results can any artist hope for with such stiff images to reproduce in any fashion? When I pose a nude I consider greatly the position for that particular model. It is no different than selecting the right actor for a part in a play. Some positions are better suited to different individual characters than others. They should be a natural for that part. The positioning of a model should look fluid and natural or should be dynamic in its stress points. Even the poses that are reproducing famous works from the past don't even come close to expressing what the original works have done. The archer pose taken from the great work of the French artist Antoine Bourdelle for example is pathetic. One would gain greater results if they used his sculpture as a reference. At least the concept of harmonious positive and negative spaces and stress
column2: tension
column3: and movement would be better understood. If one is not looking for expression and sensitivity in their work with the human form than maybe this is for them. Maybe they should also consider taking there own video then still capture
column4: of a model on a turntable for reference as I do. It is not that expensive to hire someone for the time that that takes. I hope the originators of this idea considered obtaining the assistance of a qualified professional working in three dimentions for the third edition of virtual pose
