 In this book, Byron York only promises to present the evidence of a vast Left-Wing conspiracy - and that is all he presents.  The discussion here is limited to what left-leaning money has done. Primarily, this amounts to a muckraking castigation of George Soros for pointing out the fascistic tendencies inherent in Bush Administration policies and a denigration of Soros' concerns that the US is now, currently, moving in the same direction as NAZI Germany in the period between the World Wars.  There is no discussion here of any sort of moneyed conspiracy on the other side of the aisle:  no reference to the vast amounts of AmWay (DeVoss family) money available to smear Democrats and moderate Republicans; no reference to the vast amounts of  WalMart (Walton family) or Timkin (Timkin family) money available to do away with a justified and justifiable estate transference tax; and absolutely no reference to the extremely close, and extremely profitable, relationships between George Bush and Ken Lay (Enron) or between George Bush and Jack Abramoff (Republican corruption and treason)

column1: Jim Hightower has become another spokesman for the unhappy left. This limousine liberal who lives in Texas and poses blue collar
column2: is now complaining about "trailer trash rednecks" who have taken his country from him. Since when was this Hightower's country? Yet so many misguided people are giving this book four or five star reviews. Why does this even deserve one star? Just like all the other liberal socialists
column3: Hightower complains about dog-eat-dog economic corporations
column4: the religious right
column5: and capitalism. He has decided not to support Bush in the war on terrorism against Osama bin Laden
column6: Zarkawi and his evil thugs. How dare he do such a thing.  And second
column7: who has stolen this country. NO ONE! I am sick of people saying that Bush stole the election. Rubbish! Bush may have not won the popular vote in the 2000 presidential election but he won the electoral vote. Gore may have won the popular vote but he did not win the electoral vote. The presidential candidate who wins the electoral vote wins the election. That is what our founding fathers decided. Bush did not steal the election.   And about the Republican-controlled Congress. Congress is ruled by Republicans not because they stole their way there. But because they were elected by the people. The American people decided to elect Republicans in Congress. There is no way that the Republicans have stolen the government. It's nonsense!   Please take my advice and don't waste your money on this trashy book. Go to college and get an education in political science. I would only buy this book if I wanted something to destroy. But I would not buy this book because I am not giving Jim Hightower one cent of my money. And also because this book is not worth one cent of my money.

column1: A dilemma suggests two views
column2: a situation where a difficult choice must be made.  The author presents only one view.  Over and over again she tells stories of unhappy adults who were paralyzed by the gifted label and the experience of being pushed by extreme parents.  While I believe these stories and pain are genuine
column3: I cannot understand why Ms. Quart does not speak of other adults who have thrived
column4: those who look back fondly on their gifted education and the enrichments their parents offered. She mentions the current Spelling Bee pronouncer and former champion
column5: Jacques Bailly. In other venues Bailly has frequently spoken how much he believes in academic competition and how much he enjoyed the experience as a child. But here Bailly is only quoted when he registers a complaint.   Stories of positive experiences never are mentioned.  The balance would have made this book live up to the subtitle.  The crucial flaw of the book is that Ms. Quart completely misses the point about gifted children. She speaks of giftedness as something forced on children (or as a classification "bought" by wealthy families.).  Anyone who spends time with a truly gifted child knows that the push comes from the child. No parents of a gifted child would ever credit the Baby Einstein videos for their child's intellectual curiousity.    And gifted children do ask for academic pre-schools and weekly trips to the museum
column6: and very much enjoy spending hours in a small room being quizzed by an adult. (This may not be a good thing
column7: but it is a real thing.)    I expected the book to examine the actual dilemma parents face--how much should the parent nurture the child's requests
column8: and how much should the children be encouraged to "just go out and play"  even though they resist?  By dismissing the key element of the child's desires in this equation
column9: Ms. Quart eliminates any value to her argument.    This book does nothing to help gifted children
column10: nor to guide their parents or teachers.

column1: Washington Post reporter and editor Joel Garreau's Radical Evolution could have been a good introduction to the debate over the future of humanity once the inevitable technological and knowledge explosion known by its prophets as the Singularity occurs. Instead
column2: it's an unconsciously one-sided view of the near and middle future that ignores the more intriguing aspects of the debate.  His starting point is what he calls The Curve
column3: a supposedly looming transcendent upswing in technological and biotechnical achievement that will change human existence in unprecedented ways within the next few decades. The Curve will be a step of a far greater and different type than any we have experienced before
column4: even the major transformations which followed the introductions of the car
column5: the airplane
column6: atomic power and weaponry
column7: the space age
column8: and the Internet.  Garreau first takes a look at what he calls the Heaven scenario
column9: made famous in futurist circles by sf writer Vernor Vinge and inventor Ray Kurzweil. This is the view that the soon-to-appear Curve is Vinge's Singularity
column10: an event that will make us all gods: physically perfect (if we choose to retain physical bodies at all
column11: which will be gauche and unnecessary when we can simply be uploaded as computer software and thus freed from the unpleasantness and messiness of physical existence); practically immortal; and unconstrained by energy requirements from pursuing any endeavor we might want to. This is the glowing Singularity known disparagingly as the Rapture of the Nerds by its doubters.  Garreau interviewed Kurzweil extensively for this book. The most valuable parts of the book are what important figures such as Kurzweil
column12: Bill Joy
column13: and Francis Fukuyama have to say. The problem is that the reader has to cut through a lot of Garreau to get to a little Kurzweil. Garreau himself (his travel ordeals reaching his subjects
column14: where and what he ate and drank on his travels
column15: his opinions on DDT and nuclear fission
column16: and other ramblings) is by far the major personality in the book - an odd choice for a reporter to make.  Garreau next considers the Hell scenario
column17: for an exposition of which he turns to Sun Microsystems former chief scientist Bill Joy
column18: who has made himself wildly unpopular in futurist circles by expressing fears about soon-to-happen Curve-inspired developments such as genetically engineered diseases targeted at specific races or groups
column19: etc. Joy is portrayed as a prophet of doom whose negativity is just as simplistic and wrongheaded as Kurzweil's futurist cheerleading.  So having scorned the too hot and too cold porridges
column20: Garreau turns to the just right one: the Prevail scenario
column21: which involves a soft landing by humanity on the new technologies.  Garreau takes the purple giraffe approach to the debate over The Curve. He first dismisses the exorbitant claims of the purple giraffes' rabid partisans who claim that all our problems will magically disappear once the purple giraffes arrive here. He then looks at the claims of those who would demonize the purple giraffes and who are frantically warning the rest of us about the terrors that the reign of the giraffes will bring. Garreau finds this approach equally one-sided.  So with an air of smug self-congratulation over his Solomonic wisdom
column22: his reasonable Middle Way
column23: his gift for seeing both sides of an issue which most of the rest of us lack
column24: Garreau concludes that the giraffes' arrival won't mean either Heaven or Hell. Sure
column25: they will change everything radically once they get here - ands that will be soon - but we'll muddle through. Problem solved.  Of course
column26: the real question is about the (probably fictitious) giraffes
column27: not about their effects. That's why I say Garreau has missed the more intriguing aspects of the debate. For example
column28: not once in the book proper is Roger Penrose mentioned. There is one brief reference to him in the "For Further Reading" bibliography that follows the book
column29: and that is all. This a glaring omission that grates on anyone who is passingly familiar with futurist issues
column30: but whose absence is probably not noticed by newcomers to these issues. I feel such newcomers have been poorly served by Garreau's book and will gain from it a misleading impression of the status of The Curve
column31: and of computer consciouness and "uploading" of people to software
column32: in genuine scientific circles.  The only very brief consideration which Garreau pays to the idea that we may still simply be in the middle of an era of continual
column33: churning change (as we always have been)
column34: instead of on the cusp of an explosion of a different type of change than we have ever known before
column35: is when he walks around a symposium in Boston and asks attendees why some of them might not be believers in the imminence of The Curve (Garreau's capital letters). When he doesn't receive any knock-down arguments against The Curve
column36: he concludes that his
column37: and the Heaven
column38: Hell
column39: and Prevail proponents' beliefs in it
column40: are beyond question.  This is of course completely backward and unscientific. It is essentially impossible to actively disprove all possible hypotheses one at a time. That is why the burden of proof in scientific circles has always rested on those making the new claims
column41: not on those who are not making them. And the more unprecedented the claims
column42: the heavier the burden of proof is. It's impossible to prove that the purple giraffes don't exist or aren't coming. But you can't conclude from their doubters' inability to disprove them that they're on their way here.  There are many
column43: many flaws in Garreau's writing and reasoning
column44: such as it is. He constantly interjects himself into the story
column45: which is distracting as well as boring. Who really needs to hear about the details of his interviews with his famous subjects? The point is what they have to say
column46: not where they said it or how many layovers Garreau had on his flight to meet them.  The book is permeated with Garreau's aging hippy sensibilities. He quotes from the Whole Earth catalog. He speaks with approval of the Rachel Carson-inspired ban on DDT (a senselessly tragic ban which has killed more human beings than all the dictators throughout history have managed to do). He speaks with fearful hippy horror about nuclear energy
column47: the irrational fear of which has condemned billions to live in poverty and squalor. If he is going to get all of his scientific opinions from the popular culture
column48: I wish he would expose himself to Steven Milloy
column49: Michael Crichton
column50: Roger Penrose
column51: and the more sensible French environmental movement
column52: which correctly sees nuclear energy as the Greenest alternative energy source.  One example of his poor reasoning should suffice: "To get from the formation of the Earth to the first muticellular organisms took perhaps 4 billion years. Getting from tiny organisms to the first mammals took 400 million years. Getting from mammals to the first primitive monkeys took 150 million years. Getting from monkeys to hominid species such as chimpanzees took something like 30 million years. Notice how the pace accelerates?"  But the "pace" hasn't necessarily accelerated if the size of the steps varies greatly. Garreau's landmarks are arbitrary ones
column53: not carefully calibrated equidistant ones. Most scientists
column54: and probably most people on the street
column55: would see the jump from tiny organisms to mammals to be far
column56: far greater than the jump from monkeys to hominids. So the fact that the one step took 400 million years and the other took 30 million years might actually represent a great decrease in the pace of evolution. Or maybe not. But the point is that Garreau tries to interject a mathematical calculation of rate of change to a magazine-quiz style sequence of events.  Garreau misses the chance to really explore the interesting questions of what a new humanity might mean. Religion gets a very brief mention in the last chapter
column57: in the form of some mystical references to Teilhard de Chardin. On the psychological side Garreau does dutifully cite the point that many make that computer consciousness and uploading seem to be an idea whose popularity peaks with men in their 50s
column58: who always put the onset of this new era within the next 20 years (thus granting them immortality). But he doesn't really follow up on this point
column59: or on how the wish may be father to the thought.  He speaks with people who are clearly misfits and partial failures on the human
column61: who clearly have an unhealthy hatred of their own physical beings
column62: but he accepts their "everyone will be on an equal software footing in the future" views as being rational rather than emotional
column63: antihuman rejections of our actual existences in favor of some sterile life as software.  Skip this one unless you already have enough of a background on the subject not to be in danger of being misled by Garreau's biases and omissions. And even then
column64: just skim this for the money quotes from the principals themselves

 I was born too late to remember Tab Hunter's heyday, although I was around for the later generation of teen idols. I've always been interested in the star making machinery and also wondered what happens after stardom fades; I'd also read the recent Henry Willson bio and thought this would be an interesting compliment.   Mostly, I found the book to be a disappointment. It's oddly truncated in places (esp. the last two decades of Hunter's life) and I had to look at the cover to remind myself that this was an as told to". The writing is filled with cliches
column7: wooden prose
column8: and hipster talk from bygone decades. One expects better from the presence of a professional writer. Celebrity bios and autobios usually aren't great literature
column9: but they can have insight
column10: lively prose and create interest even for humdrum lives. The reason for the odd shape of the narrative comes at the end. Someone was planning to do a tell-all scandal book about Hunter and
column11: understandably
column12: he wanted to counter it. As a result
column13: we get a recap of the "Confidential" scandal (and Hunter's side of it) and periodically see unflattering events in Hunter's personal life (e.g.
column14: the pick-up he asked to watch his house and dogs who subsequently sold off his antiques and later sent post cards from various exotic destinations). OTOH
column15: we don't get much depth about how Hunter came to terms with his sexuality or even his Hollywood decline. He sems to have developed sense of humor about being a "once been" (as reflected in his co-starring role with Divine)
column16: but he also seems to delight in name dropping and clearly continued to be a social climber well after his celebrity status had faded. Hunter wants us to see him as a horseman and a "regular" guy
column17: but someone like that wouldn't be carrying on sexual ambiguous relationships with Harry Cohn's widow.   In many ways
column18: important poieces of Hunter's life seem missing. We never get much explanation for his mother's breakdown or how she managed afterward. He speaks fondly of his brother and making occasional contributions to his widow and children
column19: but it seems like he has little real contact with them and the grandchildren's appearence at his mother's funeral seems an afterthought. The most recent years of his life seem puzzling--no sustained sort of income
column20: yet he seems to live relatively well. His partner isn't a major mogul
column21: so you wonder what his source of income might be. There are various places where Hunter suggests that
column22: in his younger days
column23: his personal life was rather indiscreet and lacking in judgment (to be polite)
column24: yet it's not clear how that changed or how really put himself together. The book might have been more entertaining with more "dish" and more scandalous details
column25: but even without that
column26: we could gotten a better picture of who he was. Without the scandal of the 50s
column27: the interest in closeted gay stars
column28: and the legions of once-young fans
column29: this would probably have quickly joined Marilu Henner's autobio in the remainder bin (where it belongs)

column1: John Haught's concern
column2: in his book "Deeper than Darwin" to convince us that science and religion cannot only co-exist
column3: but can co-exist without relegating either the former or the latter to second chair.   He tries to explain this by arguing that the two may well simply be interpretations of the world 'on different levels.' To show how 'different levels' of interpretation are possible
column4: he resorts to metaphor. Just like social issues can be explained in terms of psychology
column5: economics
column6: politics
column7: biology
column8: etc. (each interpretation being right on its own level of explanation) he agues that science and religion can also do this.   But this is where Haught's coherence ends. Nowhere does he give much of an explanation as to what the "deeper" level that religion supposedly gets to. Nowehere does he address the question of how
column9: as the Bible (and other holy books) make historical predictions that can be checked by science (many already disproven)
column10: the two are not at odds.  What's more
column11: Haught gives no reason to suppose that religion occupying a "deeper" realm than science is anything short of the kind of Gouldian "non-overlapping mysteria" he writes so sternly against! If he means something different
column12: he never made it explicit in the book. We are constantly left guessing what "deeper" might actually mean.   Lastly
column13: Haught seems to resort a decent amount to the "god of the gaps" idea that he
column14: again
column15: rails so much agianst in the Intelligent Design movement. Science hasn't explained x
column16: he exclaims
column17: and might not be able to. Therefore
column18: religion should supplant science here. But that is EXACTLY what ID is.   In brief
column19: this book needs to be rethought. The ideas need to be presented more explicitly (rather than every paragraph seeming to be a rehash of the one that came before). Haught never quite gets to the point and (maybe) because of that
column20: fails to offer anything convincing; his only offer is poetic prose.

column1: I have studied the tarot for nearly 5 years and keep an open mind whenever a new book appears on the market.  Edain McCoy
column2: who has written some wonderful New Age material
column3: strikes an off-putting note in this one.  The spreads are certainly imaginative and are perhaps insightful to her own method of tarot interpretation
column4: but convey confusing and ambiguous directions to the reader who is trying to understand her card placements.  In several of her spreads she conveys that a card's placement at a certain point in the spread "may or may not" mean some karmic element at play.  The whole exercise of creating a spread is to pinpoint with a degree of accuracy the situation you wish to define.  Therefore
column5: when a card "may or may not" mean something
column6: that interpretation could significantly change on whether you "may or may not" interpret it that way
column7: leaving the interpreter open to rationalizing a card's meaning.  Tarot cards are intuitive
column8: not rational
column9: and their meanings can best be intuited when their placement is clearly defined without ambiguity   It is difficult to have it both ways and I found working with these spreads difficult.  Imagine doing a Celtic Cross reading and the first position "may or may not" be the root of the issue.  These spreads speak very clearly to the author
column10: but not so to the reader.  I rate it 2 stars for depth and insight into Karma and past lives
column11: but the explanations are too ambiguous.

Let me cite just one example from The Truth Behind Left Behind that makes it a very weak defense of the Left Behind theology. There are many more
column2: but there are space limitations. In Tim LaHaye's Introduction to TBLB
column3: we read: "Jerry [Jenkins] and I have unashamedly taken the position that all prophecy should be interpreted literally whenever possible. We have been guided throughout by the golden rule of interpretation: When the plain sense of Scripture makes common sense
column4: seek no other sense. Take every word at its primary
column5: literal meaning unless the facts of the immediate context clearly indicate otherwise" (7). So shouldn't the reader interpret the weapons of Ezekiel 38-39--bows
column6: arrows
column7: shields
column8: war clubs
column9: spears
column10: horses
column11: and chariots--literally? Not according to our authors. Here's their interpretation from their chapter "The Coming Russian/Islamic Invasion": "Inspired by the Holy Spirit
column12: Ezekiel spoke in language that the people of his day could understand. If he had spoken of MIG-29s
column13: laser-fired missiles
column14: tanks
column15: and assault rifles
column16: this text would have been nonsensical to everyone until the twentieth century" (47). Of course
column17: this is question begging in the extreme. Why would the people in Ezekiel's day need to understand a prophecy if it wasn't meant for them? Why confuse them and us? How do Hitchcock
column18: Ice
column19: and LaHaye KNOW that this is what the Holy Spirit meant? Once the trio makes these ancient weapons of no consequence
column20: they are free to create their own prophetic scenario that can't be tested because it all takes place after Christians are no longer here! Convenient. Consider their words: "The focus clearly is NOT the specific weapons that will be used by these invaders" (47). What happened to "literal interpretation"? The weapons may not be the passage's "focus
column21: but they can't be dismissed as inconsequential to the narrative. The weapons are part of the story from beginning to end, and if taken literally would negate the future scenario outlined by the authors. They claim that Ezek. 38-39 has to be a DISTANT future battle because it takes place in the latter years" (38:8) and the "last days" (38:16). Most biblical scholars
column22: even some dispensationalists
column23: would say that these two time expressions most often mean nothing more than "in the future" or "in the days to come." The same Hebrew phrase is translated as "the days to come" in Num. 24:14
column24: which probably refers to David's victory over Moab. The prophecy of Deut. 31:29
column25: where the same expression is used
column26: came to pass in the period of the Judges (cf. 2:20-21). Here's how one Bible expositor explains it: "this expression does not refer to 'the latter days' (KJV
column27: RSV) in the eschatological sense. . .
column28: but rather to that portion of the future that falls within the scope of the speaker's perspective (cf. Gen. 49:1)." Then one has to wonder why the authors avoid interacting with Edwin M. Yamauchi's Foes of the Northern Frontier which refutes their historical
column29: geographical
column30: and lexographic arguments line by line
column31: and it was written in 1982! Yamauchi is a noted expert on this subject. The Russian invasion premise is only one of the book's many problems. If readers are interested in this topic
column32: I suggest that they pick up a copy of End Times Fiction: A Biblical Consideration of the Left Behind Theology written by me. Since Hitchcock and Ice refer to it several times

column4: neither;  and I suggest such claims are both naive and anthropocentric.  A "realistic" analysis has to begin with a very basic principle of biology:  "Every organism is optimally expressed within the original environment that shaped it".  If you want to get an idea of what is an "optimally expressed" giraffe
column5: for example
column6: you don't look at the animal within a zoo environment ---rather you analyze its behavior within the original "wild environment" of that animal (its Environment of Evolutionary Adaptedness ---E.E.A.).    Now it is naive and anthropocentric to imagine that the human animal is somehow different from every other organism existing on the planet.  As such
column7: to obtain the optimal expression of the human animal
column8: we must follow the same procedure.  One cannot look to our expression within the modern "zoo" in which we have now "contained" ourselves.  Instead
column9: one must look to the "human wild environment" to gain this deeper understanding.  The E.E.A. of the human animal is defined by the hunter-gatherer nomadic extended families of Paleolithic times.  Thus
column10: based the above foundational biological principle
column11: that particular human expression within the E.E.A. must reasonably be defined as the "optimal hunter-gatherer" ---which is a simple rephrasing of the more popular term
column12: the "Nobel Savage".  Even outside this analysis
column13: it is readily apparent that all of us
column14: presently
column15: are "wilted flowers" in comparison to human animals who optimally "blossomed" within the environment that spawned them.  These original humans experienced the best developmental trajectory imaginable.  Every child grew up within an environment keyed to satisfying the very hard-wired needs that that same environment originally designed.    Like any animal growing up in a zoo (well-designed or not) the experience of a child growing up in the modern "human zoo" simply can't compare to the secure base of a non-dysfunctional extended nomadic family that prides itself on ending a child's tears usually within a few seconds (see chapter 8
column16: "The Natural Child"
column17: within THE PALEOLITHIC PRESCRIPTION by Melvin Konner
column18: et.al.).  And Pinker would somehow ignore that such a relatively "ideal" childhood developmnetal environment just might have an especially positive effect on the adult humans thereby produced?  Again
column19: such a view
column20: I maintain
column21: is representative of a naive faith in our current "normality".  My cynicism is
column22: contrariwise
column23: that the modern human is so far removed from what is the optimal human expression that it is now almost hopeless to somehow find our way back.  It's very much as would happen if all the wild tigers were killed and we had to derive what is the optimal expression of that animal
column24: artificially
column25: from a survey of various zoos.  Could we ever re-create the original tiger in all its splendor outside the wild?  And
column26: in turn
column27: can we ever re-create the original optimal human expression
column28: in all its splendor
column29: outside the wild environment of the original savage --- The Nobel Savage?  Dale G.
column30: Clinical Evolutionary Psychologis

 Although I have not read the entire book, The New Soldier, I have read what John Kerry is actually responsible for, i.e., his congressional testimmony (in it's entiirety) and the epilogue that he wrote for the book. Unless you have read the entire congressional testimony, includiing the question and answer session, it is impossible to determine where John Kerry and the other vets were coming from. It was a turbulent time. I was an Air Force Vietnam era" vet and my brother did two tours in-country with the Army. Neither of are heroes. I know many guys from those days who served in Nam. I can tell you that there were two types of guys who went: the majority
column3: who didn't want to be there in the first place; and those who were really gung ho and two weeks on the ground in-couuntry were asking themselves "What the *#*# was I thinking?" You also have to understand how other factors affected many of the vets who returned from the war. Ever heard of The Pentagon Papers? How about The Gulf of Tonkin Affair? These documents
column4: compiled and analysed by a select few Pentagon insiders very close to MacNamara
column5: with the highest clearance
column6: were leaked by an ex Marine captain and trusted advisor by the name of Daniel Elsberg. He was responsible for much of the content of "The Papers". I challenge all of the nay-sayers to do some serious research on their own. Don't just buy into the gruel from either party. Also
column7: I am seeing a lot of speculation about why this book is not widely available. Well
column8: guess what? This coffee table picture book had a very limited printing in the first place. So
column9: what would you expect after thirty-three years? Also
column10: I have seen no actual evidence that Kerry had any control over the publishing of the book or profited from it in any way. I only have a suspicion that the fellow whose name also appears on the cover took some liberties with Kerry's name at a time when Kerry was the "talking head" for the movement.  I have another suspicion. Maybe this entire bru-ha-ha was started by someone who saw an opportunity to fleece a lot of eager idiologues who look for any way to trash Kerry.

column1: Martin endeavors to write a psychological portrait of John Dewey
column2: but falls short. Ironically
column3: the least developed aspect of Dewey's life in this volume is that of Dewey
column4: the psychologist. Dewey was an early member (& president) of the American Psychological Assn. His observation of the reflex arc is still a staple of introductory psychology and the social psychological concepts and models he developed with George Herbert Mead and others prefigured much of the contemporary work in social cognition. Important figures in academic clinical psychology such as George Kelly and Seymour Sarason drew heavily on Dewey's work and Sarason has remained an important champion. No mention is made that Dewey's great friend
column5: James McKeen Catell (a recurring
column6: but little described figure in the book)
column7: was diametrically opposed to Dewey on many important issues in psychology including the roles of inheritance and environment in the development of intelligence and the conception of intelligence
column8: itself. Dewey's ability to remain close to people whose ideas he vigorously opposed was but one of the inspiring aspects of Dewey's character. The shortcomings of this book made me more aware than ever that a full scale biography of Dewey
column9: the psychologist
column10: is needed rather than another biography of Dewey the philosopher
column11: especially a tepid
column12: uneven one like this.   Martin
column13: a humanities professor and a practicing psychonanalyst with an eclectic background occasionally deals with psychiatric disorder in Dewey's life (and the lives of his family members) and trots out some watered down neo-Freudian interpretations of his family life. Yet much of the time
column14: Dewey
column15: the man
column16: remains elusive. Martin makes a number of preposterous claims about Dewey: he tells us that Dewey was "impoverished" for most of his professional life
column17: although his salary was far in excess of that of an ordinary wage earner of his time and his home had servants. We also are told that Dewey was unique among 20th century leftists in his rejection of Marxism and Communism. In fact
column18: Dewey was one of many American leftists who were opposed to Marx and Communism. American socialism probably owes more to the social gospel and non-Marxist political economists like Veblen than to Marx
column19: Lenin
column20: or Stalin. Martin also ignores the vigorous and polemical support Dewey gave to World War I and the strains it caused between Dewey and friends like Jane Addams. Instead
column21: we are told that Dewey was a consistent pacifist driven by a concern that war would undermine democratic values. Remarks like these demonstrate Martin's ignorance of Dewey's life
column22: as well as an ignorance of the social and political environment in which Dewey lived. Much of the discussion of Dewey
column23: the philosopher
column24: is laden with academic philosophy that is insufficiently explained for the educated layperson. Many well-educated people are not familiar with Hegel or the Vienna Circle or only dimly recall these from an introductory course. Many are drawn to Dewey because of his educational ideas or his importance in 20th century demoratic socialism
column25: hence
column26: it is probably not reasonable to expect that readers will automatically be drawn to the various debates within academic philosophy.  This book is an easier read than the dense
column27: often turgid works of Robert Westbrook or Steven Rockefeller. On the other hand
column28: the book lacks the breezy
column29: often humorous
column30: tone of Alan Ryan's biography. Ryan's book is a much better introduction to Dewey---witty and scholarly
column31: yet extremely readable. Although Ryan also focuses on Dewey the philosopher
column32: he is more knowledgable about many aspects of Dewey's life and environment than Martin. He recognizes
column33: for example
column34: the importance and the the deeply flawed character of G. Stanley Hall
column35: who provided Dewey with an introduction to operationism and to developmental psychology. Ryan also points out the limitations of Dewey's sometimes wooly writing. One of the problems with reading Dewey is that Dewey
column36: the philosopher
column37: often requires an understanding of Dewey
column38: the psychologist
column39: or Dewey
column40: the political activist
column41: to understand many of the basic concepts that guided Dewey decades into his effort to develop a coherent worldview of pragmatism. The same problem occurs when one looks at him as psychologist
column42: as a pedagogue or
column43: as a political commentator/activist. He was all of these things in all his professional identities
column44: to some extent. Despite the recent run of Dewey biographies and the renewed interest in pragmatism
column45: there's still more to learn about Dewey. Unfortunately
column46: only well-read afficionados will get much from Martin's book and many may be distracted by it's shortcomings

column1: Dr. Barnard appears in the documentary Super Size Me touting a couple of the ideas in this very book
column2: namely concerning casomorphins in cheese and the supposed opiate effect of chocolate.  I scarcely have enough time to write how awful this book is or how much he misrepresents legitimate research.  First of all
column3: an introduction: Neal Barnard heads the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine.  What is this group?  Mostly
column4: a group of people who are not physicians
column5: but who ARE vegans.  Membership requires nothing but $20- no degree
column6: no research experience
column7: nothing.  A strange policy for an organization calling itself a "Physicians Committee."  This is a political interest group so incompetent that it can't even do its own research.  Do a search on PsychINFO or Medline for anything Barnard has published in scholarly literature
column8: and you will find precious little there.  That's because he's too busy writing books like these for people who don't necessarily have the academic background to know full of it he is.  Take for example the chapter on chocolate in this book.  Barnard asserts that chocolate is addictive
column9: that it has a drug effect on the brain.  He even notes one study where naloxone (a drug that blocks the effect of opiates like heroin)
column10: also blocked the desire for chocolate.  Wow that's pretty interesting stuff!  Barnard didn't mention a few things about this study though.  First of all
column11: there was more than one group tested.  There were normal subjects
column12: and then there were obese bulimics
column13: people who were quite mentally ill.  Barnard doesn't mention that naloxone ONLY HAD AN EFFECT ON THE BULIMICS.  Hey
column14: that might be inconvenient for making his point
column15: so you can see why it's okay for him to mislead you.  This indicates that the blocking effect had nothing to do with chocolate
column16: but it DID have to do with mental illness.  Moreover
column17: they didn't even test chocolate!  They used several popular snack foods that CONTAINED chocolate.  That didn't keep Barnard from zooming in on one single ingredient though
column18: and not mentioning that the people in this study consumed several other things as well.  Another problem with the chocolate chapter is that he cites a study to support his point that no component of chocolate quells cravings quite the way chocolate itself can.  He is referring to a study in which people who crave chocolate ingested either chocolate
column19: a pill containing the pharmacological equivalent of chocolate
column20: or both.  It turns out that ingesting the pill won't satisfy a chocolate craving
column21: you actually have to eat the stuff.  Not to be deterred
column22: even though this study is actually working AGAINST his point
column23: Barnard compares chocolate to nicotine
column24: and writes that smokers are usually not satisfied with just the patch
column25: they need to actually smoke (he doesn't cite any study in support of this assertion).  Well
column26: actually nicotine patches DO reduce cravings for cigarettes
column27: as anyone who does a cursory search of the literature could easily find out.  More than that
column28: what exactly is Barnard concluding here?  That the taste of chocolate has a drug effect through our tongues
column29: but ingesting it has no effect?  Can anyone really read such garbage without laughing?  I could go on
column30: but you can get this book from your library and see the rest of it for yourself.  When in doubt
column31: look up the references he uses to support his points.  Pretty often
column32: you'll find that the articles he refers to really don't say what he makes them out to say.  I thought Super Size Me was a really good film that pointed out what a vested interest many companies have in keeping us unhealthy.  Unfortunately
column33: Dr. Barnard has his own vested interests
column34: and they don't include science or truth

column1: This book is very much oriented around following a certain structure. Syd focuses on describing the three act structure and how to build your screenplay in this structure. While structure definitely is a valuable element
column2: I would not recommend anybody concentrating on it too much
column3: cause the right structure will come in the right way for your script. Much more important elements like how to create rich characters and to enhance your story are not dealt with very much. If creative advice is given it comes across in a quite rigid way
column4: and is lacking foundation. You really feel that Syd didn't gain his knowledge by working as a professional screenwriter
column5: but just by analyzing them. I am missing that kind of sensitivity
column6: creativity and flexibility in his messages to writers that would come from persons who have really written screenplays themselves. To sum it up: The book was not valuable for me
column7: in fact it left me disappointed and a bit frustrated. Other screenwriting books on the contrary have been a very inspiring and motivating source

column1: This third book of the incredibly bloated Mars Trilogy has the fascination of watching a train wreck. There is actually some suspense: how many pages will I skim before something actually happens?  I have to admire the thoroughness with which KSR created a world and made Mars real. He has described every valley
column2: crater
column3: canyon
column4: caldera and dune--and invented a lot of geographical features that aren't there yet
column5: such as rivers and oceans. He has catalogued the lichens
column6: fir forests and alpine vegetation that will someday live on a terraformed Mars. (These details are actually interesting... to a point. But KSR went waaay beyond that point.)   Most of all
column7: he has described the society that will live on Mars. It will be a sort of free-flowing California in which eternally young Martians will flit from tent city to underground commune to coffeehouse to free-sex bathhouse. (I'm still not sure who is paying the bills
column8: growing the food or creating the oxygen for them to breathe. I think a planet of artificial habitats would be tightly controlled
column9: even tyrannical.) They will discuss politics until your face turns blue. Martians will all be utopians and anarchists of various stripes. But when the subject of immigration (from Earth) comes up
column10: watch them turn out as xenophobic as any America-Firster. (yes
column11: there is a group called Mars First.)  Why did I read this series? There is a fascination to the topic. Imagine terraforming and colonizing another planet! I hoped I would learn something. The most interesting chapters were the ones where humans colonize Mercury
column12: Venus
column13: the moons of Jupiter
column14: and even places like Uranus' moon Triton. Imagine humans growing gills and genetically modifying their eyes for the low light of the "sun-deprived moons". That's science fiction! Although I was disappointed that there is not one mention of any sort of extraterrestrial life. The moons and planets are merely real estate to be exploited--making this trilogy a platform for the hubris of mankind.  I also liked the chapters where Nirgal visits Earth. What would a Martian think of Earth? Good stuff there.  As for the rest of the chapters
column15: the editor should have chopped them out with a big scissors. Why oh why does KSR pack hundreds of pages with self-indulgent ramblings
column16: travelogues and descriptions of sailing
column17: hiking
column18: racing
column19: parasailing...ok
column20: KSR is living out his outdoor sports fantasies. But Please! Novels are supposed to have Stuff Happening! Lord of the Rings was the same size as the Mars trilogy... but at least that book had a plot!  Even worse are the passages about the senescence of the First Hundred (now about 220 years old). I can see that space colonization and longevity could go hand in hand. Likewise
column21: the longevity treatment was a plot device so KSR could keep the same characters through the whole trilogy. But why bother? I'm sick of those characters. Nirgal was the only character I really liked. Maya
column22: Ann
column23: Sax etc. are tiresome
column24: whiny old farts and frankly I was glad when they finally started dying off. In fact I can't buy the whole concept of a longevity serum being widely spread through overpopulated Earth. (Which then wants Mars as an immigration safety valve.) A society that would go for such a thing is so stupid
column25: they almost deserve whatever happens to them.  After I waded through this whole mess
column26: the ending was a fizzle. Nothing happened. You will feel as if you are aging 220 years yourself
column27: as you read this series

column4: but trust me it's not.  There is absolutely nothing in this novel that makes you want to keep reading further.

column1: As a follow up of a review in Business week did buy this book which I find good to look at but almost impossible to read as such  Sorr
In Let Freedom Ring
column2: Sean Hannity sends out the subliminal message that he and his writing are about truth
column3: justice
column4: and the American way. Just the title represents everything true and good about him and America. For his five-star reviewers his message reinforces their pre-conceived beliefs and Hannity's words are the validation of those beliefs.  If this was written by a ghost writer
column5: he should have withheld payment. If it wasn't written by a ghostwriter
column6: Hannity should have one for his next attempt at literary hyperbole.  The first chapter is written in a maudlin
column7: "those-were-the-good-old-days" wistfulness of his immigrant grandfather who he describes as an honest man of integrity
column8: and a believer in the American dream. But before you can say "Erin Go Braugh" he is talking about the courage of George W. Bush for standing up to terrorism. Exactly how G.W. does
column9: he doesn't elaborate. How he goes from grandfather to Dubbya is a bit of magic.  Hannity's next trick is to impugn Clinton and Gore as being soft on terrorism. His source for this is
column10: of all people
column11: Dick Morris who knew the Clintons and now works for the Fox Republican Advocacy Network. He quotes Morris who makes such vague statements as "It seemed they were afraid of talking about terrorism
column12: or they seemed to be indifferent to terrorism." These "Morris mind-reads" are conjectural
column13: but Hannity uses them
column14: which he does with impunity.  Let's take a closer look at Hannity's unimpeachable source for a moment. It was Dick Morris who quit the Clintons shortly after the second election. It was Morris who had a penchant for streetwalkers
column15: did some jail time
column16: and entered alcohol rehab. You'd think SH could find a better source if he expects freedom to ring!  But
column17: Hannity doesn't skip a beat. He points out how democrats such as Senators Kerry and Daschle voted against certain defense-spending bills. What he neglects to inform his readers are the reasons they did because of riders that were attached to the bills
column18: or the number of republicans who also voted against the same bills
column19: or the many defense bills that Kerry and Daschle did vote for. He never once advises his reader of the defense spending programs that were killed by Dick Cheney when he was Secretary of Defense. Such deception is called propaganda.  Propaganda is something that Hannity has no compunction using here. This he does in continuing to tell a tale that has long since been debunked. Namely
column20: it is the story of President Clinton being offered Osama bin Laden by the Sudanese government. Again
column21: it's what he doesn't say that misdirects the reader. Sudan made the offer in the hope of having the economic sanctions against them for slave-trading
column22: lifted. However
column23: the FBI determined that the Sudanese were playing us because they had neither the ability nor the intent of handing over bin Laden. The Sudanese also made the offer to Saudi Arabia
column24: but the Saudis had revoked bin Laden's citizenship
column25: and refused to take him.  Benjamin Franklin said "Statistics is a liar." Hannity uses charts for the same purpose. He shows how under Reagan
column26: the army bought over 500 tanks. Under Clinton
column27: the army bought none. This leads one to the assumption that Clinton did nothing for the services. He doesn't mention that the army buys tanks
column28: not presidents. He doesn't mention the army had all the tanks they needed for armored warfare against the Soviet Union that never came. He doesn't mention that the army began changing its warfare strategies which would include more transportable fighting vehicles.  Be grateful that Hannity cannot rewrite famous works of literature as he attempts to do with history. If he could
column29: instead of seeing a dead Captain Ahab being killed by the whale in "Moby Dick
column30: we might just see a grinning captain standing next to a tethered whale with the caption: I caught a fish this big!"  There's something very fishy about his facts
column31: his historical parallels which aren't parallel
column32: and what he chooses to tell you
column33: and what he chooses to leave out.  In this book
column34: he tells whale-sized whoppers!

column1: After using TurboTax couple of years and then using TaxCut for last two years (2005 and 2006 returns) I concluded that TurboTax is much superior software. TaxCut's only advantage is that it is cheaper. If you take out price from the equation
column2: TaxCut is inferior in quality.  - In 2005 TaxCut software there was not PDF output of all the forms. This was pretty silly because after couple of years if I want to access my tax return I am not going to install TaxCut again in my computer and view by return. I would rather have have my tax return available in some widely acceptable format like PDF and then access/distribute whenever I want (I don't keep my documents in hardcopies). So I wrote to H&R Block. This year they added that saving return in PDF file feature available. But unfortunately
column3: this is far from being perfect. It excludes number of important forms - example
column4: IRS form 8853
column5: California Adjustment Schedule 540CA etc. Instead of that it saves numbers of useless worksheet (without any data entered in those worksheets)
column6: same form multiple times.  - Most annoying thing about this software is updating incorrect data. In one form I entered wrong data. While reviewing it I found a problem and went to that specific section to update. But in calculation TaxCut still showed old incorrect number. I just could not make it to use new corrected number. Eventually I had to restart a new return from scratch - just to have an dollar amount corrected.  - In many section useful Helps are missing

column1: This book is awful and out of date. I read a friend's copy and hated it. She attributes agression to schizophrenia
column2: says that psychology has absolutely no place in training animals
column3: and thinks that a fearful dog can be cured by walking it around for an hour and giving it steady pops on the choke chain. She also feels that no dog should be allowed to lick people on the face and that cryptorchidism (where one of the testicles does not descend) causes behavioral problems. Right....  I think perhaps this book was considered alright in the 70's. Now
column4: we *know* that you cannot fix all of a dog's problems simply by popping it with a choke chain. I beleive that training collars to have a place in working with some dogs
column5: but there is no wonder cure for everything and many dogs simply do not need them. They can cause tracheal damage when used improperly (and many
column6: many people use them wrongly
column7: even when being instructed) and what's more they can damage a dog emotionally - making it more fearful than when it started.   She also claims that a timid dog can be made into a happy
column8: confident dog simply by improving its tail carriage (making it run with steady pops on the choke chain). While adopting a confident or happy body position can *help* with a creature's emotional state (like when you feel happier because you're smiling)
column9: it certainly will not *cure* a behavioral problem. Her statement is akin to saying that a depressed person can completely solve their clinical depression simply by smiling for 20 minutes every day.  I agree with her on using confinement (crate training) with puppies
column10: but there are far better and more up to date resources

column1: This is one of those books that appeal to the pretentious.  The author is self-conscious and clever and has obviously written it with literary critics and English teachers and the sort of pseudo-intellectual that hangs out in New York cafes in mind.  The actual story was the last thing on his mind and it shows--the whole thing is a pastiche with what plot there is used to parade his annoying characters (Camus or Satre heroes in Victorian dress) and to make annoying observations (all the last word in philosophy circa 1960 but really dull in 2006).  Nothing could be more contrived than the alternate endings that one must pick from.  The reader does not want to pick an ending
column2: to be truthful
column3: because the author has not made the reader CARE.  I think I will continue reading actual Victorian novels
column4: by the likes of Dickens
column5: Trollope and Eliot rather than ever bothering to re-read this nonsense

column1: After reading five of her novels
column2: I have become a fan of Jodi Picoult. I will admit (and this probably proves that I am a sucker for marketing rather than letting the literature speak for itself) that I've deliberately read all of her best sellers before reading the books that didn't make it on the list.   Initially I liked the book and it kept me reading
column3: though maybe just out of habit. I enjoyed reading about the Amish way of life and the Amish traditions - though it did make me think of that Harrison Ford movie
column4: Witness (circa 1989 or something). I like that she used one first person voice as well as the third person narrative in a well crafted and varied way.  I like that her main character has a powerful job that challenges gender stereotypes by being the morally questionable lawyer. That being said
column5: she doesn't explore this as well as she could. We sort of forget that Ellie has blatantly suppressed evidence and watched as little girls saw their rapist acquitted. Rape
column6: she can defend
column7: but infanticide creates some problems for the notorious defense attorney.   Something about the book bothered me. Maybe I am reading too many of her books too fast but I am seeing a formula here.  - Many of her plots include a court room drama.  - All of her plots feature romance or end with the obvious potential for one.  - Mothers and their powerful (all encompassing
column8: self-sacrificing) love for their children are a theme in all of her books I've read.  - There is usually a "twist" at the end. She's becoming Koontz like in her formulaic predictability and I stopped reading his novels as a teenager.  Most of her books left me content
column9: like I'd eaten a good
column10: hearty meal. However
column11: this book left me hungry and searching for critical reviews to see if others shared my dissatisfaction.   So: - I was unimpressed with the "twist" at the end of this one - I knew "whodunit" about 1/2 of the way through. I was getting bored with that part of the story. The red herrings are too obvious and her suggestions that Katie didn't do it were there from the beginning. She should've stopped the heavy handed attempt to make us question that and just made it known through the 3 person narrative exactly who did the killing or hiding. Then she could have explored that character in depth instead of hiding her and others she wanted you to be suspicious about. Just because we
column12: the readers knew
column13: didn't mean that Ellie had to know - or anyone else for that matter.   - The characters in this novel were a tad generic. I am sorry
column14: I like her
column15: but they were boring.   For instance

column17: I knew they were going to get together after a little drama from Ellie through which Coop - being the quintessential "sensitive ponytail guy" - would wait
column18: albeit in pain. It was just too predictable.  Hannah's ghost; she has a ghost hunter in a later novel and I was a disappointed to see another one. But other than that

column20: Katie
column21: might be crazy and a murderer? Is it to explain why she was so drawn to Adam? Katie being the good Amish girl could only fall for someone who could share her secret ability to see her sister... In a book that is so Amishly pragmatic and logical in every other way makes it so the supernatural element clashes with the rest of the novel. Maybe Hannah's ghost killed Katie's baby or hid it.  I liked the details. The Amish and their daily lives

I had to read this book for an anthropology class taught by an intelligent but uberfeminist professor.  There's an important point in this book that sheds light on its angle: when a Muslim woman wearing a hijab and full coverings was asked how she can walk around in the heat dressed in such a manner she responds something to the effect of "it's not as hot as the fires of hell."  Mernissi is not about to challenge behaviors that are dictated by Islamic scriptures.  Her argument is that the veil and woman's place in the Muslim society are a result of misinterpretation of the scriptures and the hadith.  This is sort of akin to Christians trying to reinterpret creation as an instructive myth after Darwin shattered the fundamentalist vision of creation.  I think Mernissi's approach is generally doomed because
column2: if tradition has failed to maintain the original spirit of a religion
column3: a new analysis almost 1500 years after the fact is almost certainly doomed.  There are too many epistemological problems with diving the original intentions behind a text that is so old.  Mernissi may convince some readers that her radically new interpretation is correct but only at the cost of introducing uncertainty and mistrust in the traditions themselves. Fatally wounding relgious traditions is nearly a fatal wound to the religion itself
column4: and will only cause apathy or fundamentalist overreaction to a challenge of the status quo

column5: and then some -- but getting through this book is a hard slog

column1: "In My Country" is certainly a well meaning film.  Filled with dignity
column2: it means to explore the atrocities committed in the age of Apartheid.  Can justice be served?  Can South Africa move on?  How complicit is the average man?  There are certainly important topics and issues to be dealt with--but rarely have I seen them served up so falsely and dispassionately.    Everything in "In My Country" is a construct.  You've got Juliette Binoche as the face of white shame
column3: Samuel L. Jackson as black rage (though he's an American)
column4: Brendan Gleeson as the villain
column5: Binoche's assistant as the tolerant and understanding African
column6: and her boss as the face of white indifference.  Of course
column7: this story is told from the vantage point of the white lady and the American--as these stories rarely examine issues from the African viewpoint.  Even the testimony of atrocities--which should be a dramatic highpoint--are so staged
column8: so false with the requisite swoons from the audience at "shocking" revelations.  And Binoche is ever present to provide the tears--but as the emotion isn't genuinely developed
column9: I continued to sit there feeling rather empty at the whole exercise.  The Africans are never portrayed as significant indivduals
column10: but as understanding and forgiving souls.  I'd have appreciated a bit of emotional complexity at any point!  If the pairing of Juliette Binoche and Samuel L. Jackson seems an odd match
column11: trust me--it is.  As characters with opposing views
column12: they are put together rather conveniently.  No actual friendship is ever developed
column13: we're just supposed to take it at face value that these two would hang out together.  Well
column14: I didn't believe it for a second.  It was necessary for the plot
column15: so it happened--why bother with actual character development?  There's a more important message to be delivered by having them debate.  Of course
column16: to make matters worse--a romantic entanglement evolves.  There's not much drama there
column17: either
column18: as Binoche seemingly has an indifference to her husband and children.  If she's conflicted about anything
column19: it certainly never shows.  And as if matters aren't bad enough
column20: there's a heavy-handed (and obvious) ending that is supposed to be a revelatory twist.  But I can only say it once more
column21: without bothering to make the characters real--who cares?    A message can only take you so far.  I'd have rather have watched a relevant speech
column22: because no one here was concerned with drama.

column1: I recommend that you peruse the pages of this book at your local library or book store prior to purchasing. The author has compiled 308 pages of supposed facts
column2: ideas
column3: opinions
column4: and "objective illumination." No doubt some of the data provided is true and the first 83 pages engross the reader to the beginning of the history of coffee. Unfortunately the narrative then seems to fall apart not because the information may be false or questionable
column5: but rather the author goes off on tangents which seem to simply fill up the pages. Is Rimbaud's influence on Bob Dylan and Patti Smith necessary in the discussion of coffee?   There comes a point when the reader realizes that the author's writing is more of free flow of thoughts and assumed facts. Add to this the lack of citations and notes (which the author fully acknowledges) and the book becomes a jumble of many figures
column6: dates
column7: places and people that lacks organization.

 I have to agree with some other reviewers. I've seen the original series and I still have all of the episodes of the Showtime version recorded. When I saw this on the shelf as The Complete Series"
column7: I naturally assumed that the discussion of a direct-to-DVD conclusion had finally gotten some results. Instead
column8: it turns out that this should be called "The Incomplete Series". Of course
column9: you have no way of knowing this if you buy it in a store.  There's no indication on the outer packaging of what episodes are included. No indication that it ends prematurely and no mention that the series was cancelled before the conclusion of the storyline.   This show was a single continuous storyline with numerous highly connected sub-plots. Pretty much all of them are left hanging. Unless you want to join a large community of frustrated fans who are unlikely to ever receive any sort of closure

column1: Buddhist math? C'mon.  First
column2: let me say that fuzzy logic and fuzzy arithmetic are great tools. They're valued parts of the 'soft logic' kit that includes probability
column3: interval arithmetic
column4: Bayesian and Markov networks
column5: and lots of other good stuff. Fuzziness involves many of the formal techniques used in probability and elsewhere
column6: and gives a useful
column7: alternative view of the systems it addresses.  The basic fuzzy idea is that most descriptions involve shades of gray
column8: that few systems really match the black/white
column9: on/off
column10: either/or duality of standard formal logic. That's fine
column11: I can get along with that quite well.   My problem
column12: though
column13: is that Kosko presents the fuzzy world-view vs. the traditional or "scientific" in exactly the black and white terms that he rejects. He also argues that fuzziness describes the world more effectively than "scientific" terms
column14: that the rules of arithmetic
column15: probability
column16: and calculus are just games. They are played for their internal consistency
column17: not because differentiation or factorials occur in nature.  That's true
column18: and as a heavy math user I know enough to distinguish my models from reality. Two facts remain
column19: though. First
column20: the models very often do describe reality in ways that can be checked easily enough: the bridge doesn't fall down and the TV receives its signal. Both happen because the bad old exact arithmetic has some kind of correspondence (no
column21: I don't know what) to the real world
column22: giving real ability to predict real results. Second
column23: fuzzy logic and fuzzy arithmetic are themselves mathematical formalisms
column24: games like all the others. Once you get past the gee-whiz stage
column25: there is mathematical content as rigorous as in any other field of study. It's not either/or
column26: it's very often a different way to interpret the same self-consistent games people have played for years. It adds interesting rules to the game.  The great thing is that you really can use the new interpretations and tools along with the old ones. Fuzziness doesn't demolish the old structures
column27: it bolsters them and adds capacity.   And you can get all these benefits without shrink-wrapped
column28: bite-sized pieces of Eastern philosophy.  //wiredweir

column1: On the surface
column2: John Waters has it all -- a loving wife
column3: a beautiful child
column4: a successful business -- but appearances are deceiving. His marriage is in trouble
column5: his business is under investigation by a federal agency
column6: and his business partner has made questionable financial decisions which jeopardize everyone's future. Into this mix wanders Eve Sumner
column7: a stunningly attractive woman who makes it abundantly obvious she's chosen Waters as her next conquest. However
column8: appearances are again deceiving
column9: because Eve Sumner claims she is actually Mallory Chandler
column10: Waters' first great love.  Funny thing
column11: though: Mallory Chandler died ten years previously.  So who is this woman? And how does she know things only Mallory should know?  In an effort to discover the truth
column12: Waters finds himself involved in an affair that quickly turns dangerous
column13: as Eve/Mallory displays the same obsessive behavior that destroyed Waters' love for Mallory twenty years before.  This novel requires a major suspension of disbelief for its critical plot device: transmigration of a soul. Once the reader accepts that
column14: however
column15: the story moves along quickly and works well within its preposterous premise. Waters flails and fumbles and does his best to fix the mess he's made by getting involved with Eve/Mallory
column16: even as she seems to be setting him up for a murder charge. His desperation and fear are palpable
column17: and certainly mitigate his at times wrong-headed choices. I truly enjoyed this story
column18: that is
column19: until I read the final pages.  The final plot twist
column20: which I won't reveal here
column21: is so farfetched
column22: even within the confines of a plot that stretches suspension of disbelief to its outermost limit
column23: as to spoil all the good trashiness that preceded it. I read the last few pages and threw the book across the room. I felt cheated. I think Mr. Iles wrote himself into a corner and couldn't think of any other way to give the reader a happy ending. Gah.  Never have I been so disappointed with a novel's resolution.  Oh
column24: and the frequent references to a novel written by a character within this novel which happens to have the same title as a novel written by Iles bugged me too.  Gah.  Oh. Go ahead and read the story. Just rewrite the ending in your own head. I did

column1: Last night I listened to the whole CD on Clear Channel.  (Everyone should deliberately hold off on buying a disc until they hear every song or at least a sample of every song. column2: I Told You So
column3: and Got It Right This Time.  God Made Woman was God awful.  Richard Marx had attested that Everybody rose above Better Life in quality
column4: but I think it was lackluster in relation to Better Life.  Sorry Richard Marx fans
column5: but this song was more Marx than Urban.  Not in a good way either.  The rest of the songs were drowned in heavy production
column6: bland melodies
column7: needless bridges
column8: and repetitive lyrics.  I really expected more from Keith.  I was hoping for more guitar
column9: rather than keyboard and piano.  I was also expecting it to sound like country
column10: instead of saccharine laden pop.  I'm going to stick with iTunes for the tracks I do like and leave the rest by the wayside.  I'm not paying for the whole disc.  I wouldn't want anyone to have to pay full price for this record.     Music is an experimental business
column11: much like movie making or any other type of media art.  It's a gamble really.  Sometimes you can release the best disc of your career.  An album that has one hit after another
column12: with unlimited radio and television airplay.  Then sometimes you can release a dud.  I'm sure in Keith Urban's case
column13: that dud will still earn him a multi-platinum CD
column14: along with all the acoutrements of a "quality" record.  He has a hardcore mob of fans that will love anything that Urban produces
column15: much like Richard Marx. Of course
column16: these days
column17: Urban beats Marx in sales of his own discs
column18: but both artists stay in the same realm of revenue as far as being accomplished songwriters.  You can't dispute the fact that both musicians are very talented in that area.  I have to watch my words though
column19: or some of the fans may want to verbally break my legs when I mention anything less than a perfect review of either Marx or Urban.  LOL!  (Sometimes there is no way to verbalize something so ridiculously funny.  So chatspeak has to suffice.)  Does this mean there is no accounting for taste?  Maybe.  After I wrote this review
column20: I read similar reviews in the Boston Globe
column21: and the Daily News.  You have to look at reviews objectively
column22: but I think that I'm not the only one who sees the flaws.  Yet there is a contrast to those poor reviews.  Billboard
column23: one of the most influential music publications in the world
column24: gave it a rave review.  They said that
column25: "it was fitting that (Keith Urban) ended the record with Got It Right This Time."  Now don't get all upset.  I still love the majority of Mr. Urban's catalogue.  (Marx's too!)  Putting aside the fact that I am a big fan of his work
column26: I just think that Keith Urban's record went too far away from country.  Hopefully any good and bad reviews that he receives from this effort will help in the creation of his next disc.    (You may wonder why I included Richard Marx in relation to this subject

column1: Overall

column5: however

column7: often sounding as if Mr. Komisar decided to insert various triumphs in his life whenever he felt like it.  Furthermore

column9: but prompts put in by Komisar to respond to the questions he wanted answered.  In his interactions with them
column10: Komisar walked an unhealthy line between humility and arrogance
column11: presenting himself as a sort of low-key person who thinks outside the box
column12: yet is always right on everything and draws reverence from those around him.  At times
column13: I wondered whether this book was more of a teaching tool or a testament to his own greatness.      I found his main message to be useful

column16: however

column18: "Mr. Komisar
column19: practice what you preach!"  Furthermore
column20: I can think of so many ways that his theory is wrong.  Sometimes
column21: the best businessman is one who has passion for what he/she is doing

column1: I ordered this book with high hopes.  The reviews led me to believe it offered concrete suggestions for pressing problems.  It just isn't so.  This book seems to be primarily for people who want to rationalize the status quo: others suffer for reasons you can't influence
column2: you are a good person for just talking about problems in the world while doing nothing about them
column3: etc.  If you believe people who suffer get what they deserve or are simply a side-effect of the glorious free market then this book will be laughable to you.  If you believe making the world better for everyone is the primary obligation for members of "good society" then this book will be disappointing to you.  Etzioni mouths some standard platitudes
column4: for example that we need universal health care
column5: but inevitably either guts his statements by describing that he means something entirely different from what is understood by those statements or he backpedals furiously.  Sometimes he does both at once.  Here's a prime example
column6: again regarding health care: "However
column7: securing everyone a rich basic minimum of health care as a start should no longer be delayed if we seriously seek to move toward a good society".  What exactly is the oxymoronic "rich basic minimum" to which he refers?  We just don't know
column8: and subsequent pages are no help.  As Etzioni reminds us often
column9: this is something for further discussion (outside his book
column10: of course) and dialogue.  From the merely comical "rich basic minimum"
column11: we move to the stunningly wrongheaded comment that "there is a profound tension between treating people as ends and as a source of profit".  There is nothing profound about this
column12: nor is there tension except when the market is allowed to have its way with few controls.  Rather than taking the much more "people as ends" focused view that the market must serve society and must be constrained when it fails in that role
column13: Etzioni asks us to believe that we shouldn't always treat other people as people - sometimes they really are commodities to be bought and sold for money.  Perhaps I am especially disappointed because I had such high hopes for this book.  I'm sticking with Amartya Sen and Wendell Berry because even if I don't always agree with them
column14: I can always tell that they care deeply for others and want to offer suggestions for improving the world
column15: not empty cliches

column4: I really wanted to use my real name

column8: and thus I felt it a bit unfair/dangerous to my employer to critique any book in a public forum. (because you can google my name and find out where I work) I still feel that way
column9: so I will try to convince you I have no agenda as easily as I can as follows: 1) My argument was simply that you should VERY carefully read the table of contents
column10: including the page numbers.  Dr. Mathews is quite right that this type of book will appeal to some people
column11: just that in my humble opinion I hope those people are not put in charge of securing VoIP
column12: because this book doesn't do it. (see below why) 2) I did not slam the authors in person or capabilities - I slammed the book they wrote.  This book was published fairly recently (6 months ago)
column13: and this book is written from a VoIP perspective of several years ago
column14: in my opinion.  It is missing tons
column15: and contains lots of frankly irrelevant content to the subject.  If the title of the book "VoIP Security" is not meant to actually mean this is a book about VoIP Security
column16: then I guess I don't understand what book titles are for.  The back cover even says "This book will teach you how to plan for and implement VoIP security solutions...".  I am taking issue with that statement
column17: not the authors personally. 3) I think some people may like the book
column18: because they are not already experts in VoIP security and thus don't know what they're missing.  I believe I am pretty close to an expert.  I was looking for a book I could recommend to my customers and colleagues who are not. 4) Dr. Mathews says "It addresses the protocol specifics
column19: the technical issues
column20: and the security options surrounding the protocol."  I think that it addresses them if you don't know what they really are.  I will tell you what I know is missing from this book: a) TLS.  Much of the VoIP industry believes TLS to be the future panacea for VoIP service security. (it's not used much today
column21: but many are moving that way)  That belief is true for eavesdropping protection/privacy
column22: and server-side authentication.  It is not true for DoS/DDoS attack protection
column23: or user-side authentication.  It is also not true for fraud prevention
column24: and it adds many scalability/performance issues.  The reasons for that
column25: how SIP over TLS works at a protocol level
column26: and more interestingly the security issues around it are not addressed in this book.  That should be a whole chapter. As a side note
column27: they say TLS requires TCP
column28: which was true until the draft for DTLS came out for TLS over UDP
column29: which has received much publicity in the VoIP security world.  It came out in 2003 - long before this book was finished.  b) IPSec.  The 3GPP/IMS world and some inter-carrier VoIP peering uses IPSec to secure VoIP
column30: which like TLS only provides some security features/benefits but not others.  Used by enterprises it also adds latency to RTP (because they use it in tunnel mode over TCP).  I give the authors some credit - they did spend 10 pages on the VPN issues with IPsec (but it's not exactly how 3GPP uses it).  I still think this topic should be a whole chapter. c) SRTP.  How SRTP is performed
column31: from a protocol level and hardware/software level
column32: leaves much to be desired.  There is in fact much debate in the industry if it is needed at all
column33: how it can be managed
column34: how CALEA can be supported with it
column35: etc.  SRTP also does not protect the gateways/phones
column36: and the implementation of it is the critical piece as to whether it's any good at all.  The authors spend a couple pages on it - I would probably spend at least half a chapter on it - perhaps by removing the big section on how codecs work (which has virtually no relevance to VoIP security compared to this list).  The fact there are different codecs is important
column37: but not the formulas for the plot curves of A-law and u-LAw! d) S/MIME.  Some voip products do it
column38: but most don't
column39: and it breaks some things.  Again
column40: the protocol and security issues with S/MIME are not covered in much detail in this book. (although it's covered over at least a few pages
column41: just not enough I think)  e) VoIP Firewalls.  One simply cannot lump that into one group.  The differences in feature/architecture/functionality between categories of friewalls (not to mention models/brands)
column42: and how you use VoIP with them
column43: is so critical I'm literally shocked there isn't a ton more detail on this.  Look at other security books for data.  There are entire books about just a particular firewall brand. (not that this book should get to that level of detail) f) STUN/TURN/ICE.  They are mentioned briefly
column44: but really these technologies/protocols are another pandora's box of security issues
column45: and should be addressed if crossing NAT's is at all useful for you.  Likewise
column46: Session Border Controllers are mentioned briefly in this book
column47: but they are considered by most to be one of the fundamental pieces in VoIP security.  ok
column48: enough time spent.  I'm sorry for the length of this reply.  Again
