This movie has such wonderful reviews from both professional critics and Amazon customers that I was expecting great things. While I agree the acting (especially the girls playing Christy and Ariel) is excellent the story is just too implausible and I got that impression from the minute we see the family crossing from Canada to the US (yes they are Irish but for some reason they have to sneak in to the US from Canada). Anyway why on earth would an apparently intelligent couple enter the US with their two kids illegally
column2: without jobs or much money to settle in the most expensive city in the country?  I know the dad is an actor but couldn't he have settled the family in one of the less expensive boroughs and taken the subway in to Manhattan? The mom is a teacher but can't find a job but no wonder if they are in the country illegally. Yet there is money for private school
column3: fixing up the dump of an apartment

column6: the new baby and Frankie is very heavy handed. Though the film is told through the oldest daughter's eyes  because of several scenes and elements the movie is not suited at all to children.  And there are also several scenes that are really not connected with the oldest daughter at all.   Maybe if I had taken it more as a fable I would have "gotten" this movie more but I was expecting a straight forward drama and was disappointed.

column8: Agetta

column18: is not a bad thing -- J.R.R. Tolkien

column20: without building up much momentum.        One of the biggest problems is the way Taylor handles the fantastical elements of his book. Okay
column21: there are weird creatures. Most fantasy books have those. But his seem to just be thrown into the mix for no apparent reason. His handling of superstition and science in the 1700s is sketchy at best

 While the premise of this book is intriguing the delivery was disappointing at best. The analogies between golf and business were  trite and not very illustrative.  Good analogies between golf and business process analysis do exist, such as the way that statistical analysis and feedback loops are used by pros to reduce variation in shot accuracy and eliminate wasted motion in their swings. Shots into bunkers represent waste" is about as sophisticated as this book gets.

column1: I am pretty shocked at how many people liked this book. This is the fifth Hannah Swensen mystery I've read and was a major disapointment for me. First of all
column2: there were just WAY too many characters to keep up with. Following Hannah as she basically just questions every single person she can think of gets pretty boring. Another major issue for me was that Hannah seemed very annoying in this book. She seemed like a complete know-it-all and the fact that she'll make out with one guy and then turn around and make out with another. And don't you find it ironic that a book whose main character is constantly correcting everyone has so many grammatical errors and typos

column1: (review of ADAM'S FALLACY - A GUIDE TO ECONOMIC THEOLOGY by Duncan K. Foley
column2: The Belknap  Press of Harvard University Press
column3: Cambridge Massachusetts
column4: 2006  pp. xvi-265)  review by  WALLACE F. SMITH
column5: WALNUT CREEK
column6: CA  Adam Smith (1723-90)
column7: a Scotsman
column8: espoused liberty. He saw American colonists repudiate their king. He saw French commoners execute king and nobles in the name of "Liberty
column9: Equality and Fraternity."  The book he published in 1776
column10: THE WEALTH OF NATIONS
column11: liberated human economic life around the globe. Trade became free.  Before that privileged classes dictated what was to be produced
column12: precisely how
column13: who was to benefit and at what prices. Workers were bound to their workplace
column14: like galley slaves
column15: and all their activities rigidly controlled.  Progress was thwarted.  People raised arms against tyrants. Adam Smith gave revolution a gospel. The world changed forever.  Economic actvity can and will  manage itself.  Producers make what consumers are willing to buy; prices must meet the needs of factors of production (land
column16: labor and capital). Collective enterprise is driven by profit and expands cumulatively.  Smith had faith in this sytem.  Followers argued specifics and discovered flaws. David Ricardo demonstrated the efficiency of importing
column17: tax free what a nation's own resources limit. Swiss mathematician Euler proved that paying every factor of production - land
column18: labor and capital - their respective "marginal"  worth - incremental  effects on output - equitably distributes all income.  But land and capital are "property" meaning legal rights. A moral issue arises - what is "property"? For a thousand years polemicists asserted the right of "society" to enjoy what property earns. This is called "socialism." Propertied classes denounce socialism and use force against it.  Adam Smith had very brave insight but not logical discipline (math). Pseudo scholars such as Duncan Foley preach sermons about choice - left-wing socialism versus right-wing fascism. The tragedy of Russia shows that with the best of intentions modern economic life is too complex for command economics.  Author Foley has published very muddle-headed rambling on the subject. To wit:"... there is no way to determine the contribution to production of any one input ..."  p. 164. Duncan is unaware that Euler did just that; Samuelson's immensely popular textbook lays out the mysteries of production functions - Euler's theorem. The secret lies in partial derivatives.  Calculus is a prerequisite for any meaninful economics course

column1: I am 40 years old and have been a sci-fi fan for at least 24 years. I read an average of 2-3 books per week (not all sci-fi). I held off reading Sirens because I like to read humorous sci-fi on vacations (just my quirk). I can honestly say I was extremely dissappointed in this story
column2: and I think most real sci-fi fans will be as well. I think people are afraid to criticize this book anymore because it is so widely praised
column3: but if they were honest
column4: it's a mixed bag at best.  Some spoilers ahead...be warned.  Vonnegut makes a lot of promises early on in this novel that he never fulfills. The experience becomes much ado about nothing. I understand some people are absolutely engaged by Vonnegut's exploration of the human condition and the pathos involved
column5: but it all came off trite to me. There are other novels by Herbert and Heinlein that do it much better. Deserting main charachters on park benches to die isn't really exploring the human condition as much as admitting you led the reader down a path with no destination.    His fade-in
column6: fade-out antoginist really is lacking in depth. He's a stereotypical WASP we are supposed to like because he is destroying all those dogmatic religions by creating a new...(suprise) a new dogmatic religion. It's like Vonnegut thinks he's the only one to ever conclude that religion might be holding back humanity
column7: but then has no idea how to fix it and in the end sticks to convention. This plot point ends up a huge wash to me.  Of course the most annoying plot point right on top of the cake is the promise of this magical destination Titan and the title's Sirens. We are shown their picture
column8: which is supposed to be beauty beyond compare
column9: but never a description. In the end they are just statues on a barren landscape
column10: yet another cop-out.   In the end we discover that the point of humanity's entire maddening history has been to provide a part for a broken alien spaceship. Of course
column11: one would expect that part to be complicated enough that it required such manipulation and effort. One might even suspect that it was too hard for a single alien to make. Not here. It's hard to suspend disbelief about a piece of ribbon steel 1 inch wide and 6 inches long with a square hole punched in it. It apparently required 20
column12: 000 years of human history to produce it
column13: instead of the alien using a coke can or some analog on his elaborate ship.  There are some creative bits to this story. The trip to Mercury definitely was well done. Unfortunately the humor and creativity feel like unrelated bits strung together along one of the worst plot lines ever created. I really wanted to like this book. I really wanted to recommend it. I can't. If you like books with solid plots
column14: some sci-fi

column16: some philosophy about the human condition
column17: and interesting charachters
column18: go read Stranger in a Strange Land again.

column1: Of all the books which dominated the discussion of analytic philosophy in the 90s
column2: John McDowell's *Mind and World* was actually the one which most nearly brought home the prize of great philosophy without naughty bits: and this most nearly in the form of an inversion of Lukacs
column3: "Reification and the Consciousness of the Professoriat".  His early Oxgaffes having been forgotten
column4: McDowell was here free to offer an "unpolitical" account of contemporary thought drawing heavily from classic works.  But if the result is not quite Robert Brandom's linguistic Leninism
column5: the reader ends up getting a story about "who's to be master" that has a little too much excitement squeezed into McDowell's oscillating queries.  Much as Brandom makes a hash of the relationship between formal semantics and "inferentialism"
column6: McDowell's account of Hegel's relationship to *Bildung* does not even crib Gadamer's "historically effective consciousness" as a corrective to his "uncritical" eudaemonism (those interested in Hegel's intellectual relationship to Aristotle would do well to look at Alfredo Ferrarin's book instead) -- and the excitement one is  forever waiting on with respect to Sellars is pressed into service for a thoroughly unserviceable treatment of Hegel's remark "in thinking
column7: I am free
column8: because I am not in an other" -- very much the product of Stoic philosophy
column9: and very much militating against the "therapeutic" story about non-conceptual content directly following (with apologies rendered to Peacocke for his rather more serviceable story).   Is any of this that objectionable?  No
column10: and although McDowell's work was very much "in a vogue" for a while (i.e.
column11: served upon you according to his lecture specifications) this (as well as his essays) is fine reading concerning stylistics with respect to thoughts of the form "whereof we cannot speak..."  But none of it is as thoroughly "Wittgensteinian" as presented
column12: and if McDowell can still coherently be accused of rendering a disservice to that philosopher this heavily syncretist work must be counted as one such.  I expect this is not the case
column13: however
column14: and as such cannot in good conscience recommend this book to interested readers: if you are in the grip of a worry
column15: perhaps you should stay there
column16: and if you feel differently perhaps being notified of your pseudo-problems will not help overmuch.  Something of a lecture-stuffer

column7: and the Cadogan Yucatan & Mayan Mexico. In the past I've also used the frustrating Moon guide and weak Lonely Planet).   Of the 4 guides
column8: each quite different in focus and style
column9: I found "Hidden Cancun and the Yucatan" undoubtedly the most annoying and rate it 2 stars. Perhaps it's a bit stingy with the stars - other people have given it 5 stars
column10: but with several other guides to compare it to
column11: it's weaknesses became more and more apparent. Neither a good detailed history of the region nor particularly interesting or detailed in describing towns
column12: cities and Mayan sites. The "Cadogan Yucatan & Mayan Mexico" though slightly larger and heavier was in a different league and perhaps the best book on the region for these purposes but also immensely enjoyable and readable with many excellent recommendations for food and accommodation.  The format "Hidden Cancun and the Yucatan" (a largish thick paperback seems) to suggest the same purpose but I think did a mediocre haphazard job. Even as a reference guide it fails to deliver with a pathetic lack of photographs and maps - those provided were as good as useless for reference (instead The rough Guide and Top 10 were infinitely superior and genuinely useful). By contrast
column13: the reference information in "Hidden" is so poorly layed out and not conveniently accessible - excuse the pun
column14: but without much better visuals
column15: layout and concise text
column16: "Hidden" does a good job of hiding it's information - not good when one is on the fly. For example different towns and villages were blended in a linear text dictated by routes (for example drivngh from Cancun to Playa del Carmen)
column17: so information for a given place you might want to visit might start at the bottom of a left page and run over the next without the name place ever making it to the top of the page. Places to dine
column18: stay or shop would haphazardly fall wherever the text put them
column19: never in sections starting a page top or in any consistent structural order. Perhaps the idea was to list everything in a rambling travelogue
column20: place drifting into place running north to south
column21: east to west
column22: broken down by region. I just thought it made the book frustratingly inflexible and to idiosyncratic.   By the way
column23: why on earth produce a guide book for use in the tropics on cheap uncoated paper? Perhaps because they publishers decided to give the traveler only 4 pages of photographs. This book really absorbed moisture and seemed to get heavier and heavier! I know that sounds silly but simple details like trying to turn a page when they seem to cling together in the humidity added to my wondering about the wisdom behind this book.   The 'hidden" part
column24: the supposed trump card of this guide is of dubious merit. The "hidden" discoveries were few and far between
column25: disappointing on the odd occasion I checked them out (I stopped after realizing that they weren't so special) and just not strong enough to hang the (title) concept of a travel book (series). Indeed  I often found the 2004 version very dated and in the course of traveling
column26: made far more interesting discoveries of my own. By contrast
column27: "The Rough Guide" and "Top 10"
column28: both thin compact picture filled books with plenty of good maps and guides also contained far more recommendations of places to eat
column29: stay and visit in a concise
column30: coherent well layed out and easier to navigate manner that "Hidden Cancun & Yucatan" lacks. My girlfrined and I felt that they both immensely increased our interest in visiting various restaurants
column31: Mayan sites
column32: colonial towns
column33: beaches
column34: churches etc... In conjunction with the "Cadogan Yucatan" we were very well informed culturally
column35: historically
column36: visually and geographically. The 2 small pocket guides were excellent for walking about with when we left "Cadogan" and "Hidden" in the car - though we'd often bring "Cadogan" with us anyway because we couldn't stop reading it.   Another thing that I found grating and contrary to the "hidden" concept was the authors occasional statements of his personal preferences in side bars. Normally it's great to get another traveler's insights
column37: but personally I found the actual comments annoying. For example
column38: I strongly question how a writer appealing to people seeking out hidden and undiscovered corners of the Yucatan can suggest that Palya del Carmen's beach is his favorite on the Mayan Riviera. Maybe it was different when he was last there a couple of years ago. Another dated reference (or just downright crass) was his reference to the actual pueblo of Tulum as "a drab eye-blink off the highway
column39: with a few stores
column40: a taco shop and a palapa-roofed church". Instead we are treated to the authors name dropping of personalities he's rubbed shoulders with at Maya Tulum
column41: a chic place on the beach. In fact the pueblo of Tulum is a fast growing little town with an impressively paved main street with many interesting shops including a large "Misik Artesanias" (another smaller one is on the beach) and the adjoining palapa-roofed "Charlie's". There are a couple of big bank branches (HSBC and Banamex) with ATM machines
column42: a couple of laundromats
column43: an excellent large supermarket at the entrance to town (opposite the road down to the beach). Get my point? This is a fast growing town that is trying to make itself interesting and attractive without making itself into another souless eurotrash hole like Palaye del Carmen. How long ago did Richard Harris write his review? Is he aware that a 4 lane road is being constructed between Tulum and Coba (and onto Valladolid) and an international airport in pre-construction there? This may be a particularly dramatic place for change but my point is that the book was often out of date and unfocused

column1: The "statistics" this book cites are more than misleading and do not reflect even a moderatly informed scientific opinion.  Schzophrenia and bipolar disorder have certainly been proven to be caused by brain abnormalities as have many other illnesses. To opine that psychiatry and successful treatment of these life-threatening conditions are some sort of huge hoax is akin to claiming that there's no such thing as mental illness. The medications available to treat major mental illness can be the difference between a happy
column2: productive life
column3: and a life of debilitating violence
column4: despair
column5: and death.  The authors' child-like descriptions of medical testing and - believe it or not - their entire section describing the personality of all pschiatrists (they are evidently all controlling
column6: evil powermongers) - only serve to reinforce the authors' idiocy. Certainly
column7: medical professionals have at times been responsible for misprescribing drugs - but to conclude that all psychopharmaceuticals are evil or that all psychiatrists are frauds is laughable.  I wonder if anyone's thought of suing the authors for the damage the book's lies may have caused in their own or a loved one's life

column1: This book is complete rubbish. It is a scathing indictment of our university system and an argument against tenor. column1: My son is 5 years old and a big fan of pirates toys. When I saw the box I was extremely impressed with the display. The box advised that the toy was for kids 6 and older.   The ship is a "Lego" type structure requiring some assembly. As I have had prior experience assembling Lego models I felt I was up to the task. What I did learn is this definitely isn't the same quality as a Lego product as the pieces would not lock together. Upon assembling the main structure
column2: the pieces would snap out of place with out warning.   After about 20 minutes of stress trying to keep the structure intact during the assembly process
column3: I decided it was time to take a break. Returned 20 minutes later
column4: and the portion of the structure that I was able to lock the pieces together had again started to fall-apart.  I proceeded to shove the pieces back in the box and rush it back to the department store for a refund.   Maybe I have the patience of a 6 year old
column5: but I can't see my 5 year old enjoying playing with a toy which collapses when moved.   Pros: Box and packaging is impressive. The look and feel of the pieces is very detailed   Cons Instructions could be clearer. Although the Lego concept isn't difficult
column6: a lot of trial and error is required.  Quality control is not what I'm used to. Son never had a chance to play with this item as it was never assembled.  I replaced it with the playmobil pirate ship and my son has really enjoyed playing with this product

column1: I am in a Master's program in Science and Religion. The facts are
column2: White was the first president of Cornell University. Cornell was the first secular institution of higher learning in the US. White was resisted because of his desire to make the University purely secular; in response he wrote this polemic specifically against religion. He misrepresents history on many counts. For example
column3: he quotes the mythical account of Columbus' alleged conversation with Ferdinand and Isabella about sailing to the New World to show the earth is round. I was taught that myth in grade school
column4: only realizing in the last few months that this is a fable. Washington Irving is the one that made the story up about Columbus
column5: White quoted him
column6: and the fable has been perpetrated since. White has been used to perpetuate the myth that the Christian Church held that the earth is flat
column7: which is again completely false. No serious historian of science today accepts the conflict thesis between science and religion
column8: and no one in the field accepts White as anything more than historical curiosity. While the book might inflame people already predisposed to attack religion
column9: serious investigators about the relationships between science and religion would do better to read real historians such as John Hedley Brooke
column10: David Lindbergh and Ronald Numbers
column11: or Dennis Danielson. The nuances in historical episodes such as the Galileo affair
column12: who by the way was never tortured
column13: are much more complex than the simplistic parrot talk usually perpetuated about these subjects.

column1: I expected to find this book stimulating and informative
column2: but came away feeling that Dennett is vastly overrated and quite ordinary in his thought process
column3: logical skills
column4: and writing.  This book does not explain or offer a theory on -- as its title promises -- what consciousness is; it merely offers a lot of random observations on and stories about consciousness.  Dennett seems to start everything he writes somewhere in the middle of a conversation he has been having with himself; he doesn't know how to properly introduce a topic to the reader.  He begins the book not with an overview of his subject or a presentation of a thesis
column5: but with a chapter on hallucinations -- a very specific area of consciousness.  I indulged it with the expectation that it would provide an entry point into a broader argument he wished to advance; instead it was just the first in a random string of narratives.    I suggest that in lieu of Dennett's writings on consciousness
column6: one read John Searle or Robert Ornstein.  Or if you want an engaging
column7: conversational style of writing on the subject
column8: look into Oliver Sacks.

column1: Dragonlance is my favorite campaign setting. I have read the Dragonlance Campaign Setting d20 manual
column2: and despite its poor reviews
column3: I thought it was still useful
column4: and was not sadden by the loss of money. This book is completely different.  	The biggest problem with the Age of Mortals
column5: is the constant repetition. The book relates the history of the Dragonlance setting from the end of the Chaos War to the death of Takhisis
column6: and the sacrifice of Paladine. The story itself is rather interesting
column7: but it was already written in the main Dragonlance Campaign Setting book. As if repeating it once was not enough
column8: the authors decided to place the story in several places of the book. The story is written in the introduction. The story is repeated in the beginning of the chapter on religion. The book also has a time table of events
column9: which tells the same tale with the slight difference of separating events by the years on which the event took place. Further
column10: on almost every character profile presented in the book
column11: parts of the story were repeated again.  The art also is in need of repair. It isn't so much that the quality of the drawings is poor
column12: as the quantity is. There are very few pictures compared to that of a typical roleplaying manual. This wouldn't have been a big deal
column13: but there is obvious room for the pictures in the book. There are huge gaps at the end of each chapter
column14: where there is nothing but blank page. This space could have easily been occupied by a picture or two. Had the book cut down on the repetitive story
column15: even more room could have been made for art work. To top the space issues
column16: the problem of the first d20 Dragonlance book was not corrected. This book still has inch thick margins.  The meat of the book lies in the few prestige classes presented. There is also a page of feats
column17: and a couple pages of spells. The balance of the spells and feats is in question
column18: but since I have not yet gotten a chance to use any of them
column19: it would be unfair of me to grade them on their usability. Still even if all the spells and feats were the best feats and prestige classes ever written
column20: this one chapter would not be enough to make up for the poor planning of the rest of the book.  There is a chapter on towns
column21: cities
column22: and strongholds. This is by far the best chapter in the book
column23: but a few of the descriptions of the cities repeat larger parts of the main story. This wouldn't be so much of problem if it weren't for the boredom of having read the story several times already. This chapter had a major flaw. It doesn't have enough maps. Only three cities

column26: this chapter would have been helped greatly had it contained a map of the world

column30: and their nativity in Dragonlance. It isn't really important to the average gamer

column8: and all the other devices that make up traditional story telling.  I am very well aware that
column9: Pynchon

column11: are trying to prove that life in the modern world is soulless and meaningless.  The problem is
column12: he is not looking hard enough to find it.  He is the literary equivalent of that cooky professor who says nothing written after 1900 is worth reading.  My answer to the professor who tried to shove that one down my throat was to hand him a dozen books worth reading that were written in the last century.  The problem is
column13: you have to look hard to find the gems in the dross of life
column14: and this book simply tells you that those don't exist.  Finally

In Piano Tuner
column2: Daniel Mason (an American medical student who went to Myanmar to find himself)
column3: presents a clear picture of a liberal Englishman in the late 19th century
column4: who travels to Burma to repair a piano. He apparently hated himself and his culture so much that
column5: within weeks of arriving in exotic colonial Burma
column6: he craves for a new identity as a Burmese. Without any hesitation
column7: he cheats on his wife (exotic Asian women are so sexy)
column8: abandons his previous life
column9: and rebels against the British authorities in Burma.  This genre is very old and quiet stale. Ever since Europeans "discovered" Asia
column10: there have been books about going to the orient and finding meaning in a life that was meaningless in Europe. Daniel Mason trudges down this weary path once more one hundred years later.  Not only does he spin out an old formula
column11: he does so with very little sophistication. In the novel
column12: a Burmese woman accuses the English newspapers of caricaturing local women as dancing girls and men as barbarians. Mr. Mason does the same thing in his novel. There is not one Burmese male character in the novel who is intelligent or endearing
column13: and the one Burmese female character has a fetish for European men. She can't get enough of them.  A dominant character in the book is an English doctor (Mr. Mason's fantasy alter ego?) who is a lover of the arts
column14: a scientist and a thoroughly decent chap. This doctor is protecting the region from British aggression
column15: studying local flora and fauna
column16: saving lives of the Burmese with his medical ingenuity
column17: and truly appreciating the beauty of the country.  While Mr. Mason seems to oppose the military aggression and rule that the British used in that part of the world
column18: he openly endorses the idea of a white savior doctor who can teach the locals how to live in a civilized manner. This is so old
column19: that it hurts me to write about it.

column8: if you like. Enjoy parts of it. But make no mistake: to take any of this seriously
column9: you have to regress to a prehistoric world-view
column10: before men learned to think
column11: to ask questions; before logic or science -- a time when dazed
column12: superstitious primitives believed stars could fall to the earth
column13: if they didn't grovel humbly enough to their supposed god.   Do the absurdities and contradictions bother no one? When the "sheep" are raptured up to heaven
column14: their clothes are left behind. So heaven is a nudist colony?   The basic contradiction
column15: of course
column16: lies in using worldly action (some of it exciting) to proselytize for the unworldly
column17: the supernatural.   But why should we care whether any of the "good" guys gets killed? And why should THEY mind -- won't they go straight up to heaven? That's what they WANT
column18: isn't it? Why even lift a finger against the "bad" guys -- didn't Christ say
column19: "Resist not evil"?   Worried about who will win? "God" is infinitely powerful. So Jesus (who is 1/3 of God -- or something like that) is sure to win when Armageddon rolls around
column20: in book 12 of the series. And the "sheep" -- the believers -- will happily worship him
column21: looking just like the pictures of dim-witted
column22: bovine people you see in the tracts Jehovah's Witnesses leave at your door.   The going price for a used copy of "Tribulation Force" is one cent. Does that tell you something?   Actually
column23: the story-telling is worth more. The basic premise is worth less. Perhaps it averages out

column1: Edelman's criticisms of index mutual funds are nonsense. Most blatantly
column2: he sets up a false straw dummy
column3: by saying that index funds are claimed to have ZERO trading costs. Rubbish! NO proponent of these has ever said that. Starting with the largest
column4: Vanguard. All providers of index funds (and Exchange Traded Funds) assert that they have trading costs. Edelman surely knows this
column5: yet he goes on to misrepresent index funds. In order to "refute" the "claim" by saying that they do indeed incur these costs. Neophyte readers without any background in financial matters might be taken in. It shows clearly the type of audience that he is aiming at.  Yes
column6: index funds have trading costs. But so do actively managed funds. And the latter almost always do much higher trading. Reflected in the overheads. Index funds have expense ratios (overheads) of around 0.1-0.4%. Active funds are from 0.9-2% or more.  Another claim he makes is that index funds do mechanical buying and selling
column7: without having a human actively consider these decisions. Yet this is a strength of index funds
column8: not a weakness. When an active fund buys or sells
column9: it could be right or wrong. It is not a given that the active fund will even be correct on average. And the current price of a stock reflects this give and take
column10: across all active trading.   Edelman also says that when you buy an index fund
column11: you could get hit with capital gains
column12: if the fund sells stocks with large gains. But the low trading (=long holding periods) of an index fund
column13: mitigates against this. Active funds are more likely to hit you with capital gains
column14: because they trade much more frequently.  The strongest point he makes about index funds is that in a market downturn
column15: they should underperform active funds. Because index funds must stay fully invested
column16: whereas an active fund can have a cash position that cushions the fall in its stocks.   Intellectually
column17: this is the most plausible scenario for an active fund to outperform an index.  But hey
column18: you know what? In the last US bear market
column20: the main index funds still outperformed most of the large active funds. (Where both types invested across the market.) It turns out there is no guarantee that an active fund's cash position is sufficient to overcome a bad choice of stocks
column21: whose prices fall more than the market averages. This 3rd edition was written in 2003
column22: yet there is no reference to these events. Edelman did not update his remarks from the earlier editions. Sloppy.  He also quotes Forbes as deprecating on index funds. Wrong. Over the last 20 years
column23: Forbes has consistently written favourably on these. Because the Forbes fund surveys and associated advice look approvingly on low overhead (expense ratio). As they have put it several times
column24: the overhead is the most consistent thing you know about any fund
column25: in bull or bear markets. Their surveys have shown that index funds outperform most active funds

column1: I found this book to be annoyingly simplistic.  The illustrations - full color photographs - are nice enough but the text leaves a lot to be desired.    For example
column2: the book gives three steps for sewing in a zipper
column3: which might be enough if they told you whether to use thread or yarn for the backstitching into place (the picture seems to show them using yarn but it's not really clear)
column4: whether or not to remove the backstitching (the picture of the finished garment appears to show the (rather sloppy)backstitching still in place.  The third step is to slip stitch the edge of the zipper into place...again
column5: no mention of whether to use the yarn or matching thread
column6: though it would appear to be embroidery floss.  Kitchenering is shown briefly (and not explained very well) but is called "Grafting by Sewing
column7: so a newcomer to knitting wouldn't know what to look for in this book when confronted with the term Kitchener" in a pattern and
column8: alternatively
column9: when faced with the term "Kitchener" in a pattern wouldn't know that this was the method they might have seen in this book called "Grafting by Sewing."  I'm sure there are better books on finishing techniques than this one

column3: dirty old men
column4: horny female computers
column5: naked adolescent girls
column6: and dominant beauties who would be right at home in leather and whips.  Without these archetype characters most Heinlein novels written after 1970 would have a sparse population indeed.  As if this isn't enough
column7: Heinlein drags in his usual cast of characters from his other novels as he is so prone to doing.  In spite of all their cameo appearances
column8: this group remains dull and one dimensional throughout.  Heinlein's earlier novels written prior to 1960 are still fine fare for young people
column9: especially boys.  This novel
column10: as well as most of Heinlein's later work will be enjoyed primarily by a group of die hard fans and is definitely not for general consumption

column6: the shapes of the robots and weapons

column12: a spiffy sidekick
column13: and enough explosions to keep popcorn eaters eating.  This movie felt like a lot of effort with little substance.

column1: I'm criticizing Carver with the utmost deference

column3: Good Thing)
column4: which manage to say so much with so few pages.  His poems
column5: however
column6: are not as good as his short stories.  They lack the continuity of his stories
column7: as well as the practiced craft of more experienced poets.  The line changes seem awkward
column8: and there is not a consistent theme in each sub-collection.  These poems are not meant to be read by poetry afficionados

column10: but if you like to read poems about the same themes

column1: I agree with another reviewer who said the book was unnecessarily long.  Genetic Algorithms are a great programming tool
column2: and there are some tips and tricks that can help your programs converge faster and more accurately
column3: but this book had a lot of redundant information.  If you are interested in using GA for solution-finding
column4: I doubt you'll find much useful in this book beyond the first chapter or so.  Many of the examples later in the book were so specific that I couldn't see how they could be usefully generalized.  Really optimizing a GA approach for a specific problem domain takes a fair amount of tuning
column5: and this book won't help much with that.  I think time spent surfing siteseer or other publication sites would be better spent than reading this book.

James Loewen's "Lies" is a valuable tool
column2: debunking myths and misconceptions-even unearthing causation for common historical misconceptions. Where this critcal work fails
column3: though
column4: is in understanding the purpose for teaching history- for students to understand and affirm American institutions. Loewen's praise of a figure like John Brown does nothing to further this end. I do not believe
column5: as the author does
column6: that history as taught today is propaganda
column7: but I do agree that textbooks are written to serve a purpose
column8: and this being a capitalistic society
column9: they are also written for consumers.   I am particularly irritated at his continuing the present trend of Christopher Columbus bashing. It serves no interests to villify Columbus in the name of historical accuracy. All who have immigrated here owe him a debt regardless of his alleged crimes against humanity. Loewen rails on about the "exploitative" element in Columbus's story
column10: but his personal bias is likewise present in his support for African discovery and claims of racially motivated historiographical discrimination. Similarly
column11: his accusation of Lincoln as a racist violates the historical principle of judging the past through the prism of the present. It is a fallacy which needs context to be properly examined. Both the author and I agree that history is written by the victors
column12: so why does Loewen rehash this ad nausem?  Loewen asks the question
column13: "How is one supposed to feel about the America that has been presented?" My answer after reading his book is
column14: overwhelmingly negative and cynical. His criticism of texts
column15: as well as all modern scholarship revising previous inaccuracies
column16: must be taken into account in teaching history
column17: but his negative tone must be balanced. Students do need to become
column18: in Loewen's words
column19: "crap detectors." Students should be given the tools to analyze events and formulate reasonable conclusions
column20: on that much I think we would agree

column1: Breath-taking! I have worked and traveled in  Russia  and the CIS over  the past ten years and I am reminded of the story of the two scientists who went to the seashore to discover what a beach was. The first scientist observed the waves and tides pounding the rocks and said
column2: "Aha! Big rocks grind together to make smaller and smaller rocks until we get some pretty grains of sand!"   The second scientist went to the beach with a pair of tweezers and a magnifying glass
column3: and spent all day selecting grains of sand according to his preference of shape
column4: size
column5: weight and color. Then he hauled his sand collection to his laboratory and began to categorize and cross-compare each grain of sand with the grains of sand from foreign country's  beaches until he felt he had enough data to write a book about how large Russian rocks preyed on small Russian rocks and how pretty pieces of Russian sand were rare; and that the pretty pieces were always buried in the mud of a Gulag and how all the rest of the sand grains had to hide the audacity to strive to be beautiful - which could somehow provoked the envy of the big rocks into oppressing the sand grains.   In the end
column6: his book was full of clever sophistry and cynical blame for the majority of the Russian sand grains wanting to be beautiful. He concocted his own "Cosmic Law" which stated that Russian sand grains were either content to live in dreary
column7: collective layers because they did not want to be envied by other Russian sand grains who were afraid of the bigger rocks -or that all Russian sand grains should strive to rise to the top where they could hide under new "Laws" which would protect them from learning responsibility and from thinking for themselves; thus keeping all the grains of sand under "soft" control and diverted from trying to be better sand-grain souls.  I hesitate to use a four letter word to describe the author's covertly angry
column8: bitter and abusive criticism of the evolving and talented  Russian people who have
column9: after several hundred years only just begun experiencing the decency of a leader from their very own country. (Even Stalin was Georgian)
column10: but so
column11: for the opportunity for the discerning sociologist to experience and study a stunning and ingenious example of "Sophistry"
column12: I shall give this book one star. The thundering silence of any encouraging word and the breathtaking jealousy of the re-emerging
column13: responsible podvig of the Russian people will become self evident to students of ignorance versus spirited elan

column16: dark

column1: Many of us have the sinking feeling that the Internet is starting to resemble television. As the saying goes
column2: "There are 500 television stations
column3: but nothing's on." Estimates vary about the number of Web sites on the Internet. By some estimates
column4: there are 300 million. Which means there are 300 million Web sites and nothing's on. Most of the Web sites aren't worth visiting.  The author of "Best of the Internet" wants to direct you to the Web sites that are worth going to. To that end
column5: he has assembled some 1
column6: 000 Web site names and descriptions into 19 categories -- reference
column7: communicating
column8: computing
column9: entertainment
column10: news
column11: sports
column12: hobbies
column13: family
column14: education
column15: health
column16: lifestyles
column17: religion
column18: finance
column19: careers
column20: shopping
column21: travel
column22: government
column23: and the weird.  If you are willing to trudge through this book's 420 pages
column24: you will find more than a few good Web sites. I found a number of good online stores
column25: for example. But the problem with this book is that the author mostly presents the tried and true. He doesn't stray from the beaten track. You discover Web sites that you could probably find on your own or already know about.  I thought the book book presented far too many corporate Web sites. Do I need to know that Disney.com is a good family-oriented Web site? The author could have searched a little farther for eccentric Web sites that are of interest to families. I find corporate Web sites dull and uninspiring
column26: but many are listed in this book.  Another thing: The Web site descriptions are long-winded. By the time you read some of these descriptions
column27: you could have visited the Web site on your own and decided for yourself whether it is worth visiting.  I hope if the author revises this book that he cuts back on the Web site descriptions and gives us more Web sites instead. How about 2
column28: 000 Web sites next time instead of 1
column30: with fewer words to describe each Web site?

column1: Like it or not
column2: I sometimes wonder if an author is more loved for his image than his abilities.  Thomas Pynchon is one of those.  If the Crying of Lot 49 is his best work
column3: or exemplary of his work
column4: as so many say it is
column5: then perhaps he really should find a day job
column6: to use the cliche.  Lot 49 is an attempt at literature without any actual literature.  It's what happens when you take out plot
column7: character
column8: and all the other devices that make up traditional story telling.  I am very well aware that
column9: Pynchon
column10: like so many other authors of his era
column11: are trying to prove that life in the modern world is soulless and meaningless.  The problem is
column12: he is not looking hard enough to find it.  He is the literary equivalent of that cooky professor who says nothing written after 1900 is worth reading.  My answer to the professor who tried to shove that one down my throat was to hand him a dozen books worth reading that were written in the last century.  The problem is
column13: you have to look hard to find the gems in the dross of life
column14: and this book simply tells you that those don't exist.  Finally
column15: the content of the book often seems pointless
column16: and the writing is weak.  There is no forward motion
column17: and nothing to interest a decent reader

column1: New Rule:  Stop confusing cruelty with honesty.  -Bill Maher thinks it's his job to tell people the "ugly" truth. column2: but everyday people are on their hands and knees begging for one. I guess if I had been born a white man in America and never faced any hardships or heartaches
column3: I wouldn't need God either. Furthermore
column4: everybody has religion. It's just that all of our religions aren't in churches. Some people's religions are drugs or sex or pain or alcohol or anything else that we use to help fill that void in our hearts. What's YOUR religion?  It's also funny how Bill Maher ISN'T a Democrat
column5: yet most of his fans are. Hmmm
column6: ever heard the saying
column7: you are what you attract? Libertarianism is only liberalism by a different name. Compare the two and find they agree 95% of the time.  The bottom line is Bill Maher is an arrogant man who thinks he's right about everything and that the majority of America is stupid. Well if America is so stupid
column8: why should we have a democratic system where the stupid have influence? Why not have an oligarchy where only Cornell graduates make the decisions? Better yet
column9: why don't we have a dictatorship with Maher as our leader considering he's the only one with any real intelligence.  He's an immoral man who thinks he's moral because he confuses it with ethics. Ethics is how fairly you treat people. Morality is Godly obedience. Morality says it's wrong to be a pros-ti-tute because our bodies are sacred. Ethics says it's wrong for a pros-ti-tute to t-i-e her John to the b-e-d then steal his wallet.

column1: This book is stuck in an archaic age.  Get something more relevan
I am in great shape.  However
column2: I cannot get over that so many men's underwear products have waist bands that constrict and exasperarate blood flow and muscle tension.  Obviously they are made in China where the average waist is about 25 inches.    The idea of "Medium" as marketed is ridiculous by healthy American standards.  My body fat is low.  I am not profoundly muscular bound. As is common in men of my age
column3: lower back problems are not unusual. I have a 32" waist.  Is that not "Medium" sized?   I think we simply need to get rid of the elastic waist band altogether.  One size fits all doesn't work and it is dangerous to those many of us that fight our lower back problems.    The draw string is fine.  It allows flexibility.  So what if your pants fall down?  It seems to be the fashion
column4: anyway.  Just give us the option of pulling the shorts back up instead of pinching nerves with a static elastic waist band that causes ridiculous lower back problems because of unnecessary
column5: uncontrollable constrictions.    Also
column6: these boxers don't hold up well to any kind of washing.  They looked like crap after the first time I washed them.  I wish I could get a refund because I won't wear them again.  My life partner told me they looked like "old men's" underwear. That is sad and embarrassing because I agree they looked like crap after one cold wash and light dry.  I am not a mean hearted kind of guy.  So
column7: I am going to shut my mouth now and not do business with you again.

column1: Don't pay money to see this. Wood Harris is not a bad actor; quite the antithesis. He made a heroic effort to portray a man whose persona
column2: mannerisms
column3: and "vibe" simply cannot be immitated. Kudos to Mr. Harris for his bravery. The director did a mediocre job bringing life to a badly written script. Granted
column4: Hendrix' story had a great deal of tragedy; but I have it on good authority that Hendrix was also a lot of fun to be around.  The scene that described his death was not historicaly accurate: and I know people who were personally aquainted with Hendrix and were around when he died: and they told me what REALLY happened that day. The music was marred by the fact that nobody can play the guitar like Hendrix without sounding like someone trying to immitate him
column5: and Hendrix' estate refused to allow them to use any of his original compositions. The glossing over of the music; which was Hendrix' greatest accomplishment
column6: was truly irritating. All it was was sensationalism and Hollywood glamor: all flash and no substance - which does a great disservice to Hendrix' legacy
column7: musical genius
column8: and life. The whole thing made me sick.

column3: not chronologically
column4: which could be engaging if the text was not so confusing or superficial. Most of the book focuses on the art of the 17th century
column5: and absolutely nothing after 1760. The section on Rococo interiors is fairly comprehensive
column6: however
column7: and to his credit
column8: Minor does include writings from Winkelmann and Diderot
column9: grave omissions from previous survey texts

column5: but consistently thrown in are degrading remarks about feminists and/or women with jobs

column8: there were strange racial comments about a French chef and a New Orleans maid. In this book
column9: the Indian cab driver and the Japanese
column10: well

column12: still
column13: ick.  I think Fairbanks was using ethnic and racial stereotypes to add more of a locational flavor to the books
column14: but well

column16: but eventually all of the little "oddities" combined together into something where I was so uncomfortable I couldn't enjoy the book
column17: which is really annoying since normally I love the type of mystery book it appeared to be. The anti-feminist comments that Carolyn makes are in some ways even ickier than the racist ones because they aren't only stereotypes

column23: but I can't bring myself to go back and re-read to see if I missed some trivial line that would help it make more sense.  In essence

column25: which maybe that Fairbanks was only trying to set stages and solidify characters instead of being... not nice. So maybe if a reader would just skim over the first part they would have a better reading experience than me. The one star I gave this book feels too high

column1: Interesting experimental fiction.  In Big Trouble
column2: Barry employs the technique of shifting protagonists so well that in the end the reader isn't sure who the story is about.  Characters are abandoned with abandon and neglected through carelessness
column3: leaving a laser sharp focus on what the novel is really about--which is not the psychodelic frog.  It's something less original.  The genre is also well disguised.  Is it a comedy or a thriller?  If a novel is funny
column4: can we take the thriller part seriously enough?  In some cases
column5: yes.  When
column6: for example
column7: the comedy is built on clever dialogue by characters truly capable of mayhem.  In this case
column8: no.  It's a little jarring when a comic cop is traveling around
column9: chained to an entertainment center
column10: while a teenage girl is in the clutches of a sex-oriented crazy.  In all fairness
column11: the novel does feature a ticking clock
column12: which is handy to have in a thriller.  It's more effective if there is something believable about the story.  I expected a novel with an overdose of silliness
column13: but I was spared that
column14: which was a plus.  No characters with absurdly meaningful names.  The nuts and bolts aspect of writing was competently performed.  While there was little depth to any characters
column15: that's probably less of a requirement for characters  we want to laugh at.  The characters could have used some personality
column16: but that's a common flaw.  The novel should have been funny in places
column17: for a list of situations would show some potential.  But I had no difficulty keeping a straight face throughout.  Others would disagree.  The politically incorrect portrayal of Miami was entertaining
column18: if not actually funny.  The overall effect of reading Big Trouble is to bring about a yearning for the days when an editor would say
column19: "Sir
column20: I know your name is a household word
column21: and I know we could make money on whatever you write
column22: but I have to turn down too many good novels to give a green light to...to something like this."  If there ever were such days.

column1: In Stephen  Silbiger's words
column2: "I realised that the basics of an MBA education were quite simple and could easily be understood by a wider audience." What the author is trying to do with his book is to cram in two years of an MBA education into 350 pages. Naturally
column3: the book misses the whole point of the exercise of a University education: it takes time to grasp the often complex models that students will have to master in order to be eligible for a diploma with their name on it. It may be true that a lot of MBA programmes are very repetitive and that the basic information can indeed be summarised into a few pages only
column4: however this means that all the details is missing.  As we all know
column5: MBA programmes are very heterogeneous and will all differentiate at teaching something slightly different
column6: in as far as the subjects are concerned (obviously the contents remains the same for the same subjects). Silbiger's MBA is based upon 9 subjects
column7: where others like negotiation
column8: international business
column9: entrepreneurship
column10: or project management are all summarised into one chapter.   What this book does well
column11: is to emphasise that the main objective of an MBA is to be able to take a global decision within an organisation
column12: that is decide in such a way that no aspect of your entrerprise will be defavoured in any way. However
column13: not only does the book lack in perspective (the author literally bases his this book on his personal educational experience and does not focus at all beyond the US border)
column14: but at the same time the contents of this book is very shallow. The great theories are only outlined in very general terms and a lot of detail and further theories that you should expect from a sound MBA
column15: are missing totally. The book is an insult for all those who have actually completed an MBA
column16: by spending one or two years at a constitutional MBA
column17: and puts the non-MBA reader at a very low level.  Thus only the lowest rating can be awarded for this book
column18: as it fails to deliver what it promises

I loved the earlier Nevada Barr mysteries
column2: with their depiction of national parks and natural dangers.  I wasn't as happy with some of her latest efforts
column3: but still hadn't given up on her.  Now I'm not so sure.  This latest novel started off well enough although the idea of two severely traumatized girls should have been a clue as to what would follow. The idea that they were from a polygamous Mormon sect was a red herring.  Perhaps it was Barr's attempt to show us how these girls were abused even before they met evil incarnate. The scenes where Anna realizes who the real villian is and her interaction with him and the poor tortured third traumatized girl went on for over 60 pages. Each scene was more disturbing the one before it. I found myself skimming the pages and still am not sure how she resolved all the loose ends. But I have absolutely no desire to re-read the end of the book and find out.  I wish I could say that I would read another Nevada Barr novel because I so thoroughly enjoyed the first ones. But after reading this disturbing
column4: somewhat convoluted story
column5: I would think twice.  If I did pick up another Anna Pigeon novel
column6: I'd make sure I had something else to read if the story took another dark turn. I would certainly not stick with it to the end.

column1: This book is basically Marxist view of art
column2: and what art is intended to accomplish.  This isn't necessarily a bad thing!  It does help you to examine your assumptions and beliefs a bit
column3: and that's one of the things an education is supposed to do.  The book repeatedly hammers the idea that art serves the purposes of the ruling class.  This is beat upon to the point of tediousness.  There is also a chapter that can be summarized as "art serves the purposes of powerful men by trivializing women and encouraging them to think of themselves as an object d'art for the viewing pleasure of others.  Oddly enough
column4: the book didn't really return to this them in the final essay when it talked about the visual image in advertising.  That's an arena where visual imagery is used to play on the insecurities of everyone
column5: but especially women
column6: to convince them that they are flawed and need __(fill in the name of a product)____ to be happy and respected and glamorous. Speaking of which
column7: one of the more interesting points in the book (even though I believe it is flat wrong) is the discussion of the rise of "glamor" as a desirable trait.  I found the book interesting
column8: and it irritated me
column9: but only in a good way--By making me think about my views.  But it really is written from the perspectives of a trendy liberal from the early 1970s.  Instead of closing with a powerful message summarizing some important aspect of art that we have been taught
column10: the authors even use the final paragraph of the last essay to point out that capitalism exploits the masses and coerces them to ignore their own best interest(that's literally what it says!).  Probably worth reading
column11: but not a high priority.  The Penguin edition is compact and affordable
column12: but the B&W images are so small that much of the value of the work is lost--You can't see details of the art being reproduced

column1: I doubt many who have written reviews here are actual college students.  Physics is probably one of the most challenging courses one can take.  Nevertheless
column2: it can also be an exciting field of study - this book doesn't do it justice though.  It has the potential of scaring off newcomers.      While the book's overall visual presentation is nicely done
column3: the theory behind various mathematical laws is poor.  Often
column4: it takes two or three paragraphs of rambling before getting to the point on a topic.    Each chapter has its own set of word problems to solve.  While some of the problems are generally a piece of cake
column5: most contain subtleties and assume you know far too much prior knowledge outside the book.  It would be a nightmare solving these problems without the answer/studyguide book handy.  That guide is almost as large as the textbook and sells for almost $70 alone.  Even with the studyguide
column6: some of the demonstrations are illogical and don't necessarily reflect the material you learnt in the current or previous chapters.  I've even seen plenty of cases where the math contradicts what the material in the chapter stated!    Although the book says it is a calculus-based text
column7: there really isn't a whole lot of it in there.  This might be a blessing to some but isn't always practical in the real world.  My Calculus textbook covered physics problems better than this textbook!  The authors tend to brush basic differentiation/integration in the theory portions but they're never really used in actual problems.    The PhysicsNow online study tool has some neat diagrams and interactive problems but is still generally useless.  Good luck getting your account activated when registering online!  I had to call customer service several times before I could actually login to the site.    I could conclude in saying that this book does make a great reference book to people who already have knowledge in physics.  However
column8: I'm sure there are better textbooks out there that can teach you the basics if you're new to the field.  Many fellow students in my physics classes have shared the same grunts about the book as much as I have and agree that this book can make physics frustrating to the newbie.

column11: and have piercings as if someone's appearance is indicative of their worth or ability.  I'm sure he would have a heart attack if he walked into my classroom and saw me teaching with a baseball hat on. All of his critiques would be fine if only he had done one thing: research.  He constantly compares his experiences as a teacher in the 90s with his own experiences as a student decades before.  However
column12: all he offers is anecdotal evidence based on his own memories when comparing students then and in the 90s.  If he had taken a minute to get down off of his high horse he might have went and talked to some teachers who had been around for decades and asked them their thoughts on students
column13: or even better
column14: go hunt down his college professors and ask them about classes in which he was a student.  However
column15: rather than go out and do some good investigative reporting and gather all the facts
column16: he chose to write a poorly informed book-length letter to the editor about those damn kids who keep walking on his lawn.   This book is a missed opportunity to have a real look at students in colleges.  It is a shame that someone with no teaching experience and such an inflated self of self-importance (the very things he chastises his students for) chose to think that he was qualified to write it.

column1: This book tries to cover a lot of ground
column2: but in the end you get a sense that it has gotten you anywhere.  The first impression I got was that this book was actually a bunch of journal articles thrown together because there isn't much sense of continuity to this book.  It doesn't have an overall theme and the topics covered don't seem to connect well.  It starts off with a short biography of the Grimms
column3: so far so good.  After that
column4: it covers the orgins of the tales
column5: a little dry
column6: but not bad.  After that
column7: there's a chapter about how the Grimm tales indoctrinate children into the bourgeoisie.  The Marxism seems a little dated.  After that
column8: out of the blue
column9: you get a chapter on Henri Pourrault
column10: an obscure writer of fairy tales.  It's never explained why this writer is in this book
column11: but I guess the author really liked this journal article and couldn't resist throwing it in.  After this
column12: it gets really weird.  You get a chapter about how fairy tales are all about childhood sexual abuse.  If that doesn't kill your mood to read fairy tales
column13: then the following chapter in which the author attacks the Grimm tales as outdated and obsolete and advocates the rewriting of the tales for more modern perspectives will.  One gem that the author singles out for praise is a rewriting of Cinderella.  In this version
column14: Cinderella is a labor organizer who organizes all the workers in her kingdom.  The prince
column15: impressed by her accomplishments
column16: falls in lover with her and proposes.  However
column17: Cinderella refuses to betray the worker and rejects the prince.  In the end
column18: Cinderella moves to America and the prince commits suicide over the heartbreak.  Wow
column19: the kids will love that one.  It's not even entertaining or enlightening for adults and borders on masochistic.  That's some of the nonsense that you'll run into in this book.  I really recommend that you pass on this

column1: As is typical with software claiming to be "topo"
column2: it is not. Expecting that the buyer of topos will typically be someone looking for USGS quads this software is not as advertised.  Since I own the other major competing program (for which you need to buy each state in order to get Quads (and for which I can not seem to find Wyoming))
column3: I was eagerly awaiting this package.  In five minutes I realized Delorme is essentially useless to the backpacker/mountain biker (et al). You can order quads very simply using the package
column4: but at the zoom level appropriate for making an ordering decision the wonks at Delorme decided they would make the map blank (apparently to force you into buying electronic quads at $2.50 a piece).  So
column5: you need to actually know the quad you want before you order it.  Well
column6: if I knew that
column7: I would already own the quad
column8: and certainly wouldn't need to buy an electronic version.  For 2.50 more I could get it laminated.  Yes
column9: this is a flame
column10: but it is deserved. Delorme might be great software if you know the quad you want; it is ridiculous software if you are trying to explore and area in order to decide where you want to go (and then download
column11: and pay for
column12: the appropriate map).  All in all
column13: a complete waste of money--I only feel it worth my time to write this review so that the suppliers of such software get a clue and discover a more appropriate business model (versus selling blank maps
column14: with a 100 dollar credit for maps that you don't even know will work)  Cheers.

column1: This was the movie that gave us The Brat Pack

Since then the gals in the movie as well as a few others who weren't in the movie (Anthony Michael Hall

column4: this was the one I liked the least.  Maybe it was the fact that all the characters were so vain and self centered. column8: I didn't have all the dramas going on they did.  That was kind of sad

This caputed more of a time in fashion and music than it did a mindset.  It's not a bad story
column10: but the vain and self centered antics of the main characters left me cold.

column1: Ruby Payne's A Framework for Understanding Poverty describes a personal journey
column2: but falls short of creating an entire framework of poverty applicable to all situations. Since her evidence is based solely on her personal experience
column3: if readers apply her theories
column4: it will only exacerbate existing stereotypes.    Payne's book is riddled with over generalizations. It has been our experience that people in poverty do not feel a "need to beat around the bush" (30).  And by stating this
column5: is she implying that all middle and upper class people always speak directly to the point?  The fact remains that patterns of discourse (and poverty)
column6: rely more on regional
column7: cultural
column8: and societal factors
column9: which Payne simply does not address.  Furthermore
column10: her assertion that "fighting and physical violence are a part of poverty" (37) confirms the bias of her own personal experience imbedded in her publication
column11: and about people in poverty around the world.  The result is a deficit theory perspective that  adversely affects her approach in dealing with an impoverished population.  Even more frightening is the fact that she influences the approach of many others who read her book without a critical mindset
column12: and assume the same biases and stereotypes which may hinder rather than help those trying to escape poverty.  We recommend future readers of this book to  read with caution
column13: and resist her attempts to facilitate assimilation into a classist society

column1: Please note that this 2-star rating should be read as "fair
column2: not as below average. Here we have a reasonably interesting straight chronologic hagiography that I would recommend for readers who (like myself) do not know much about the period in question. If you don't know much about Roosevelt already, you will learn some things. If you, on the other hand, are at all familiar with Roosevelt or any of the contemporaneous social or political movements, you will not find much of interest here. I did not enjoy the book much, largely because Morris simply does not seem to have anything to say, though he has enough to relate to fill the pages. With the magnificent, strongly opinionated Johnson (number 2) biography by Caro, this book stands in relation as a USA Today squib does with a New York Review of Books article. 1979, I assume, was simply not a strong year for American history books: The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt" must have been awarded the prize by default: it's fairly long
column3: manages (sometimes only barely) to keep the reader's attention
column4: and contains nothing controversial. I wouldn't waste my time with it. The companion volume ("Theodore Rex") is not so boring

column1: This book is awful.  It is full of speculations and just bad science.  I am going to quote one egregious example.  The comments in brackets [ ] are mine:  "Like the brain
column2: the human eye also evolved opposite [really!] but complementary functions.  Each human eye is a perfect mirror image of the other; yet within the each retina there resides two functionally different types of cells.  With elegant symmetry
column3: the contrasting functions of the rods and cones correspond to the division of tasks between the right and left brain [that is quite a comparison]. "Rods named for their cylindrical shape
column4: are extremely light sensitive.   Distributed evenly throught the periphery of each retina
column5: they see in dim light and appreciate [the rods have feelings??] the totality of the visual field
column6: seeing images as gestalts.  Rods share with the right brain the ability to perceive [the rods can think??] reality all-at-once [as opposed to what
column7: a little bit at a time?]. Cones
column8: in contrast congregate densely in a small spot in the central part of the retina...Cones have two attributes.  They appreciate [there he goes again] color and intensify clarity [whatever that means]. Concentrating on one aspect of reality at a time
column9: [huh?] cones view the visual field as if through a tunnel. [Actually cones and rods sense light together
column10: at the same time
column11: and your brain integrates and intreprets all that information into a perceived image.  But the most fantastic statement is the last sentance of this quote:]  Like rods
column12: cones report to both hemispheres
column13: but the left is metaphorically best suited to process their input.  [That is such an absurd statement that Shlain gives a footnote
column14: right on the same page
column15: contradicting his non sequitor.]"  And so it goes on for page after page of drivel
column16: I finally gave up after 6 chapters.  A lot of reviewers find this book to be thought provoking.  I think it is a sad state that our appreciation of science is so dim that people can actually find this nonsense to be of interest

column1: The book
column2: "The Framework for Understanding Poverty" failed to live up to its high expectations. Dr. Payne talks about helpful strategies to improve instruction
column3: such as using graphic organizers
column4: rubrics
column5: and activating background knowledge. She lumps all people who live in poverty into one group
column6: assuming that every student comes to school with the same life experiences. Some of the negatives about the book are that there are more generalizations
column7: rather than facts. This leads to some good ideas but a lot of falsehood. Payne feels that teachers need to let students know that formal registry is their way to getting high paying jobs in the future
column8: and this could discourage children and make them feel less about their culture and background. Although learning academic language is important for students to acquire
column9: they should also feel that their language and culture is validated in the classroom
column10: including their registry.  Dr. Payne focuses on the negative aspects of living in poverty. Instead
column11: she should have addressed ways in which educators can look at strengths and experiences children living in poverty bring to the classroom. Her so-called "framework" is a far cry from what a framework should entail. It is also important to keep in mind that her own company
column12: aha! Process Inc.
column13: published this book. She grew up in privilege so she cannot relate to those she is writing about. In order to truly understand Payne's perspective it is important to know that she is a Bush supporter and has contributed thousands of dollars to his presidential campaigns

column4: but he jumps from subject to subject with no transitions. He acknowledges his partner for being the first to hear what Edmund has written. But obviously the partner is no editor. The book should be titled My Digressions. Because White can vividly describe a person in few words
column5: we think he has depth. He doesn't. His astuteness hides shallowness. His writing deserves better content. He writes to be read: He craves approval. When he sleeps with someone
column6: he wonders how the lover perceives him. When he writes
column7: he wonders how the reader will perceive him. He knows that all his life he has been able to charm people into loving him; now he thinks he can tell us everything
column8: especially the things he considers disgusting
column9: and that he will able to still self-depreciatingly charm us. "Here I am
column10: he might as well write, faults and all. Now love me. Or (preferably) not." After all his therapy he has not learned that no one can validate him except himself. How can we love-how can we read-a man with this much self-hatred? He has become what he fears most: boring

column2: what is a nut in the bathroom?  A pee can."  "Why did the baby cross the road?  She was stapled to the chicken."  Billing itself as "the mother of all joke books"
column3: The Jokelopedia has the apparent goal of turning your child (or grandchild
column4: etc.) into a comedian.  Categorized by subject matter such as a monster jokes
column5: classroom distractions
column6: family funnies
column7: etc.
column8: the book contains riddles
column9: jokes
column10: cartoons
column11: and tips from famous comedians.  Many of the riddles have pun-ch lines consisting of puns:  some that I consider funny
column12: and many of which adults will consider groaners
column13: but will get a lot of giggles from 8 year-olds.    Although I tend to like puns more than the average person
column14: as a practitioner of non-violent communication
column15: I don't recommend giving this book to children.  I am concerned that roughly up to 10 to 20% of the laughs come at the expense of becoming desensitized to the suffering of animals and humans.  For example
column16: there's a joke about a woman who buys a parrot
column17: and to get the bird to talk
column18: she buys a mirror
column19: a ladder
column20: a bell
column21: etc.  She goes back to the store and reports that the parrot died.  The clerk expresses his sorrow over her loss and asks if the parrot ever said anything to her.  The woman replied that just prior to dying
column22: the parrot said
column23: "Doesn't that store carry any food?"  So the joke is that the parrot starved to death because the woman was too stupid to buy food in addition to all the accessories.  There are riddles that have punch lines at the expense of animal suffering
column24: for example
column25: "What's black and white and flat? A panda that's been run over."  And the tacky frog in a blender joke
column26: mentioned by a previous reviewer
column27: could give a child the idea to actually try this (likely very few children but it's possible).  Although much of the egregiously tacky material is in the "Snot funny" section
column28: there is some in other sections of the book.  Another reason I don't recommend the Jokelopedia is because of the practical joke recommendations.  The child who tries out these suggestions will probably think he or she is being funny
column29: but those laughs come at the expense of being rude and crude to other people
column30: and insensitive to their feelings.  For example
column31: one of their slumber-party jokes is to pour cold water over the shower curtain rod on someone using the shower.  Another is to put another child's hand in a glass of warm water to get him or her to wet the bed.  Yet another is to put some fake plastic vomit in the sink.  One of the elevator practical jokes is to bet the other passengers that you can fit a quarter in your nose.  Yuck.  Another joke encourages lying:  "Tell [your big sister] that one of her friends called (for this to work
column32: be specific--use the real name of someone your sibling is close to and say one of the coolest kids in school is having a party tonight
column33: but you can't remember all the details."  In case your budding comedian runs out of practical ideas to play on siblings and parents (yes
column34: a parental practical joke idea involving the kitchen sink sprayer is provided--don't say you weren't warned!)
column35: there are five suggestions for tormenting the pizza guy.  One could
column36: as another reviewer did
column37: rip out some of the pages prior to giving the book to a child
column38: or perhaps cross out portions with a thick dark marker like it's a government document.  (But if you rip out the page of slumber party practical jokes
column39: the blurb on Lucille Ball is on the other side.)   Had I received this book as a child with pages ripped out
column40: I would have been extremely curious about what was missing and sought out another copy!  Unless the authors write a new edition that takes out the practical and insensitive to suffering jokes
column41: I don't recommend rewarding them by purchasing this book.  That's unfortunate
column42: because I think some of the puns are very clever
column43: and encourage children to have fun with the language.
