column1: An amazing transformation came over me while reading this book. No
column2: I did not turn into a lizard or a bird. Never before have I experienced such an enormous swing in my state of mind while reading a book. No classic has moved me so much. No works of Hume
column3: nor Kant
column4: nor even Harry Potter's chambermaid have driven in me such a force of wild-eyed realization as compared with this amazing collection of words. I will do my best to describe the story
column5: without boxing your ears or tugging my braid.  The story starts like all of Jordan's stories do
column6: which is to say that an avalanche of words were used to describe such mundane things as grass and horse eye lashes. Nevertheless
column7: Jordan's indispensable and uncanny knack for stringing words together kept me in the game. I had read the first seven books in the series and knew what I was up against. This was nothing. A hundred
column8: two hundred
column9: or even fifty thousand words to describe yet another immature dialog between a pair of immature people wedged in an altogether immature scenario would never get me down.  But as time wore on
column10: it started to wear on me. Like water over a rock
column11: my meddle started to wan
column12: slowly washing away with the sands of the wheel of time. I began zoning out
column13: unable to focus on the words on the page before me
column14: finding myself having read an entire paragraph with no recollection of having done so. I wondered
column15: am I really taking an SAT test? All my previous training seemed to have left me. My eyes were failing me
column16: my brain quitting. I was aghast. This series of books that had heretofore been as straight in it's narrative as a pentangle was bogging down more than I thought even possible. I was losing interest. The flame was going out.  But I dug deep. I concentrated on the void
column17: the endless void
column18: the taint of Boredom making the void sickly sweet and palpable in my veins. I could taste it
column19: it's sickening blackened bleary broken bleakness trying to take over my mind
column20: my body
column21: my soul. I controlled it. And with that control
column22: Jordan's world of Boredom coursed through my veins like a pat of hot butter on a toasted English muffin on a hot summer day in Florida when the air conditioner is broken.  Shortly I had discovered the long lost Talent of Skimming. What had previously taken hours to read now took minutes! Pages down in seconds
column23: chapters in no time at all. Boredom? Shredded to bits. Single words picked here and there
column24: dialog grasped in an instant when the words "boxed" or "grasped" sprung from the page. I was alive
column25: I was being tainted by Boredom! The lost Talent of Skimming
column26: an astoundingly rare yet miraculously rediscovered Talent much like others I came across while reading this book
column27: made me feel more alive than ever. Not to be outdone
column28: Skimming was joined by Sleeping
column29: Ignoring
column30: Laughing
column31: Putting Down
column32: and Reading Something Else. All amazing powers in their own right
column33: but nothing to hold a candle to Skimming.  In no time
column34: Jordan's 8th book came to a close
column35: and the narrative was no closer to being resolved than if all the characters had jumped into a blender and pressed the puree button
column36: using the One Power of course. I mean
column37: how else would they press the puree button if they were *in* the blender? I dare say that it would be improbable.  In any event
column38: this book was so bad that the time invested in all 8 can't keep me coming back for a 9th. Fool me 8 times
column39: shame on you. Fool me 9
column40: shame on me

column1: More than two million jobs disappeared from the U.S. between '01 and '04 - half a million in high-tech industries alone. Further
column2: Steven Roach
column3: chief economist at Morgan Stanley
column4: estimates that there have been about 8 million fewer jobs in the current recovery than would have been expected from prior history
column5: and most of the new jobs come with low wages and few benefits.    Berger knows these numbers have caused a rising fear that no American job is safe from low-wage countries.  To discover whether these fears are justified
column6: Berger and a group of MIT researchers visited over 500 workplaces and factories around the world.  Their conclusion is that cheap labor is not the answer.   This conclusion is currently true in some instances; however
column7: the authors fail to see that cheap labor (the "China price") is increasingly dominating decision-making - both in services and manufacturing.  Jobs that formerly were not candidates for outsourcing (finance
column8: market research
column9: industrial design
column10: computer systems design
column11: paralegal research
column12: reading X-rays) now are; strategies that previously fought off Asian alternatives often fail to work several years later as China and India adopt new techniques; in fact the authors often cite previously highly successful American companies that subsequently succumbed.    G.M. and Ford are additional examples where this may yet happen - despite years of world-leadership. Part of their problem was believing that they could let Japan have the low-cost market - this worked for awhile
column13: but now Toyota et al have applied the lessons learned in that market segment
column14: and leveraged their distribution etc. systems on to producing competitive SUVs and innovative hybrids as well.  Meanwhile
column15: Toyota sees Korea and China as its most formidable future challenges
column16: and despite its vaunted Toyota Production System
column17: maintaining direct control throughout all stages (so does Microsoft
column18: but that hasn't kept it from substantial outsourcing to India)
column19: and co-locating with suppliers
column20: is seriously looking at China.  Remember Visteon and Delphi (Ford and G.M.'s former parts arms)?  Spinning them off was supposed to encourage more companies to utilize them
column21: and it worked - for a time.  Today's successes are far too often ephemeral!  To be fair
column22: the authors also point out that studies and analyses on the impact of outsourcing reach conclusions all over the map.  However
column23: I think the most accurate (and certainly highly credible) conclusion is that of former MIT economist (and Nobel prize-winner) Paul Samuelson - globalization should increase the world's total income and average standard of living
column24: but there's no reason to think any particular country or region's advances will outweigh its losses.  Berger
column25: et al
column26: also go on to recommend substantially improving American education.  The "bad news" is that this has been tried for at least 30 years
column27: with little impact.  Further
column28: others have determined that Asian IQs average about ten points over that of American whites.  Regardless
column29: what difference would improving education make
column30: even if we did achieve equality with Asian outcomes
column31: when the workers are paid but a fraction of Americans?  Berger does mention the rationale for foreign corporations choosing to continue building millions of cars in the U.S. - laws requiring U.S. content.  Toyota
column32: Nissan
column33: Mercedes
column34: BMW
column35: Subaru
column36: VW and others have built large plants in the U.S. as a result of this act.  However
column37: the authors fail to recognize this as a potentially strong and viable overall solution to the hollowing of America.  Another important omission is the problem of outsourcing large numbers of jobs to illegals within this country - in fact
column38: Berger et al reference a situation involving such as a solution!  Estimates are that AT LEAST nine million illegals from Mexico are here - depressing wage levels and stealing jobs that Americans formerly did. And what about the large number of Canadian truck drivers within the U.S. - soon to be augmented by Mexicans. (There are NO American truck drivers in Mexico that I know of
column39: and very few that I've seen in Canada.) Then there is the self-inflicted problem of L1 and H1B visas bringing hundreds of thousands more
column40: albeit legally.  While technically not "outsourcing
column41: the impact of each of the preceding is the same.  Another thought from some experts" is that sending off the lower-level jobs allows the U.S. to focus on "higher level" jobs such as innovation.  That's ridiculous for at least two reasons:  1)Manufacturing
column42: for example
column43: involves more than drilling
column44: welding
column45: molding
column46: etc.  It also involves design
column47: production management
column48: production layout
column49: machine design
column50: etc.  These are NOT low-level jobs
column51: nor is operating highly technical equipment.  2)How are all the displaced workers going to become eg. biomedical researchers
column52: rocket scientists
column53: etc.?  (Oh yes
column54: the Chinese and Indians are moving into those areas also; I have encountered a number of Americans who took recommended training in new areas after being "outsourced" from a long-term occupation only to become outsourced again.)  Also missing from "How We Compete" is any discussion and recommendation on healthcare.  Auto manufacturers repeatedly claim that having to pay healthcare for their employees adds $1
column55: 000+ cost to each car - creating government-funded universal healthcare like other nations would help save jobs in America.  "How We Compete" address an important topic - however
column56: its focus on CURRENT approaches (vs. trends) results in conclusions that are seriously over-optimistic.  (Inadequate analysis by Berger and others helps explain the maze of contradictory conclusions on this topic; political and economic motivations of short-sighted clients are additional drivers.)  Eight million jobs here
column57: nine million there
column58: etc.
column59: etc. - it adds up and hurts a lot.  Meanwhile

column1: I was very disappointed with this book- I expected to learn something new about the soldiers of the Red Army in WW2 but instead I got the same picture of a green/brown filthy primitive horde which inhabits many other (especially German) books on the Soviet Army. Most of the book is about how bad the Red Army and the Soviet Union were. The daily lives and motivations of the soldiers are really treated in a cursory manner and the author seems to get frustrated when the vets relating their experiences don't tow her neocon party line- eg.: "Ilya Natanovich ought to remember Stalin with disgust... But what the veteran remembers
column2: with a smile of recognition
column3: is an attitude that borders on religious faith...". Throughout the book any positive memories of Red Army veterans are always countered with five stories about corruption or incompetence or cowardice or the evils of Soviet Communism. But we know from history that far from falling apart the Soviet Army held on against unbelievable odds to become the best land army of its time bar none! You'd never know this from reading this book which joins many recent Western books which recount the story of the Eastern Front only to denigrate the Russians. There is a long section of the book which seeks to show how anti-Semitic the Russians were when in fact compared to an other army of the time (including the US Army) they were the least rascist. There is also alot of moralising at the end of the book about the Russians treatment of the German population at the end of the war- again after a giving the hideous German occupation short shrift. So in the end it's the usual amorphous smelly commy Soviet subhumans fighting in the service of evil Communism who are described. A real disappointment to anyone hoping for an actual social history of   Red Army soldiers in WW2. They remain as inscrutable as ever

The Crossing is set in New Mexico and Mexico in the late 1930s
column2: during the last days of the Wild West before the onslaught of the motor car ends the frontier once and for all.  	The story is centred on two adolescent
column3: monsyllabilic farmer's sons in New Mexico. When a wolf comes up from Mexico the farmer and his two sons decide to set traps and catch the wolf. McCarthy takes us into the mind of the wolf and an interesting
column4: but sadly short
column5: period of the book ends when the older son
column6: alone
column7: catches the wolf. Here he decides
column8: rather than kill it
column9: to return it to Mexico from where it came. When he reaches Mexico he is surprised to find the Mexicans don't see his generosity in quite the same light. After they commandeer the wolf and set it to fighting dogs Billy shoots it
column10: and drifts through Mexico before returning home where he finds his parents murdered by horse thieves. An obvious plot at this stage would be for them to seek revenge but no. Instead they become thieves themselves and we find ourselves heading back to Mexico
column11: with an unclear goal except to find their horses
column12: a big country in which to find half a dozen horses
column13: and our two protagonists becoming less and less likeable by the page. It is a pity that although McCarthy manages to take us into the mind of the wolf he never once reveals what the two boys are thinking
column14: nor why. What motivates Billy and Boyd? For the entire book we never find out.  	 They meet a girl in an encounter that will be confusing to anyone who does not speak fluent Spanish. They also meet several Mexicans
column15: some with their parent's horses
column16: and they reacquire some of the horses in equally confusing scenes. Later Boyd
column17: the younger brother
column18: runs off with the girl; Billy returns to the USA
column19: tries and fails to join the army (we are now in the 1940s) and so works on various ranches before returning to Mexico
column20: for the third time
column21: to find his brother.  	In `The Crossing' there are in fact three `crossings' into Mexico
column22: which is projected as a lawless country full of generally unpleasant people
column23: much like the USA. In fact
column24: through the book there are few endearing
column25: likeable characters that the reader can actually root for; the wolf and one or two horses are the possible exceptions. Much of the dialogue is in Spanish and difficult to follow. McCarthy may be pleased with himself for speaking Spanish but many readers of English literature do not and with so much dialogue in Spanish
column26: and untranslated
column27: it makes the story difficult to follow. 	This is further aggravated by a lack of proper punctuation. Mr McCarthy should remember that punctuation is something that has evolved with the English language and is there to make the language more comprehensible. To eliminate this not only distracts readers from what you are saying
column28: but stops readers from enjoying the writing. Reading a sentence of 80 words without so much as a comma is very hard work. Lawyers often omit punctuation when writing a legal document to protect them legally. At times
column29: `The Crossing' was much like reading a legal document
column30: you need to read each sentence twice to understand exactly what McCarthy is saying.  Yet McCarthy still gives a compelling story described in vivid locations. Behind the faade of Spanish dialogue
column31: unpunctuated English and dull characters there is a powerful storyteller at work here. It is a pity he chooses two charisma free lads having a loosely connected series of mini-adventures to express himself

  M. Gary Neuman puts fear in the hearts of my married people. His notion that emotional infidelity is more dangerous than a sexual affair because everyone wants emotional attachments, is more a scare tactic rather than good advice.   If you look at his rules, then anyone who has an emotional attachment outside of marriage is guilty of infidelity. Best-friends, close siblings, parents, children from a previous marriage, could all fall into these rules. You could have an emotional affair with your mother or your best friend.   Instead of focusing on real issues that cause jealousy" Neuman blatantly says that we should avoid and be on guard for those people who might even want a friendship.   This whole concept is wrong.   There are better books and better sources to read

column1: This book begins with ill-conceived premises and gets even worse.  The author begins with the contention that the French philosophes invented compassion
column2: sympathy
column3: and egalitarianism in the 18C.  Only somebody who knows little about religion
column4: and nothing about Christianity
column5: could make such an asinine statement.  Christianity's first commandment is agape
column6: or uncritical love for others.  Christianity was also unique in that it accorded the same rights to salvation to slaves as it did to kings.  Granted
column7: Christians frequently fail to live up to Christ's moral standards
column8: but that is beside the point.  Ms Hunt argues that these concepts were unknown.    The secular notion of egalitarianism
column9: on the other hand
column10: is patently absurd.  Since all people are different and unique
column11: no two people are equal in either endowments or outcomes.  The author utterly fails to draw this crucial distinction.  Ms Hunt frequently conflates and confuses historical circumstances.  She celebrates the egalitarian spirit of the French Revolution while remaining absolutely deaf to its atrocities and excesses; ditto with that other egalitarian scourge
column12: Communism.  She does the same with slavery
column13: confusing the different patterns that occurred at different times
column14: and at different places.  European slavery
column15: prior to opening the new world
column16: consisted primarily of women and children captured during conflict.  Usually
column17: their humanity was not in question.  Yes
column18: they were frequently used cruelly
column19: but that cruelty was a mere pittance when compared with Communists
column20: and other purveyors of egalitarianism and high-flown notions of human rights
column21: such as Ms Hunt.  Rather than address these issues
column22: Ms Hunt dismisses criticism with the haughty contempt that characterizes today's liberal elites.  She concedes the many atrocities committed in the name of human rights and egalitarianism
column23: such as the current war in Iraq
column24: but fails to understand that these disasters are merely foregone conclusions resulting from her faulty premises.  She cites the US Bill of Rights as an early commitment to human rights.  It was no such thing.  Rather
column25: it was a guarantee that the federal government would respect the customary rights demanded by American citizens.  The fact is rights are very particular
column26: and not all rights are recognized everywhere.  For instance
column27: few Muslim nations would recognize freedom of religion--one of the West's most cherished rights.  The Constitution was written to protect the rights of American citizens because the framers understood what Ms Hunt fails to understand:  that rights are customary and emanate from particular cultures
column28: and that most of the founding fathers quickly became disillusioned with the radical ideas emanating from the French Revolution.  The other concept that seems to give Ms Hunt so much difficulty is that other than being inherently absurd
column29: radical egalitarianism is a guise for those who wish to assert superior rights.  When
column30: for instance
column31: black civil rights leaders argue for
column32: say
column33: affirmative action or blacks-only dorms in college
column34: these "equal rights" apply only to blacks.  Indeed
column35: all animals are equal
column36: but some are more equal than others.  It's sad that Ms Hunt fails to understand this very simple concept.  How many more innocent victims of equality and human rights will have to die on the altar of her ideas?  Readers interested in the history of egalitarianism and human rights would be much better served reading Thomas Fleming's "Morality of Everyday Life"

column1: The only reason I completed this silly

column4: fatuous novel.  If you desire to read about 20 forgettable people in a seriously inbred family speaking at the same time about the impending wedding of one of their own

column6: it is senseless
column7: repetitive and tedious
column8: and the characters dash madly in and out of the novel
column9: without making any lasting impression on this reader. Instead
column10: read Welty's short stories and "The Optimist's Daughter" and you will discover a totally different Welty:  one whose fully realized characters and profound psychological insights will leave you with the enduring belief in her genius.

Maybe my expectations were too high.  This heating pad does not get hot enough; not nearly as hot as others I've used.  The massage feature is not effective and is simply two speeds of vibration  I bought this one because I was attracted to the thickness of the pad.  I've had problems with other heating pads bunching and folding up too much.  If this one only got hotter it would be nice; I don't really care about the massage feature.  My heating pad hasn't broken yet as the other reviewer experienced.  I'm still using it for now
I'm surprised that no-one has commented on the overly complicated knitting/purling method used in this book.    The book shows only one way to make a knit/purl stitch
column2: and it's slow and torturous.  You insert the right needle into the stitch as you normally would when knitting or purling
column3: but then you hold the point where the needles intersect
column4: pick up the working yarn with your free hand and wind it around the needle.  Then you pick up both needles again and complete the stitch as usual.  This method would frustrate any child
column5: enough to get them to stop knitting altogether

column1: Would have been a better book if the author had stuck to the subject of Freemasonry instead of spreading misinformation about the OTO.  The author does a disservice to the reader who might not know any better
column2: as well to the many fine Masons who enjoy membership in both Freemasonry and the OTO.  Perhaps if he had spoken to one of these Brothers some of his misconceptions might have been corrected and I would encourage the Brother to consider interviewing a few Masons who are also OTO members for any subsequent editions or other books so that information is more factual and less sensationalized

column1: I was placed on The Mediterranean Diet by my physician because I need drastic improvement in my cholesterol levels. If you are looking for ways to get started or for recipies
column2: don't buy this book! Although Mr. Wright seems to have a winning reputation and the book is filled with authentic
column3: flavorful recipies it does not relate to heart-based eating. The ingredients include eggs
column4: full-fat yogurt
column5: cheeses
column6: shellfish such as shrimp
column7: and butter. Choosing and buying this book was my mistake; I just don't you to make the same one! You will find it a complete waste of money if heart-health is your goal. Buy The Mediterranean Heart Diet by Helen V. Fisher instead

column1: A very boring and stupid film about college freshmen with a kindergarten maturity level. The movie is horribly slow to get to the point and is riddled with nonsense dialogue: I've heard better lines in 'Fast Times At Richmond High' thank you.    Altogether a very forgettable film that has a lot of talk about nothing. Don't believe the great reviews about this film: the film might appeal to the 14-17 year-old crowds fantasizing about how 'cool' college life might be with all the 'cool' people and 'parties.' If you're not in that category
column2: skip this boring film and save both your time and your money.

column1: Never could connect with the main character in this book.  She mostly seems cold and impersonal to me.  She's described as "nice" by other characters in the book
column2: but she's mostly condescending and rude to them
column3: as when she tells the postman to "bugger off" after he tells her "good morning".  Didn't feel any warmth or affection for her family either.  They are superficially drawn and seem to have little connection to each other.  The husband is uninvolved and disinterested in his family's life.  Mostly disagrees with wife on everything.  The village seems lackluster and full of unhappy
column4: discontented people.  Nothing charming or engaging about it to make one feel that it's "cosy".  Bleak and dreary is more like it.  Not much to the story line either.  I figured out the basic plot early on and I am usually the last to know what's going on.  Don't recomend this book at all
